country:
None
text:
I like this recipe for certain things like raisin, cinnamon or walnut bread, but as a table bread it's a bit too sweet for my taste.  I cut the recipe in half and put the ingredients in my bread machine on dough cycle with 2 1/4 tablespoons of yeast.  When cycle is complete I roll it out with a rolling pin into rectangle, brush with melted butter, sprinkle brown sugar and then add nuts, raisins, whatever and roll it up into a bread pan and bake when it has risen again 1/2 inch over top of pan.  A great breakfast bread.

text:
Great as written but much bettr if you use MILK instead of water.  I always substitute milk in any recipe where water is called for.  The milk lends a richer taste and helps retain moisture in the bread.  Make sure the milk is warm too before adding to the flour.

text:
I bake a lot of different breads and love trying new recipes.  I read the reviews on this one and it sounded so promising.   I think the mistake was that the recipe says bread flour (which is DIFFERENT than all purpose or self rising flour) and that made it the consistency of pizza crust...dense and very chewy.  On a positive note...If you reduce the sugar to 1/4 instead of 2/3 of a cup, you get a tasty dough for pizza crust.

text:
The only addition I can come up with is as follows:  When proofing the yeast, only add two tablespoons of sugar to the mixture; also add just a dash of vinegar to the mixture if you have soft water.  Yeast like and acidic atmosphere.  We also copensated whole wheat pastry flour for a quarter of the flour for more tenderness, also adding a tad bit more water for the whole wheat.  Other wise the recipe is wonderfull!  P.S. Don't overwork it or you'll end up with flat bread, which is also excelent!  Good luck all!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Magnificent recipe for a delightfully sweet, moist, and dense bread.  A great sandwich bread, keeps for a few days (if one manages not to eat it in that time), excellent for crispy-on-the-outside-moist-on-the-inside toast.  It is perfect for dinner rolls; I also enjoy making a few doughnuts with the extra scraps after forming my loaves - just fry and douse with cinnamon & sugar!  I find that I add an extra 1-2 cups of flour during kneading because the dough is very sticky otherwise.  The rising time varies with different yeasts and approximated water temps, but the rule of thumb I use with this dough is simply to monitor its rising cycles rather than to go by time. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
One of the Best breads I have ever eaten.  However, I edited it the first time I made it (partially on accident) and it was much better that time.  I only used about 1/2 cup of sugar and cut the yeast back to 2 teaspoons.  It made a very moist bread.  If it is made that way you can cut very thin delicious slices.  PERFECT!  The second time I made it I used the full amount of yeast and couldn't cut it as thin and it dried out much quicker.

text:
I used this recipe as my first serious attempt and home made, non-bread machine bread, and the outcome gets better and better each time I make it.  I have made this recipe at least once a week over the last 6 weeks and have found the following changes have made the perfect bread: I use a half Better for Bread white flour, and half Whole Wheat flour.  I add 1 teaspoon extra yeast for a fluffier wheat bread and I substitute the sugar for 1/2 cup dried honey (found in a local helth food/cooking store). I also increased the temp to 375 degrees. The outcome is soft, fluffy, Honey Wheat bread that makes great sandwiches and the most wonderful french toast.

text:
The best recipe.  I make it almost every other night now!  I also play around with the recipe!  I made an italian version and a sun dried tomato version.  Just add dried garlic, garlic power and italian herb when mixing in the flour.  Finish it off with egg wash, dried garlic, herb and parmesan cheese.  For the tomato one, I used the oil that come with the sun dried tomato instead of veggie oil and add sun dried tomato...yum yum yum!  If you don't want the bread to be so dense, let it rise a little longer or punch it down and let it rise again!  It will give you a fluffier bread !!!!

text:
Awesome recipe!  Followed the instructions for the KitchenAid Mixer users, and used only 2T sugar--Also, used Bread Machine Yeast (it was in the fridge), in the amount suggested, and it just kept rising!  I used mini loaf tins, and weighed the dough at .75 lb per tin (made 4 loaves and a smaller loaf) I will try less next time, as the tops of the bread were huge! (cute though!).  
I also tossed icecubes in the bottom of the oven throughout the cook time to provide a crusty exterior to the bread--terrific!

Perfect with the blue-ribbon chili recipe from this site, as well as with the fluffy french toast recipe.  This will be my go-to white bread recipe...THANKS!

1099719
Display Name:
pionergirl
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Came out awesome after making bread quite a few times and messing every recipe up. Here is what I found out: 1)water that yeast is mixed into HAS to be at whatever temperature the recipe calls for. Too hot and it kills the yeast, too cool and the yeast won't foam up. 2)for perfect rising every time I heat oven up to 200 degrees. Turn oven OFF when it reaches 200 and immediately put bread dough in for one hour. I do not put a towel or anything over the bowl (make sure bowl is well oiled). If dough has not risen enough then leave in oven until it has. Make sure not to open the oven a bunch of times to see if dough has risen enough. The more you open the door the lower the temp in the oven will be for the rising dough. 3)make sure not to over knead the dough. For me this is a learning process of how the dough feels when it gets to the "done kneading" point. Knead it too much and the dough will be "tough". 4)when dividing the dough in half I used to pull dough apart in the middle and my loaves never looked right. I now use a pastry cutter (metal rectangle thingy) and just cut down the middle. 5)after dough is done rising DO NOT pull it out of the oven and sit it on counter to allow oven to heat up to 350 degrees (cooking temp). Leave the bread in while temp rises and cook for a few minutes less if the top begins to get too brown.  I followed another reviewers suggestion and did an egg white wash on top of the loaves and it came out perfect.

This is a great recipe to try- easy even for a novice to bread making.  I tried it several ways; with less sugar, with part wheat flour, etc.  Came out perfectly every time, even with several changes.  I do always have to cook it for about 40 minutes though, and let the second rise be about an hour before putting it into the oven.  I like the sweet taste from 2/3 cup sugar, but with 1/2 cup sugar it does taste more like plain white bread.  Have fun with your bread making!

I made this twice - the first with limited sugar and the second time with the called-for amount; my husband ignored the first batch and devoured the second!! This was my first successful loaf! I let the bread rise in a slightly preheated oven for both rises, and I let the second rise go for at least an hour. I also cover with plastic wrap, so I don't ruin a towel if it rises too far. I cook for 35 minutes and cover the bread with foil for the last 3 minutes. Very tasty- thank you!

text:
Edited to say:
You really need to use the bread flour, not all purpose flour.  I tried two with bread flour and two with regular, and the ones with regular flour came out all wrong.  YOU MUST USE BREAD FLOUR or don't rate the recipe badly.

This is the first time i've made actual bread, though i've made everything else involving yeast.  Turned out great!  I could only find one loaf pan so I used an 8 inch cake pan for the other one.  I actually wished I had used both cake pans, as there were more "heels" with a round bread!  I don't find this recipe to be at all sweet, it's just fine.  My only problem was that the second rising took one hour instead of 30 minutes.  They rose better when I put them inside the turned off oven than when I had them on top.

text:
It's hard to say something that hasn't already been said about this recipe. Let it suffice that I took the time to register an account on this site just to say, "Thank you!" to the recipe's author and give this five stars. I bake all of our family's bread these days and this just became our new standard. I made two loaves; regular (per the instructions) and cinnamon sugar (melted butter, cinnamon, and a little brown sugar spread on the dough before shaping). I haven't tried the cinnamon yet, but the regular loaf is absolutely perfect. If you're thinking of trying this bread let me encourage you to follow the recipe to the letter for the first time. You can adjust the sugar later if you'd like, but it's not as sweet as some reviewers would lead you to believe. This bread is a dead ringer for what mom used to make and it's an excellent example of a heartland supper table staple.

Finally... a bread recipe that worked for me. I've tried and failed several other recipes and this one didn't turn out like a brick.

It took a lot longer than 30 minutes on the second rise to get 1" above the pan.

----

I've started using this recipe for cinnamon rolls and it works great!

After the first rise, I roll it out flat and apply melted butter, cinnamon and sugar in improvised quantities. Then I slice roll them into rolls and let them do the second rise. My family loves them!

text:
This is pao dulce (Portuguese sweet bread) and also a base bread for pan de jamon (Venezuelan Christmas bread). As soon as I saw this recipe I knew instantly what it would taste like--soft, sweet and chewy. My father was a bread baker for over 20 years in Venezuela (he is originally from Portugal) and this bread was always in our house. I urge everyone who is thinking about making this to go ahead and try. It's very easy and the results are superb. Wow, I was flooded with memories as I was making this bread---everything from how to test the water temperature for the yeast to how to properly knead the dough and shape the loaves. Lovely memories indeed. Thank you Peg for submitting this!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A great recipe to start baking with!  Mine turned out perfect for sandwich bread, not crumbly like others said.

You can make this more healthy by using whole wheat flour instead of regular flour and by only using one tablespoon of sugar instead of half a cup (use this sugar to proof the yeast).  

Also, you can leave out the oil.  However, make sure to use oil to line the baking sheet and the bowl that you let the bread rise in, otherwise the dough could dry out and stick to the pan.  

If you don't use any oil, make sure to steam the oven.  For the bread's second rise, you can place the dough in a cold oven with a pan of hot water on the bottom of the oven.  Leave the oven closed until the bread rises again.  Take the bread out, preheat the oven, and put the bread back in with the pan of water.  This adds moisture to the dough: the lack of oil will make the bread dry out otherwise.

text:
This recipe reminds me of childhood.  I can't remember how many times I came home from school on a rainy Oregon day to warm loaves of homemade bread.  I've given yeast bread a few half-hearted attempts over the years, but haven't had much success.  My bread turns out heavy and flat with a tough bottom crust.  I had pretty much given up hope when I decided to try this recipe.  I did misread the recipe, using 1 1/2 tsp (One yeast packet) but I didn't even realize it until the bread was done, and it had baked up light, fluffy and fabulous anyway.  I thought it a bit odd that others said they would use a loaf of bread for a gift, but after making this I can't wait to do the same.  Thank you, Peg, for making me a bread maker, and for the lovely reminders of more carefree days!

Display Name:
Bethany Hussung
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3496850.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe! The taste is great! But according to the directions the bread seems to come out dense. I work in a bakery as a pastry chef and just recently started making bread. It had been on my "wish list" of things to make in a while. I made the bread according to bread guys KA mixer instructions, except, after first rise I rolled my dough out into a long rectangle and rolled it up like a cinnamon roll. Then I tucked the two ends under and set for the second rise. I put the pans on my stove with the oven on. It keeps it warm. After a half an hour it didn't look fluffy enough so I waited another half an hour. It was big and stood about an inch above my pan. So let your bread rise for an hour instead on just 30 minutes and it will come out fluffy and not dense! Enjoy!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-06-05T09:18:02.223

userID:
15837587
Display Name:
DarlingMissLovette
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my favourite go-to bread recipe, I make it regularly and my family loves it! Great for sandwiches, toast, or to compliment dinner. I always braid my loaves, which gives it a professional and impressive look-- if I'm making some to go with dinner I'll bake a braided free-form loaf on a cookie sheet, so it can either be sliced or pulled apart. For yeast packet users-- I used to open a few packets and measure out 1 1/2 tablespoons, but one time I was in a rush and just used two packets without measuring. It came out perfect, so that's what I do every time now. I've also always used all-purpose flour rather than bread flour, and I've never had an issue. It is fairly sweet, which I love, but if you prefer your bread a bit more savory I might consider reducing the sugar (as I've seen other reviewers suggest). I used this recipe when I was just starting to learn about baking bread, and I have never ruined it-- I would definitely recommend it for beginners :)

None
text:
This is my new standard recipe for making easy yeast bread at home! It turned out delicious and was quickly devoured by the family. For those who complain of dense bread, or it being too sweet, make sure your yeast is fresh and to let it get thoroughly "started" before proceeding with the recipe. The longer you leave the yeast in the sugar-water, the less sweet and more of a sour dough taste you'll get. Also, make sure to kneed the dough enough to develop adequate gluten so it's not too dense or crumbly...

text:
Absolutely love this recipe I make it all the time and only a couple adjustments Ive made to the recipe over the many years I've been baking it. First before raising second time I slightly cut down the center of the loaves to make them split top then I actually let it rise a full hour the second time this makes it just perfect. Everyone loves it. I also cover the tops of the loaves towards the end with foil to reduce browning on the tops of the loaves then I brush it with melted butter after taking it from the oven. Great recipe. Thank you!

I have been weary of white sandwich bread. And I love making bread. I've made challah, dinner rolls, pizza rolls, etc. But white sandwich bread, I just couldn't. text:
Wow. This was the first recipe I made with my new Kitchen Aid stand mixer.  Thank you to breadguy for the tips in his review!  This bread brought the best compliment I have ever received on something I made: my husband compared it to his grandmother's famous bread.  That brought me to tears.  *Update: When this comes out of the oven I immediately brush it with olive oil or melted butter, then cover with plastic wrap as it cools. That helps soften the crust.  I made a batch with half bread flour and half whole wheat flour, and that was declared to be the best bread yet.* *2nd Update: this works well for sweet rolls, like cinnamon or orange, and I have also used it to make a stuffed loaf (Stromboli type).  *Update 3: add garlic and Italian herbs before making into Stromboli!* Bottom line: this is a great, easy, versatile recipe.*

text:
I made this bread for the second time this morning.  The first time I made it, it didn't turn out the way I had hoped, but it was my fault! First, I decreased the sugar - only used 1/3 cup; second, I used my stand mixer with the bread hook but obviously didn't knead the bread as long as I should have because I could taste the yeast.
This time I used the 2/3 cup sugar called for and kneaded the dough in the stand mixer until the dough was crawling up the bread hook.  When I took it out of the bowl, I continued to knead it by hand for a few minutes more, ensuring all the ingredients were well mixed.  The end result was two perfect loaves, that baked up perfectly in 30 minutes.  I couldn't resist the smell of the fresh baked bread and cut a couple of slices right away!  Absolutely amazing and what surprised me, is the sugar was not overpowering in the finished loaf!  Having nailed this recipe, I am not sure I'll ever use my bread machine again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yes, this bread is sweet, but it has a key word in the recipe:  AMISH.  Amish make the bread sweeter than regular white bread, and the sugar also lends a hand to the proofing of the yeast.  It reacts faster and becomes much thicker than regular bread recipes because the yeast feeds off of it.  I highly recommend this bread as a sweetbread, but if you're wanting to make it not so sweet, just halve the sugar in the beginning.

text:
This has become my go to recipe as my husband adores it! For those saying it's too sweet, you need to remember that this is a traditional Amish recipe. We have Hutterite family friends here in Canada and their bread is very sweet as well. This is probably why my husband always asks for this recipe so much, it reminds him of visits from friends from the colony at his grandparents farm! This has become a family favourite...thank you for sharing it!

text:
1/8/2013 I cut the recipe in half and combined it all in my bread machine on the dough cycle. After that first rise, I took it out and forgot to knead it lightly. I just put it straight into my loaf pan to rise again, yet it still turned out and tasted delicious! I used it to make Mom's Gourmet Grill Cheese Sandwich, and what a wonderful sandwich! This bread made grilled cheese something special! 3/13/2016 I make the full recipe using my KitchenAid Mixer. So easy. After mixing all ingredients together using the dough hook, I oil the mixing bowl and set it on a heating pad to rise. Then I punch it down, put it in 2 loaf pans, and set them on the heating pad to rise before baking.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this bread.  It has replaced store-bought bread for us, we have made it every week for over a year.  We use 2 cups whole wheat flour and 3 cups white bread flour.

The recipe makes 2 loaves.  If you only need one, go ahead and mix up the full recipe, then after the first rise, divide into two dough balls and freeze one.  Just wrap tightly in plastic wrap and freeze.  When ready to use let it thaw in the bread pan and it will rise once thawed.  Tastes just as good as fresh loaf.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I found a secret!!  Add 1 Tbsp of Whole Ground Flaxseed Meal.  OMG, It makes it softer and better than 5 stars.  I'm no health guru, and would probably frown upon reading a review like this.  Healthy most of the time means it doesn't taste as good.

I've made this recipe over 30x normally, and it comes out soft and good. But add the 1 Tablespoon of flaxseed!  Its essentially healthy fat which I have since learned makes all breads softer.

I now use 1/2 of recipe in a bread machine to make this bread.  

We eat it plain and used it for grilled cheese sandwiches /french toast.  Needless to say this recipe helps us kick up everything in our house.

text:
I made this bread with my KitchenAid mixer and it was a breeze. After adding the flour, I mixed on speed 2 (using the dough hook) for about 3 minutes and then let it rise, punched it down, divided into two loaves and placed each loaf on a baking sheet which I sprinkled with cornmeal (the cornmeal gives the loaves a nice texture and appearance). The only reason I am giving this bread two stars is because it is VERY sweet as other reviewers noted. I will definitely make this again because the consistency is wonderful, but I will reduce the sugar by half as a starting point.

text:
Absolutely fantastic, and so easy! The only problem is, I have to make all four of my kids a loaf when I make it!This bread freezes well, and you can also divide it into 12 rolls before the second rise, and they are just as yummy! I bake the rolls until they are just turning brown, let them cool, seal in an airtight container and freeze. When I need dinner rolls, I take them out, let them thaw, preheat oven to 350 degrees and bake 10-12 mins. Tastes just like fresh!!

city:

country:

text:
I have made this bread many times now without any issues what so ever. I live in ohio and the flour amount is perfect. This makes me about 2 bread pan sized monster loaves or one really long bread pan loaf.  I use half the amount of sugar thats called for in the recipe as my goal is sandwich bread. I also use about 2 tbs of yeast instead of 1 1/2 it gives it a slightly stronger yeast taste like you get in store bought bread. I have started using grapeseed oil instead of veg simce istaying away from gmo's. Olive oil is too heave, it makes it dense. I make this in a bread machine so i add the water, salt, sugar and oil first then the flour on top, and finally the yeast. I set it to dough which mixes and rests for about an hour and a half. Then i put it in the pan and rise again. No hand or mixer kneeding, no proofing the yeast. Its so simple! We dont buy store bread anymore. This is perfect.
Review:
Rating:
5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think this is the easiest bread recipe I've ever tried.  I followed the advice of others and cut sugar to 1/4c.  I also made this in my Cusiniart mixer, using the bread hook to mix up the yeast mixture and then the dough.  I put a shallow pan of hot water in the oven and covered the bowl with a damp cloth while proofing which worked great.  I punched the top down with my hands and then used the mixer to knead the dough again for another 4 minutes on the lowest speed.  Instead of making loaves, I pinched off the dough in 1.5" balls and laid them out next to each other on a cookie sheet.  I let them rise and then lightly brushed the top with beaten egg whites.  I ended up with about 48 dinner rolls although there are much less now! :) These turned out perfect and my family raved about them.

Ace recipe, this has become our staple. No more buying bread.  Thank you for sharing this!! city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delightful! 

Made a half recipe (only 1 loaf).

Used 1/4 cup warm water to dissolve yeast & set aside. Used remaining 3/4 cup warm water to dissolve sugar & salt while yeast was dissolving (approx 10 min.). Used greased pan & also added a little oil.

2nd rise took a little longer than 30 min., but rose faster when I placed it on top of my pre-heating oven- I'll do that from the beginning of the second rise next time & see if it rises faster. 

After 25 min. of baking the top was plenty brown.  May check earlier next time or reduce temp. 

Wonderfully good!!! Good substitute for sour dough bread if you don't have a sourdough starter! Highly recommend the recipe!!!  I'll definitely be making this one again!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this bread for a couple of months now. It comes out great every time! I make a healthier bread by using 2 cups bread flour and the rest whole wheat flour. Also I have used 2 cups bread flour, 3 1/2 cups Whole Wheat flour, add 1/4 cup of Flaxseed Meel and 1/4 cup of Wheat Germ. Even the picky eaters don't realize that this bread is healthy. This is a very easy recipe to make to adjust and make what ever you want. Less sugar for dinner rolls plain or add some Italian seasoning to the mixture shape brush with melted butter and bake. A little more sugar great for Cinnamon rolls or Cinnamon raisin bread. Thanks for posting!

userID:
4332463
Display Name:
Judith A Corey

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/662540.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed this EXCEPT for the kind of flour...I used all purpose and I have to say, it turned out wonderful.  It was  easy, and I will use it again and again.  I made it with my Kitchen Aide mixer and used some of the tips I found in the reviews.  Thank you so much.   ***
As an update....I still use this recipe every week, and I have taken to rolling the dough out into a rectangle shape and then rolling it into a log, trimming the ends so that it will fit into a loaf pan and it comes out perfect.  DON'T moisten it to make it "stick", put the seam side down and you will be just fine.  When I use it to make rolls, I add a touch of vanilla, use butter instead of oil and I do NOT KNEAD IT or roll it out.  I just pinch off a golf ball size piece, roll it into a ball shape and flatten it just a tiny bit, place them in a greased pan with the rolls not quite touching, let it rise for an hour and bake like you would the bread, at 350 for about 17 minutes.  If you want them to be shiny, beat an egg with a tsp of water and brush the tops before baking.  Brushing them with butter is nice, but they don't get that shine to them

For BREAD MACHINE users, just load in these ingredients in the same order as any recipe: water first; then flour, sugar and salt; (canola) oil in each corner; then yeast in the well in the middle.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe and so easy to make!  I had never made bread before and decided to try it.  On the suggestion of a friend for a good white bread, I used 2 Tbsp. of sugar instead of what the recipe called for.  I used my Kitchen Aid mixer with the dough hook to mix it all together.  I wasn't sure what the yeast was supposed to look like but went on the article on AR to see for sure (it was completely obvious when it started proofing).  I ended up baking mine a little longer in my silicone bakeware (turned out beautiful) because I did one loaf, 12 dinner rolls and a "pretzel" out of what little dough was left.  I would like to have a taller loaf next time so I might use the entire loaf in one pan.  I let it "rise" for the suggested 30 minutes after I put it in the loaf pan but it didn't grow in size a whole lot.  Other than that, it was such an easy recipe to follow and a great one if you've never made bread.  Thanks for sharing!

userID:

Display Name:
friscomom

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I add 4 tablespoons of cold milled flax.  Its adds a really nice nutty flavor and makes the bread more moist.  I also make this recipe by hand.  It takes little time and does not mess up the mixer.   I have been making this for a few years now, so I have the process down and memorized. It takes me about 20 minutes to prep it and get it in the bowl to rise (that includes the 10 minutes to wait for the yeast to proof) and about 2.5 - three hours total (that includes all the waiting time).  Its important to know total time as you proabably want to be home during that time.  Its also important you get the water temp correct.... for me its exactly 1 minute in the microwave. I use this bread each week for my kids and husband's lunches, for toast and even for Thanksgiving stuffing this year.  My guests LOVED the stuffing and complimented it not knowing the bread in it was homemade.  I also buy my ingredients in bulk at costco, so the cost of this bread is really cheap!

text:
This is fantastically delicious. I cut the recipe in half because I only have one bread pan. Except for that I didn't have any bread flour and had to use All Purpose, I followed the recipe pretty much exactly. I didn't measure the sugar precisely and I may have only used 1/4 cup for a half recipe. I allowed it to rise 1 hour, punched it down, kneaded into a loaf shape and let rise in the loaf pan another hour. Baked 25 minutes @ 350. PERFECT! It rose very well. I haven't let it cool yet, and just cut the end off so I could taste it right away (because I'm starving :) I'm going to let the rest of it cool and see how well it makes sandwiches. I may just use this recipe for white sandwich bread from now on if it works out OK. I would also like to try it as a wheat version....hmmm and the cinnamon raisin version others suggested sounds delicious!!!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Soft, fluffy, sweet and perfect height.

When making bread, the amount of flour is always a suggestion.  In my case, I used just over 5 1/2 cups but once I got to 5 cups I added flour by the tablespoon; so to avoid adding too much flour (which would result in a denser loaf)-- I do not have a mixer so this was all done by hand.

Based on the amount of sugar listed in the ingredients list, this bread would obviously be on the sweeter side.

I just had the first piece and it was indeed a sweeter loaf, but expecting that, my husband and I devoured our butter slathered pieces harmoniously!  

Also, for a yeast bread, this certainly doesn't take much time to whip up! 

I would absolutely make this again!

country:
None
text:
Made as recipe stated, the bread is a bit sweet for my taste (why it got 4 out of 5 stars).  I then tried halving the sugar like another reviewer suggested and now I have a white bread that BEATS any I have tasted in the supermarket!  Tastes great and wonderful texture too!  Also if you're out of bread flour, just use all-purpose flour.  You will still get a great loaf of bread!  I used my KitchenAid mixer to kneed the dough.  About 5min of kneeding after the dough comes together then into well oiled bowl for the 1st rise.

country:
None
text:
This is my second attempt at baking bread...the first time was about 20 years ago and suffice to say it was such a disaster that I have not attempted to try again until I saw this recipe and all the great reviews. It was easy and turned out perfect! I took the suggestion about reducing the sugar to 1/4 cup and I think this is good. I would probably increase it to 2/3 if making a sweet bread such as cinnamon rolls. I won't need to look for another recipe, this is perfect. I thought some readers might like to know that I split the dough into thirds and put them in well oiled aluminum loaf pans from the dollar store. I think I should be able to use them several times. I live alone and am diabetic so I don't need a large loaf. Baking time was the same, 30 minutes.

text:
A great bread, although it's a little too sweet as written - I reduce the sugar to 1/2 - 1/3 cup when I bake it, put an egg wash on top, and it comes out very fluffy and flavorful. 

It makes pretty round loaves with a little sesame seed sprinkled on top of the egg wash, and I'm trying it as cinnamon bread right now! This is a good, versatile recipe and my new go-to bread.

text:
Delicious recipe!  I followed BreadGuy's top-rated comment as I have a KitchenAid stand mixer, and used 3 TBSP of organic sugar rather than the 2/3 cup.   This is the most successful bread I've made yet, in terms of the initial rise and how large the loaf got while in the oven!   These loaves are nice and tall, and a good size for sandwich bread (others I have made haven't risen as high, and end up puny in comparison to the lunchmeat!)  I weighed my ingredients, and everything came out perfect at exactly 30 minutes.   Thanks!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe as is, no adjustments, is delicious. I was looking for a sweet white bread for Easter dinner and this is perfect. I used a bread machine, adding the yeast and 2 tbsp. of sugar to the pan with the warm water and oil first. Then I added the flour, rest of the sugar, and salt and used the dough cycle. Once done, I removed the dough from the bread machine, kneaded, divided it into two, shaped into loaves, placed in greased 9 x 5 loaf pans and let it rise in a warm spot for 1/2 - 3/4 hour before baking off. Kids loved it!

text:
OMG...this is the best bread! I made it exactly as written. Since I haven't made bread in years I would consider myself a novice. A couple of pointers at least for myself is that I had the water heated to 110F but once I poured it in the "cold" bowl it dropped 20 degrees so I put the sugar and water in the microwave and heated to 115 after adding the water/sugar back to the bowl it was perfect. Other point, my house is cool after waiting for the dough to rise on the kitchen counter for 45 minutes it did not rise at all. I put it in front of my heater and it rose perfectly in about 30 minutes. I am sure there are other ways..perhaps a warm oven that would work great.  I do not think this bread it too sweet with the recommended sugar.

text:
This was my first bread baking experience & it was awesome! Very easy and straightforward, a great starting point for making your own bread recipes. I have used this in combination with a coffee cake streusel topping to make cinnamon swirl bread. But by far my favorite is a Whole Grain variant with a quarter cup of honey and maple syrup. Topped with pecans, oats and, you guessed it, more maple syrup. Truly amazed my friends and impressed their parents; its kindof a healthy alternative to a doughnut and goes great with your morning coffee.

text:
I make this bread all the time! The trick is to be patient when waiting for the yeast to proof. Don't rush it! The foamier it gets the more light and airy the bread. If you do you will get a denser bread.

text:
Since I was little I had always wanted to try to make bread, but my grandma always told me it was too hard.  Not so with this recipe.  I make loaves of this to go with potato soup and also just as gifts.  The first time I made this for a family friend, half of a loaf was gone within 5 minutes of me slicing it!  I sent the other loaf home with them and they used it with their dinner.  What amazed me about it is that they only eat whole wheat bread but they loved this recipe.  I did change one thing and that is I halved the amount of sugar so that the bread wasn't too sweet.  This is now my uncle's favorite food that I make (the first time he had it, he ate nearly the entire loaf in a night!  He said it was so good he couldn't stop).  This is such a good recipe!!

This bread is awesome.  It's easy to make, doesn't require a bread machine (or even a mixer!) and has turned out great every time I have made it.  As other reviewers have mentioned, the bread does have a slight sweetness to it, which is really yummy.  As an aside, I did have to sub in olive oil last time I made it, as I didn't realize I was out of vegetable oil until I had already started.  It turned out just fine, though, and you couldn't tell any difference in the taste.

text:
This bread is incredible!!! My little sister now wants her own loaf for her birthday... so she can have the whole loaf to herself :D For excellent sandwich material, instead of all sugar, use 1/4 honey and 1/4 sugar omitting the other half of the sugar. To make bread for french toast, use the total amount of sugar that the recipe calls for, but split it with honey. It's stunning that bread can taste so good! Thank you so much for this recipe, I am not ever trying to make another white bread for sandwiches ever again!

text:
Great recipe, I've used this one several times. I've since used this basic recipe. I use only 1/4 cup of sugar and about 4 table spoons of honey, it adds a bit different of flavor as well as speeds up proofing the yeast. Then I sprinkle a bit of oats in the loaf pans. About half way through the baking I lightly brush homemade whipped honey butter on the top crust and sprinkle on some oats. And tadaa honey oat bread.  All in all a great recipe for beginners and leaves room for experimentation which for a cook is always a good thing.

text:
I am giving this bread 5 stars.  I have a few pointers though.    First, make sure you let the yeast proof, at least 10 mins, but I wait 15. )  and Next,if you have to knead the dough by hand,  make sure you kneed the dough until completely smooth. (yes your arms will get tired, but I find that the less you kneed the dough, the more air pockets you have when its done. ) And I personally hate air pockets inside my bread.

text:
Wow, am I glad I found this. I was looking for a bread recipe that wasn't designed for a breadmaker, which so many on this site are. I gave mine away a few years ago, because I was never happy with the results. Had some trouble with proofing the yeast, which wasn't the fault of this recipe, just bad yeast from the supermarket (even though used well before the expiration date). After finally getting a nice foamy head on the water/yeast/sugar mixture, the rest was a breeze. I always thought you had to use milk, because my mother always did, but this turned out better. For my white bread loaves, I did cut down sugar to 1/2 cup, which still produced a very slightly sweet nice flavor. I used the recommended 2/3 cup sugar for some cinnamon swirl bread and it was just perfect. I'm going to make cinnamon rolls for a brunch next weekend and will go with the recipe as written aslo. Thanks for sharing this great recipe.

userID:
4785058
Display Name:
MissyLou
isPro:

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I accidentally rated the Amish Bread recipe, meaning to rate this one. I started on a quest to bake our own bread (family of 6) several months ago, and after trying numerous recipes, this one wins Hands Down. Only thing I don't add is any sugar....no need for it if you don't like sweet bread.  This recipe comes out perfectly each time. I even cut the recipe in half and no problems. I also don't cover the bread when it's rising. If you coat your bowl lightly in oil, then put your dough in and twirl a few times, it's coated and won't dry out. It's usually oily enough on top even when I put in the bread pan to rise the 2nd time...I mention in case any of you have issues with bread deflating when you take the cloth (or oiled cling film) off after rising.  When I make the double loaves, I bake one, and freeze the other BEFORE baking it. Just pop 1/2 of the dough in the bread pan just after you knead it (not after it rises first time), wrap in cling film, freeze. To bake, pop in warm spot and let defrost/rise over several hours (about 3), then bake. PERFECT loaf.  If you have any problems at all with this recipe, check the flour you're using. Strong Bread Flour is only one that works for me. Oh, and I also use extra virgin olive oil and sea salt. We always bought our bread from the local baker who makes excellent bread, but my husband now prefers mine saying it has more flavour (nice baker bread tastes like paper, and we don't go near the grocery store bagged bread!)

LOVE this bread. I have tried bread before unsuccessfully even in a bread machine, BUT this recipe is fool proof. I didn't have to add quite as much flour bc it was elastic and smooth with 4.5 cups. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making bread with my mom since I was little and this bread is replacing hers...(shhhhh, don't tell her).  This recipe gave me two large dense loaves with soft crusts that sliced like a dream and are great with meat and cheese.  I have doubled the recipe with no trouble, rolled cinnamon/sugar into it for cinnamon bread, made cinnamon rolls and sticky buns with it and made picture perfect dinner rolls.  Wow, this recipe is very versatile and simple.  I've decreased the sugar to 1/3 cup for one batch and didn't really care for it- I guess I like my sugar.  I also used all purpose flour with no problem.  You can't go wrong with this recipe.  If you are having trouble, do a little research into breadmaking in general, so you don't mess up the steps - like running the water over your wrist to make sure it's not too hot (it should be warm, but not burning hot).      Other than that, this recipe is pretty foolproof and will give you bread to rave over.

text:
9/16/09  This bread is sooo delicious!  I made it exact to the recipe, although I did brush some egg wash over the top (1 egg mixed with 2T water) prior to baking which made a nice shiny crust.  It was sweeter than white bread, but still very good.  Next time I might experiment with the sugar just for fun, and possibly substitute some wheat flour or even try all-purpose flour.  For the 2nd rise I let it rise 45 minutes.  I don't know why some reviewers say this bread is dense because I did not think so at all.  Maybe they usually eat Wonder bread or something.  This is the first bread in years that I've made start to finish totally by hand - I usually use my bread machine, if not for the whole recipe then at least through the first rise.  This recipe is SO easy.  Thank you!  It's definitely going into my collection for our enjoyment for many years to come! - - - - -

11/11/09  I tried this again today with only 1/3 cup sugar and it was a bit less sweet, but just as yummy!  I love it both ways.  It's delicious made as a sandwich with ham and honey mustard.  Next time I'm going to try making it into cinnamon bread. :)

I never proof the yeast unless I suspect it might be too old, + I keep yeast in the fridge.  The bread is very easy to make, is very light but easy to cut and doesn't crumble, so it makes good sandwich bread and toast.  I used Robin Hood Flour from Canada (which is very fine, like silk compared to regular flour which is velvety).  It raised so well my husband said it looked like it had a parachute open.  Very good bread, I will make it a lot.

I have been making this bread for a couple of years now. It was the first bread I ever tried to make. I love it! My family loves it! It is so easy and quick. About 3 hours start to finish. I have used this recipe to make cinnamon sugar bread also; just roll out the dough nice and thin and spread a couple tablespoons of milk over the dough. Then top with a rediculously thick layer of cinnamon sugar, roll up, tuck ends under and bake as directed. If you are looking for a bread to be your first, this is it. Thanks Peg!! We LOVE it!!

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So Good. Its a little sweet, but not to much. It was the first bread I've ever made, and it turned out perfect. Just a few notes though. You want your water to be between 86 and 99 degrees F. You dont want it to be to hot or you'll kill the yeast. I let mine proof about 15 minutes, give or take. Then I do like other ppl say, and mix it in my mixer, on low, adding 1/2 cup of flour at a time. you have to use bread flour. There is a difference. After its pretty well mixed, I mix it medium for 5 minutes, take it out, make it into a ball, drizzle with oil and let rise for an hour, punch it down, and let it rise again. If the room isnt extremely hot, I usually have to let it rise for 1 1/2 hours.

country:
None
text:
This is a really good recipe due to its taste.  I substituted veg oil with corn oil and used all-purpose flour instead of bread flour.  The bread still came out succssfully and I am really glad I decided to try out this recipe.  I've made bread before and a really helpful tip is to proof the yeast before any other steps.  Proof the yeast by combining the active dry yeast with the warm water and sugar ingredients, let it rest for about 10 min.  By then, the yeast mixture should have double in volume/size.  This is another way to insure that your yeast has been "activated".

I am eating this bread as we speak and it is delish! My husband and I are homemade bread fanatics. I didn't cut back on the sugar I like sweet stuff. It is sweeter than most white breads. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very forgiving recipe - used KA mixer throughout. Proof yeast in KA mixing bowl then add the oil and salt, then add the flour 1 cup at a time with the dough hook on low speed. Once all the dry ingredients are in come up to medium speed for 5 minutes. Then take the dough out, fold it over on itself to redistribute the yeast, make a ball, and place it back in the same bowl after you drizzle a tablespoon of oil (veggie or olive) and turn the dough to coat evenly. Cover tightly with plastic wrap and then a kitchen towel.  Can reduce the sugar down to 2 Tbsp for a less-sweet farmhouse-style bread.

userID:
21907115
Display Name:
Allrecipes Community
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was great! I made one loaf and 18 rolls from the recipe. I followed the suggestions of others and only added 1/4 cup sugar. I think the most important part to this recipe turning out well is to make sure you use good yeast, the proper temperature of water (110-115F) and let it proof for 10 minutes. At the first rising, the dough had doubled in size in only 30 minutes. I kept the rising dough on top of the stove while the oven was on at 350, I think this also helps. This bread turned out crunchy/golden on the outside and soft on the inside. The rolls took 20 minutes and the bread took 30. It's definitely a good basic bread, I plan on trying this with cardamom/cinnamon, more sugar, and raisins next.  Update: I made this with the right amount of sugar, cinnamon and raisins. It was FANTASTIC. I added 1 cup of raisins before the batter firmed up. Kneaded and let it rise. Separated the dough into 2 pieces. I rolled them both into large circles, wet the tops and then poured a sugar and cinnamon combo on top of each (1/2 cup sugar + 2 tsps cinnamon divided for both). I rolled both up and left one for a loaf. I cut the other into slices to make cinnamon rolls. Let rise for 30 minutes, and then put in oven for 20 (rolls) and 30 (loaf).

text:
I made this with instant yeast, kneading well and placing directly into the baking pan and letting rise to 1 inch above the edge.  I let it rise in warmth and with a wet cloth on top.  These loaves baked to perfection.  The baking time, for me, was 12 minutes, then rotated in the oven and baked another 3 minutes so it browned evenly.  The crust is super soft.  I lined the whole pan with parchment paper and oiled it well.  This ensures a soft crust.  The whole thing took me an hour to make.

text:
Easy and quite yummy as is. I don't think it's anything other than it claims to be -- a basic white bread that each baker can tweak to his or her own tastes. ETA: The second time I made this I did some experimenting. Instead of cutting the amount of sugar, I used 2 tablespoons of sugar to proof the yeast and then replaced the rest of the sugar with 1/2 cup of honey, which I added with the other ingredients. The honey adds flavor and reduces that over-sugared flavor.

text:
This was a very simple bread to make from ingredients I always have around the house still waiting to taste it but I trust that it will be spectacular! For all the people who have trouble proofing the bread, try sticking it in the oven with the light on and door closed, DO NOT heat the oven, the light works fine on its own. I live in Canada and even when it is -40C outside and my house is only 17C with drafts my breads/buns always rise beautifully.

I knew this would be a bit too sweet for me, so I cut it back to 1/4 cup honey.  In addition, I beat two egg whites and added them in with the wet ingredients.  You'd be surprised what a bit of beaten egg white can do for bread.  For a fluffy, slightly lighter bread than this recipe, try the Grandma VanDoren's also on this website.  Makes three loaves.  Sooooo good!

text:
This recipe deserves all the wonderful reviews. Im new to bread making and have tried a number of recipes but this is the one and it is really so versatile. It makes the best sweet dinner rolls and fantastic cinnamon rolls. I have also reduced the sugar and made a braded loaf, something like an Italian loaf and a regular loaf. This is also a very forgiving recipe, I started out using bread flour, but have now made it with just plain all purpose flour, Ive added things like garlic powder and Italian seasoning and just cant seem to mess it up  it has come out great every time. Try it as written and then have some fun with it. Kudos to Peg for such a fantastic recipe.

userID:

Display Name:
Harlii
isPro:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading almost all of the reviews on this recipe, I almost didn't try it. One, I have no electric mixer, having broken it within the last 2 weeks, and two, all of the "it's too sweet" sort of scared me. But I'm glad I forged ahead.

This was the simplest recipe I've tried so far. Not a lot of fiddly ingredients, straight-forward directions. There are three things I changed regarding ingredients: I used 1/2 cup of sugar, 3 tsps. of salt, and regular all-purpose flour.

I had no trouble with the yeast/water/sugar at all. I didn't time it; I just watched it until it was good and foamy. I used a whisk to add the flour, one cup at a time. I was able to use the whisk alright for the first 3 cups of flour, and then I simply used my hands to work the last 3 cups of flour in. Not a problem at all.

I kneaded the dough for several minutes and it was just a perfect texture...I was really pleased. I drizzled just a bit of oil over the kneaded dough and worked it all over, then placed it in an oiled glass dish. I placed the dish with the dough into a larger bowl filled with 2 inches of warm water. After 30 minutes, it really hadn't changed at all. So I added more hot water to the larger bowl. After 30 more minutes it had risen a bit, but not double. I then put the entire thing (both bowls, covered with plastic wrap and a dish towel) in the oven, turned the oven on for 30 seconds or so, then shut it off. After another 30 minutes it had risen a lot more. I turned the oven on again for

Like others, I cut the sugar down to 1/4 cup.  But, I also brushed a mixture of honey and melted butter on the top of the loaf after it had baked, which added a light sweetness that was delicious.

Since I didn't have two loaf pans, I just fashioned half the dough into a round loaf and baked it on a greased cookie sheet.  I think I still prefer the simplicity of store-bought bread for quick sandwiches, but this bread is so good that it was worth the work.

Awsome bread!! I think I will reduce the sugar by a couple of tablespoons next time (even though I love the sweetness! - but just to make them a wee bit healthier).  I also added 1/2 cup bakers special milk (from King Arthur Flour), three Tablespoons soy granular lechithin (to help give it a longer shelf life - also available at King Arthur Flour Baker's Catalog) and reduced oil to 2 Tbsp (and added about 1/4 additional water. These loaves turned out very high, perfect texture and flavor - Will DEFINITELY make again!!  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Wonderful! When I saw this recipe on the top 20 list, I knew I had to try it. It was so easy to make! I was a little worried at first because I had no bread flour, and I only had bread machine yeast. But, it worked out fine. It made the best bread I have ever made, and I have tried several recipes. Next time I am going to use a bread machine and see how that works. I did not think it was too sweet in the least. I used the recommended amount of sugar and thought it was perfect. A lot of the other reviews said to cut the sugar in half, I wouldn't. My bread did not raise one inch over the pan, but that is probably because I did not have bread flour. I also put my bread in a 170 degree oven to rise, this worked wonderfully. However, next time I will put a damp towel over it because the top got a little dry. All in all this is the best bread on earth!! Almost one whole loaf was gone before it had even cooled! I just ate two pieces with butter! I am going to have more for supper along side a big bowl of homemade soup! Yum Yum! Thank you so much for this recipe! I printed it, and I am going to make it again and again and again!

text:
It's been a while since I've made white bread from scratch but I was having one of those "earth mother" days and breadmaking fulfills my need to nuture. We loved this recipe.  Dough was tender; I used only 5 cups, reserving 1 cup of flour for kneading so as not to add too much flour, toughening the dough.  I found I didn't need the entire amount.  Dough rose beautifully, and baked golden brown and soft.  Aroma filled the house with homemade goodness.  And I won't go into how heavenly it was...warm with melted butter.

text:
This is by far the best homemade bread I have ever had.  I halved the ingredients and ran my bread machine on the dough cycle (after proofing the yeast).  Then I punched the dough down and put it into a loaf pan to rise again.  It always turns out wonderful.  Once it rose so high the top of the bread hit the oven top, the pan was on the middle oven rack!  I make this very often and everyone loves it!

text:
This is a wonderfully easy sweet bread that I use as a base for countless variations.  I use it to make cinnamon rolls, or to make a jelly roll style loaf with raisins or cranberries.  Sometimes I substitute 1/2 cup of oat bran for 1/2 cup of flour.  For a nutty flavor I add a half cup of grape nuts to the dough.  

Just an excellent simple starting place for some of my favorite kitchen experiments!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this twice now, the first time, I followed the recipe to the letter, and it was good. It was kind of dense though, so when i made it the second time, I let it raise for the first hour, punched it down, and let it raise again for about 20 minutes, then put it in bread pans, and let it raise for ANOTHER hour, it takes a lot longer, but the results were WELL worth it. I made two loaves last night, and they are both already gone!!
The other thing I like about this recipe is that it was SO MUCH EASIER than a lot of other bread recipes I have tried, I think because it uses water and oil, instead of milk and butter.
overall it's really good, and I will be making it to take to my Mother-In-Law for Thanksgiving.

Absolutely great bread recipe. The only problem I had occurred when I mixed the dough in the bread machine the first time I made it. I think this added the flour too fast, and this recipe really needs the flour to add in slow. It still rose but it took a long time! The second time I made it by hand, and it was just fine. The bread has a great, slightly sweet taste, and the texture is wonderful.

This recipe is wonderful.  I'd kept the bread in the frig wrapped in foil and it doesn't dry out.   It's great for toast.  Haven't tried freezing yet.  It's moist, tasty and much better than our "store-bought" white bread here in the USA.  My ""picky"" husband that wouldn't eat his mother's bread loves this one.

Recently, I started baking again after a long absence. I thought I'd lost touch.  Tried some of the recipes with starters and felt something was wrong with me.  This recipe helped me realize it's just the recipe not the baker/cook.

Thank you for this recipe.

Linda

I'm a "new-bie" baker and this turned out great! One secret I've found in baking which I'm sure goes for most all recipes is that you need to keep dough warm to get it to rise better.  I stick mine in the microwave while rising (do NOT turn microwave on) , because it's warmer in there than sitting on my counter. Thanks Peg!

text:
After dividing the dough in half, I rolled it out flat and rectangular. Then I rolled it from the end rather tightly and let it rise the final time.  Add another 15 minutes to the rise and the tightly rolled loaf rises without huge air holes and wont tear as easily when putting on spreads.   I also used only 1/4 cup sugar and it tastes great!

Ogre

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This a great and simple bread recipe for the experienced bread maker or if it is your first time making your own bread. this makes two very nice sweet white loaves that do well with sandwiches and makes an awesome french toast.

For the first time breadmaker, just follow the recipe as it is. I use either Feishman's or red dot yeast. Make sure the package says quick , instant, or rapid acting.  Other yeasts will do the job but they take longer to rise and are more finicky about temperature.

I have adjusted the recipe a bit for my everyday use, I use 1/4 cup softened butter instead of the oil, I also use 1 cup whole milk and 1 cup water for the liquid. I think it improves the taste a bit . I like the buttery taste in my bread.

I liked it but this recipe is way too sweet for my taste unless it is to be toast for jam. It was easy to prepare and a nice texture. 

I made one loaf and 8 large buns from one batch. The buns baked 24 minutes to a golden doneness.  I tried to brush garlic salted butter on them to cut the sweetness for a more savoury dinner roll but it was just a sweet garlic bun. . Ha! My kids ate them and I haven't finished the bread yet but my gut tells me a loaf of this size at 350 degrees will take more like 45 minutes to bake. Will keep this easy recipe to tweak to my taste.

text:
I made this bread and like some of the other reviews I cut the sugar to 2 teaspoons.  It is easy, easy, easy to make.  If I make it again I will cut the receipe in half.  It seemed to dry out after a day or two and with two loaves difficult for just me and my husband to use up.  By day three I had to toast it with butter because it was so dry.  It was the first time I have ever made homemade white bread and it was a breeze to make.  I did keep the loaves in plastic so they wouldn't dry out but it didn't help.  The first day it was fabulous.

text:
I have been searching for the perfect bread recipe that was crazy soft, has the perfect flavor and didn't require a bread machine or kitchen aide. If you are also searching for it look no further! This bread is fabulous! It is so soft and contrary to my original concerns about such a large amount of sugar in this bread, it actually wasn't sweet at all yet had a very savory flavor. I'd say it was similar to a buttermilk bread but not quite as sour. The only things I really did to the recipe, was make sure to brush the whole loaf with melted butter after it was baked but still hot. This doesn't effect the flavor so much as just the texture of the crust, it makes it incredibly soft. I also didn't follow the secondary rising time. I let the dough rise in the bread pan to the desired shape and size I wanted the loaf. I will definitely be sticking to this recipe from here on out.

This is an excellent bread recipe. I tried it as written and it was a bit too sweet for me, so like many others I reduced the sugar to 1/4 cup. I now make it weekly and we easily eat both loves.

userID:
15717930
Display Name:
Cherlyn786

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made correctly this bread is soft, fluffy, and delicious!!! I don't know if this will help anyone, but I too had problems with my bread coming out dense. I think I've pin pointed a few thing that might be contributing to this. The first few times I made this I paid extra attention to the yeast due to the reviews. Then I got into a hurry once and made a few errors. The result being dense and not so great bread. I put together a few tips since then to prevent this problem. 1. Having your water too hot  can kill your yeast, it really does only need to be warm! 2. Use a smaller bowl for your dough to set in. The dough uses the sides of the bowl to 'cling' to as it rises. Too large of a bowl can cause your dough to sink into itself. 3. Really watch your flour and salt! Salt will hinder the growth of the yeast, you'll notice a distinct decline in the  height of your dough if you use too much salt. The recommended amount in the recipe should be followed closely. Following these tips alone I've not had to start weighting my flour out. If you continue having issues after making these changes I would recommend doing that as well!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2015-05-03T10:29:22.557
helpfulCount:

city:

None
country:
None
text:
have made this several times when I want an easy bread to make.  I would def recommend cutting the sugar down, I usually cut it in half. A good trick for making sure your dough rises is before you start your recipe, heat your oven to 200 degrees F and once it's there, immediately shut it off. By the time you are ready to let the dough rise, it will be optimal temp. If you think it's too hot, open the door and cool it for a bit. Works every time.

text:
I really liked this bread.  It is denser than most breads I have made which I like.  And with all the sugar, it has a sweeter taste too, also the salt really lends a nice flavor.  It does taste like "Amish" white bread we get at the Amish bakery in Sugarcreek Ohio.  I used 1 cup of whole wheat flour and while kneading had to add an extra cup of white flour to keep it elastic and not sticking.  Thanks for posting this recipe, it is my "go to" bread from now on.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very easy to make.  I divide my loaves into three instead of the two posted in the recipe, and use the full amount of sugar ( I have a huge sweet tooth) ...My neighbor gave me some yeast from Costco and it seems to stretch the dough for this recipe.  I also use a kitchen aid mixer and I only use about 5 1/2 cups of flour because my machine gets too wobbly.  If I find the dough too sticky when I take it out of the bowl when stirred I just add more flour when I kneed it before proofing it in the oiled bowl.  This recipe doesn't contain eggs so if you have people that have allergies to eggs this is a fantastic recipe.  I have stopped my search for the perfect bread recipe!Thank goodness for Amish and old school recipes from the past.....

text:
My first time baking bread and I have to say, its the BEST bread I've ever eaten!!  I'm shocked that I actually made home made bread!  It is a little labor/time intensive, but WELL WORTH it!  Do it ONCE, you'll be hooked!!  I followed the first reviewers instructions as I made it with my kitchenaid and dough hook and it was easy. The most difficult thing about it was the water temperature. Really "warm" was what I would call it. NOT hot, not "Luke warm" either Best to use candy thermometer to be sure around 110*.  If time permits, I'm baking bread weekly, no more store bought!  Thanks for awesome reviews... so helpful!!  *I only used 1/3 c of sugar as I didn't want "sweet" bread, just nicely flavored sandwich bread.  Think I'll stick with that amount.

text:
I make this 2-3 times a week.  Some notes:  1)This is a perfect first recipe for someone wanting to try making bread. 2) There is a lot of sugar in this bread, and it is sweet.  3)  The toast from this bread is incredible, probably due to the sugar (think "roasted marshmallow" for as sugar is heated).  4)  My rise times are very much slower than advertised, perhaps 6 hours or longer, due to a cold apt (70 degrees) or perhaps not kneading it enough?  But the "bread experts" tell me this is okay, and in fact, desirable.  5)  I put "some" molasses (1/3 cup?) into a batch once to rave reviews (reduced the amount of sugar a bit tho, perhaps to 1/3 cup).

text:
Made this bread 5 times. Love it! I've used different amounts of sugar every time. 1/3C is the best. I also started my water at 48degrees. The bowl & waiting for the sugar will bring it down to 45degrees by time you add your yeast. Wait about 10 mins for yeast to proof. I use stand mixer. This bread is so easy. I've only needed 5 1/2 cups adding 1C at a time.

I'be had a few bad experiences trying to bake bread in the past and was hesitant to try this recipe since it seemed so easy. It look me a few months to build up the courage to try it. I was very pleased and will use this as my go to recipe for bread.

I cut the recipe in half since there are only two of us. I substituted a half cup of whole wheat flour just because I was feeling adventurous, even though it's supposed to be white bread.

I used melted coconut oil in place of the vegetable oil and it was delicious. It makes it sweeter so it's more of a breakfast/ snack bread.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'd never made bread from scratch before.  Almost a fool proof recipe.  I used my ninja dough blade to mix the first batch, I didn't check the temp on my water before adding the yeast, and I ended up putting all the dough into my 13x4x4 USA bread pan (worth every penny guys).  The bread was great for the most part, but a little underdone in the center, rose out of the pan a bit, and it had a slight "yeasty" taste.  

The next batch I made, I actually made sure the water temp was around 110, and I put only 2/3 of the dough into my 13x4x4 bread pan...I put the remaining 1/3 of dough into a separate 9x5x2.75 pan.  I also kneaded the dough by hand this time (for only about 2 min). --- TURNED OUT PERFECT.  I mean it is ridiculous how painless this was to make.  I used it for sandwiches, toast, and dipping into an herbed olive oil...yumminess.

Had not made bread in years since the bread machine broke.  Wife bought me a KitchenAid mixer so figured I'd give this a shot.  1st time was a success and we love the taste/texture.  Making another batch today.  Literally just dump all the dry ingredients into the mixer, including the yeast, let it run for a minute, then add 112-degree water (I do measure the temp), let it run for a minute then add the oil.  To rise I put the bowl in the utility room where the furnace and water heater are.

city:

country:
None
text:
Reliable recipe that never fails to turn out.  I have made exactly as written (except for halving it so I make one loaf at a time) at least 20 times.  It is very forgiving re rise time, room temperature (winter versus summer), yeast age, etc.  It is simply reliable, and the result is very good bread that holds together well in the toaster for a great breakfast (with a little butter).  Thanks for sharing.

Update:  I have reduced the sugar to generate a lighter bread.  I usually make one loaf at a time, so that would be 1/3 cup sugar using the recipe.  I use a little less than 1/4 cup, and it turns out great.  I use a stand mixer to knead, and add flour  until the dough cleans the bowl.  After the first rise, I use the mixer to knead the dough for a couple of minutes before it goes into the loaf pan.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe. For those of you that said it turned out too dense and that it called for too much flour, how much flour a bread recipe calls for is more like a guideline. Altitudes, climate, and even seasons will change how much you put in. I myself have varied a whole cup amount in the same location, but the season was different. After you've added the first 3 cups you want to add just half a cup at a time so it doesn't end up too dense. The less flour you add, the lighter/fluffier it will be. If it is still sticky but can stay in one piece if you hold it up, that's about where you want it. I just made it yesterday again but did half brown wheat and half white and my husband and I both liked it better. I always get compliments when I make this and have had several people ask me if I added gluten because it doesn't crumble and is very moist. I have found that most bread recipes are great right out of the oven but are crumbly and dry the next day, but this one stays good for about a week and a half before it starts to get a little dry. Love, love it :)

Also 15 minutes before I took my bread out I did an egg wash with a whole egg and a splash of water for color and a more firm crust.  Just my preference.  You could just as easily do a butter wash after it is done baking.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1482259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This bread turned out great! Very soft and flavourful, with a nice crust on the outside (not too chewy). I did, however make a few simple modifications. First off, I read all the other reviews about how it was too sweet, so I used only 1/3c plus 2 tablespoons of sugar. Perfect sweetness! I also used potato water (water left after boiling potatoes) instead of regular water. I used regular all purpose flour which worked just fine (maybe better if you like a softer bread). And I turned them into large buns baking at 27 minutes. I also brushed them with egg wash (an egg beaten with a tablespoon of water). Couldn't be happier with it!!

Edit: I added an egg to the dough and made it into my own cinnamon rolls :) mmmm!

Edit number two: I also tried this recipe with half whole wheat and half AP flour and it was wonderful!

I have made MANY bread recipes having worked in bakeries for many years. I'm a stay-at-home-mom now and was looking for a straightforward bread for my family to enjoy on a daily basis (mostly for sandwiches). I wanted no fuss, no muss, and no expensive ingredients. Display Name:
Happyschmoopies

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2719006.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely perfect!  This is the first time I have made white bread and I found a winner! The recipe was fail proof for me - it rose perfectly and baked in the exact time of the recipe. I used rapid rise yeast because that is wheat I had in the house. I actually added the yeast to the sugar and then added the water.  I was afraid the water would cool down too much if I mixed the sugar and water first.  I ended up using not quite - 5-1/2 cups of flour to get to the correct consistency.  I have a hard time distinguishing what sounds like "hollow" to check for doneness, so, I just checked it with an instant read thermometer.  I took out about 190 (based on what I read on the King Arthur flour site) and it rose to about 198 degrees.  I will definitely be making this again! UPDATE:  7/17/17 Do yourself a favor and make this bread!  It is wonderful!  It reminds me of Hawaiin rolls, but, not quite as sweet.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just tried this recipe and followed "breadguy's" instructions. worked perfectly. putting the bread in the oven to rise works wonders. This is the fluffiest bread I have ever made. It is very sweet, which I like but I might try making it with less sugar next time as the sweetness doesn't work with all sandwiches. The person who posted saying it was dense probably didn't let it rise enough on the second rise or had a draft. I have been struggling with making bread for years and I finally  started doing a proper second rise and the dense bread is no more! Good luck

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6027390.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good base bread recipe, but I change it for my purposes.  I prefer wheat for nutritional purposes, so I do 3/4th of the flour as whole wheat flour and 1/4th of it white just to give some levity to the bread.  I also only use 1/3 cup of flour, unless I intend to use the dough for something sweet, like cinnamon rolls, then I'll do closer to the amount the recipe calls for.  I use coconut oil instead of vegetable oil.  I also add pure gluten to make up for the fact that I don't use bread flour (which has a higher gluten content, so I prefer just to keep regular flour and add gluten when needed).  I also add a little dough conditioner.  I made this without the gluten and dough conditioner, and it was still good, but those two things make it rise far more and make it more soft, airy and less likely to dry-out.  Definitely worth adding to it!!!   Makes for a delicious bread, which I make each Sunday to last us through the week.  :)

text:
I love the simplicity of this recipe and the results are typically good.  The bread taste great and it's super easy to make.  With that said, I do sometimes have issues getting my yeast to proof.  Sometimes it will a little, sometimes not at all, sometimes like magic it proofs great and the dough rises really well.  Not sure why I get such inconsistencies.  I use good yeast and always make sure my temp is just right.  I know this is not the fault of the recipe, but just thought I would share my experience making this bread.  Good luck and enjoy.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My very first time making bread was an astonishing success! Because I was afraid of wasting ingredients - in case I messed this up - I scaled the recipe down to make only one loaf, which I would suggest if it's your first time, too. (**Notes for first timers: My first rise took quite a while because my house was so cold. It ended up taking half the day to rise until I finally decided to put it near something warm. That did the trick! So don't give up if yours doesn't rise - consider moving it somewhere warmer. Also, kneading the dough after that first rise, man, I was convinced I was going to get a brick! I kneaded it for a while, trying to make it "soft" because when I took it out of the bowl and kneaded it "a bit," it was a very heavy, small and non-stretchy ball of dough! I let it rise the second time for more than 30 minutes near a warm spot again, praying it would rise that 1" AND IT DID! And it was so delicious! So don't give up in case you have problems like me!**) After reading suggestions to cut the sugar down for a more "traditional" white bread taste,  I found it was still a tad sweeter than normal white bread, BUT I am way more excited to try it with the full sugar amount since now I know it'll probably taste exactly like Hawaiian bread!!! Since my oven runs hot, I only had to bake it 25 minutes. Excellent recipe, will not stray from it in case my bread making mojo gets squashed by another recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Versatile is certainly the right word for this bread! I've made it with bread flour, white flour, and half whole wheat flour/half white flour. I let it cool in the pan for about 10 min. before turning the bread out onto a large plate and rubbing a thin coat of butter all over the crust. I like to make 1 loaf regular Amish Bread and the other loaf Raisin Amish Bread. To do so, follow step #1 as normal. For step #2, stir in the salt, oil, and 1c. flour. Divide between 2 bowls. To the 1st bowl (regular dough), add 2 1/2c. flour. For the 2nd bowl, add 1 tsp. cinnamon, 1 tsp. white sugar, 1/8 tsp. nutmeg, 1/3-1/2 c. raisins; stir, then mix in 2 1/2 c. flour. Knead each dough separately, and allow to rise in 2 well-oiled bowls. Follow remaining steps as original recipe.

text:
A really good, basic bread recipe. I made this and baked one loaf right away but stored the dough in the refrigerator and made the second loaf 3 days later. I will say that I liked the second loaf better because it wasn't as sweet. I guess the yeast ate up more of the sugar while the dough was sitting.
However, even the first loaf was very good. I'm just not a sweet tooth type of person and prefer the other way. So, I am making the recipe again today but will wait to bake it for a few days.

text:
I have been making this one for years and used it in many different ways. One thing that has been bugging me about it, though, is that it's really crumbly and dries out quickly. It's dense and not flaky in a good way. I want something more fluffy that melts in my mouth. It uses minimal ingredients, which I like, but I'm left longing and on the hunt for another easy delicious recipe. I'd give it 3.5 stars if I could.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this bread for years and have made over 200 loaves! Everyone loves it! Adjust sugar to taste. If you use suggested amount the taste is similar to Hawaiian bread. 

If you do not want to kill your yeast follow these helpful tips: make sure your water is between 105*-110* if it is 120* and above it will kill the yeast. Salt and yeast do not get along! Salt kills yeast. Do not add the salt until after you mix in 1 cup of flour. 

If using a Kitchen Aid mixer with dough hook use stir setting until all flour is added then bump it up to 2 until dough is smooth. Do not go higher than 2!

text:
Very easy bread recipe.  I make bread all the time for my six young children, and this is always my base recipe.  Usually I reduce the sugar to 1/4 cup unless making a sweet bread (like cinnamon swirl).  This is truly awesome bread.  A tip to make it stay softer longer is to add 2 TSBP of dry potato flakes to the dough; and lightly butter the top of the bread when you pull it out of the oven for a silky crust.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe has been a big hit every time I have made it. It is especially tasty coming straight out of the oven when it is warm and moist. I suggest leaving it in the oven for 35-40 minutes, not 30. This might just be personal preference, but I find that taking it out at 30 minutes, as suggested in the recipe, was not enough. 

HAVE GREAT YEAST... and if you don't, dissolve it in slightly warmer water, as well as let it rise longer and in a warm, dark place. 
 
This bread is very sweet, which works for my taste buds but not my waistline!

It is quite dense, but nonetheless: amazing.  It is great if you are on a budget as well, and can be done in using one bowl and a 9x5 inch pan. Yay for less dishes! I did not have to knead it on the surface, finding it easier (and a lot less messy) to knead in the bowl. 

It is extremely versatile: a great white bread base.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This might be the lightest, sweetest loaf bread I've ever made.  I followed the instructions except for the rising time.  It took 2 hours for the first rise, and that was by forced proofing.  After placing the dough in the loaf pans I force proofed the dough again for  80 minutes, until the dough was 1" over the top edge of the pan.  It baked in 20 minutes at 350F.  (Forced proofing is done by placing the dough in it's bowl/pan in a hot (110-120F) water bath.  The water should only be deep enough to submerge the bottom 1/2 of the bowl/pan).

text:
Delicious bread!  Soft, but nice and substantial.  But I do agree with the majority of reviewers that it is a bit too sweet.  I reduced to 1/4 cup, but the bread tasted a bit too "yeasty".  Increasing to 1/2 cup made it too sweet, so I think I'll try 1/3 cup next time.  Makes lovely sandwiches, toast--anything you could think of making with ordinary white bread!  Thanks for the recipe!  If you're using the individual packets of yeast, use one packet per loaf, or two packets for the whole recipe.
