text:
I can bake great cookies, but I have always been terrible at baking bread--even when I had a bread machine. It would always come out dense and doughy with a big air bubble at the top. In fact, I haven't even tried for years, but decided to try one more time and I am so thrilled to find a recipe even I can make! I made it exactly like the recipe except that I took other reviewers recommendations to cut back on the sugar. I used about a third of a cup and probably could have gone down to 1/4 cup. (It was still slightly sweet). 

It baked up light but with a good texture. It was great with just butter on it, but this morning I toasted a few slices and topped with butter and cinnamon. It was fantastic! I can't believe I actually made that loaf of bread.

i have made this recipe every week for years. but today i made orange rolls out of it and it was amazing. i rolled it out, added butter, orange marmalade, a litle brown sugar, and fresh nutmeg. rolled and cut and they melted in your mouth.  of all the recipes out there, this one is the best!!!
if its too dense, you are adding too much flour. i use 4cups with a dash more when divide into 2 loaves.  it will look very sticky but will turn out very light.  if its too sweet use half the sugar.

text:
I just started making bread last weekend and this was the 2nd recipe I tried.  I really liked the flavour of this bread and it reminds me a lot of the bread my grandma made.  I asked my family and friends to tell me which one of the two different recipes they preferred, and no one could really answer that.  However, a few did say they thought they preferred this one.  I ate it with butter, toasted, in a sandwich and used it for a grilled cheese and in the end I 'think' I prefer the other recipe (Traditional White Bread from this site).  The ONLY thing that tipped the scale, and only very slightly, was that it didn't seem to hold a sandwich together, grilled or otherwise; I found the sandwich fell apart, and no, I didn't slice the bread too thin.  I still gave it 5 stars as I don't think it would be fair to give it less until I make both recipes a couple more times, just to compare them a bit more.  Will definitely be keeping this one on hand.

text:
Excellent recipe but heed Breadguy's advice if you use a Kitchen Aid mixer.  I learned that it isn't necessary to preheat your oven when making bread, whatever the recipe - honest!  That will be appreciated more in the summer.  This is my second try and I threw in an egg to keep it fresher longer.  This is a gorgeous loaf no matter what you use it for (husband is chomping on a turkey and havarti sandwich) and makes marvelous cinnamon rolls! (remember, tho, de gustibus non est disputandum  - there's no (point in) arguing about matters of taste.  An alternate but equally valid interpretation is 'if you don't agree with me, you have no taste.'(joke))

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So easy; this was probably the easiest bread I've ever made (and I've made a bit!). The second rise took almost three times as long, but I waited for it anyways; definitely worth it because the loaves didn't rise much in the oven. The loaves are sweet, but not overly-sweet, and it'll be perfect for breakfast and dinner.

I did do ONE THING differently but it had nothing to do with the mix; I put a cookie sheet on the bottom rack in the oven while it preheated and right when I put the dough in, I threw 4 ice cubes down real quick and closed the door. The added steam really hardened up the crust nicely, making this SUPER easy to slice. I recommend it if you like crusty breads!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good recipe.  I tried it today and varied it a bit to suit my style of baking.  

I prefer weights to volume measures for flour.  So, I used 2 pounds (32 ounces) of flour.

I prefer butter to oil, so I used 1/2 stick of butter of melted and cooled butter instead of the 1/4 cup of vegetable oil.

It baked in 32 minutes and had a beautiful, thin, light brown crust and a delicate crumb.

I tried a slice spread with butter and a slice toasted with butter.  They were delicious, but a tad sweeter than I prefer.  Then next time I bake this bread (soon), I'll drop the sugar to 1/2 cup and I may reduce the sugar further depending on the taste.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an EXCELLENT recipe for white bread! I don't think you could go wrong with it, bu here are some tips! 1. Weight your flour instead of using cup measurements. It is more accurate. 2.lower the sugar for a fluffier and less sweet bread. 3. Rub shortening on your hand before you knead the dough, prevents it from sticking to your hand. 4.Make sure you use GOOD AND NEW YEAST. Thr first time i made the bread i use some left over old yeast and i came off really bad. I switched to SAF yeast and my bread came out wonderful.Also be patient and wait until the yeast misture is foamy and creamy. Trust me, it is worth the wait. 5. When i am in a hurry, i mix the dough first.put it in a oiled bowl cover with plastic wrap and put it in the fridge. After about 6 hours the dough rises beautifully! I punch it down then knead it for a few more minutes 6. I tried using all-purpose flour instead of bread flour and it works just fine. You might need a little more flour and the texture is slightly different. 7. Don't put too much oil in your tins, the dough will absorb it and prevent it from rising. 8. They make great buns! Just divide and shape them then bake for around 20 minutes. (try adding a tiny sausage in the middle!)  9. Brush butter on the baked bread to give them a great look and better taste.

text:
Have made this recipe twice and it seems fool proof!  I took the advise of several, weighed the flour (762 grams), used 1/3 cup sugar, 2 tbsp yeast and used bread flour.  The dough raised FAST and the loaves raised FAST and I had beautiful tall, loaves of bread.  There was no heaviness or coarseness.  This bread is light as air and perfect for sandwiches... or warm with butter.  10 stars!!!

text:
Thanks Peg.  Family crisis this month due to daily bread production halt; the machine broke.  Don't need one anymore, though!  I use 3tbsp sugar; 375deg for 30 mins.  Mornings are cold here near the water and 2nd rise takes 40-50 min unless I put it in the warmed oven. Dough seems to repay heavy kneading with a smooth pretty crust.  Tuck the edges down hard after punching into the pan and the top balloons perfectly.

I just tried this recipe today and I absolutely loved it! I always read some lower reviews along with the higher reviews just to get an overall feeling of what I should expect, and I think that helps. So if you're reading this, you're already on the right track. My mom tried it and went "Oh, my goodness, this is SO good." AND IT IS! It's not too dense and not too fluffy. I'm giving it four stars because I decided to use 1/3 cup of sugar instead of 2/3 and even with half the amount of sugar, my mom and sister said it was "sweet somehow". Maybe the original Amish White Bread is supposed to be sweet, I don't know. I suppose it is a matter of preference. ANYWAY, I will definitely be making this again in the future. Maybe I might try it with 2/3 cup of sugar if I'm feeling it.

Used original recipe with BreadGuy's advice for proofing with a KitchenAid mixer. Thank you! Easy bread recipe. Came out crusty on the outside, soft on the inside. Hearty consistency. If you're looking for a light bread from the grocery shelf, this is not for you. Have made this twice. I took out a 2-month old frozen loaf yesterday, thawed and reheated it. It was still good though crust was not as crusty, other than that, no complaints. Take the time to make this, it's worth the effort!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3292791.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
turned out great this recipe is a keeper, one of the best breads ive made in a long time, I converted it over for my bread machine to do all the mixing and for that I have a few warnings that I experienced 

most bread machines only hold a 2 lb loaf so what I had to do so this recipe wouldn't blow the top off during the proofing cut the flour down to 4 cups which is the max for a 2 lb loaf if yours only holds 1 lb loafs your gonna have to cut that in half 

after the machine is done in the dough cycle "after proofing and kneading" for mine thats a hour and a half take the dough out on a lightly floured surface and work in the rest of the flour "knead it very well" and this recipe makes two perfect loafs of bread, I egg washed the top of the loafs before baking and they came out with a nice shiny crust 

I highly recommend you do not cut the 30 min sit in loaf pan out after kneading the remaining cups this builds gluten and will reward you with light fluffy loafs of bread with a uncommon consistency you can not get in store bought bread

thank you for a great bread recipe

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/2414.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used the 2 cups of flour called for (recipe split in half for one loaf, and flour lessened to original before the change), plus just another 1/4 C to get it just un-sticky enough to handle, turn a few times and get into the oily bowl for rise.  (*just made another loaf of this bread and had to sub 1/4 C gluten flour, turned out not as white, but great) I did the oven trick for rise that someone shared.  (*this time for warmth I set the dough to proof on my running dryer in the laundry room).  Well, this turned out to be the most perfect loaf of sandwich bread- very soft, yet with this gluteny durability I've been after.  (*my 2nd loaf even better than first- was running out of flour, so BARELY made the recipe, and resulting dough was BARELY handlable.  But it was just workable, and didn't take much working prior to first proof, and not much at 2nd.  When I got it out of pan after cooking, I thought it was liquid inside it was so soft, but it was not!  It turned out my best cooked loaf- no raw spots and not too dense in the least.  Light and strong.  I did not use bread flour, but unbleached AP, again.   One thing>> I will use much less sugar next time....it is too sweet for what I want.(I used half the sugar called for this time, and it was much better for us, not tangibly sweet). I really appreciate finding this posted recipe for white bread- it's a great one. SIMPLE- you're likely to have the ingredients on hand. Also added egg wash and poppy seed this time. Yum.

text:
Ridiculous how good this bread came out!! Made it yesterday, and I can guarantee it will be gone after lunch today! The one I've been making is perfect for toast and such, but this one is absolutely perfect for sandwiches, buttered bread, etc...The only adjustment I made was cutting the sugar in 1/2 (to 1/3 of a cup), and it was plenty. Any more would have been too sweet for sandwich bread. And I used the K.A. to kneed it on setting 1 for 5 minutes. The bread came out awsome!

text:
Wow!  This bread is amazing!  I made it exactly as written except I halved the recipe and used my Kitchenaid mixer.  Thanks for the mixer instructions submitted by other reviewers.  My second rise took a little over an hour.  30 minuted in the oven, and it came out perfect!  So moist and fluffy and light.  The sweetness complimented the savory bean stew I served it with.  Didn't even need butter, it is so good.  It's comes out sweet as written, but not cake sweet.  I will try other's suggestions and make it with less sugar to use as a sandwich bread.  Thanks for the recipe, Peg, it is a real winner.  And gave me some confidence to experiment further with bread making.  LOVE!

I have been making htis bread for years now, it is so easy and super yummy, I only use 1/3 cup sugar.  ANd I don't worry so much about "proofing" the yeast...I do use really warm water and then sugar stir and then add the yeast and stir...it always comes out fine!  Enjoy!  You can also use this for pizza crust, hot pockets, cinnamon bread, or roll flat and fill with lunch meat and cheese and roll up and bake for a finger food

text:
This is fantastic!  Easy to make, sweet and yeasty heavy bread.  It is great to serve with or before any meal.  After mixing the dough, for whatever reason- maybe too cool in my house, my dough did not want to rise but you can put it in the oven covered on warm or with the oven door cracked to help it rise.  At any rate it turned out to be a good heavy sweet yeasty bread great for sandwiches or a side to any meal.  It is easy and cheap enough to make that it's worth it to make once a week and not have to buy bread at the store!  Thanks for sharing the recipe!

country:
None
text:
My absolute go-to bread recipe even in a recipe box overflowing with bread recipes! By simply following the steps you can't go wrong and this is quite possibly the most versatile and adaptable bread recipe on the entire site. 

I've made it just as written and gotten rave reviews and taken other's advice, dropped the sugar to around 1/4 cup, and had the same people raving again! The sugar content definitely makes all the difference in the world with more sugar equaling a denser bread. 

I've used this recipe to make everything from sweet breakfast breads to salty herb-filled Italian bread by tweaking the sugar and add-ins and just couldn't be happier with it either way.

Take the time to give this one a shot and you may just toss your other recipes - with this one, one is all you need!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-02-13T03:31:31.8
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
8797858
Display Name:
scmLovely
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
3
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this bread! I'm not sure if I'm doing something wrong, but I cannot get that white fluffy store bought bread, but on the other hand, I really like this MUCH better. it's slightly sweet with a light chewiness, and fresh out of the oven I could eat a whole loaf! I've made this a few times, first following the recipe exactly and came out with a sweet-bread consistency, pretty dense and very buttery and sweet. I cut down the sugar to 1/2c for my second batch and had basically the same results, only having a slightly fluffier bread. Again I cut down the sugar (desperate for that "sandwich loaf") to 1/4c, and finally had a great loaf of bread. My husband and I ate an entire loaf within an hour out of the oven! It was still slightly sweet but definitely the best bread EVER.
KITCHENAID USERS: proof your yeast in the mixing bowl, then add your salt & oil. on speed 2, begin to add your flour 1/2-1c at a time. once you add about half and begin to get a ball on your hook, decrease to stir each time you add flour and only add 1/2c at a time (my mixer tossed flour everywhere at 1c on speed 2!) Once your happy with the consistency (i found this closer to 5c instead of the recipes 6c, mix on speed 2 for another 3-4 minutes, remove from your hook and HAND KNEAD for another minute or two. It gives the bread that hand kneaded love and helped me shape it out for a nice pretty loaf in the pan.
Hands down, this is a great loaf of bread! Definitely a keeper!

text:
Easy recipe to make and change.  I halved the recipe just incase I ruined the bread.  I even risked it by making it wholesome by adding wheat flour and ground flaxseed.  I did increase the water by 1/2 cup to compensate for the flaxseed. I let it rise 1 1/2 hrs, then another 30 mins in the pan. Put it in a 425 oven for 5 mins then reduced temp to 350 and baked for 35 mins. It turned out delicous! Will definitely keep making this recipe. Next I will try  a cinnamon raisin version. YUM!

Wow!  I'm new to this whole bread baking and after 5or 6 recipes that were all dissapointing to some degree, I Made A Perfect Dough with this recipe!  I actually halved the recipe (In case I messed up again) and made 8 nice size hamburger buns which turned out BEAUTIFUL!  I am now making a loaf bread with this recipe - thank you, thank you , thank you for posting this "Kelley-proof" recipe!

country:
None
text:
I've made this bread as per the recipe and once with my own additions.  When made as per the recipe, the bread is great!  I took half a loaf with me to work with the intention of sharing, but liked it so much that I decided not to share.

The next time I made it, I followed the recipe for the most part, but added a cup of dried cranberries (didn't have any raisins) after the third cup of flour.  Once mixed and risen, I punched it down, kneaded it for a few minutes, cut in half and flattened out each half.  I sprinkled each half with cinnamon and rolled them up before putting them in the pan.  It turned out wonderfully!  My family loves it!

text:
I made this bread following the directions...next time I will use the tips but this is FLAT out the best one I have tried. 

The tip about putting a pan of warm water in the oven to help with the rise doesn't just help in the colder north but can help in the South when it's winter. I ran a pan of the hottest water I could to put in the pan underneath it and did not open the oven door til the hour was up. It works wonderfully.

text:
I love this bread! Have made this several times, now. However, I have made some changes due to personal preferences. Lowered the amount of sugar to 1/2 cup... may end up lowering it even more. I also used 2 cups of whole wheat flour and 4 cups of unbleached flour. This last time, (today 12/8/11) I used virgin coconut oil instead of the vegetable oil. Bread was very good! We like a more dense bread, so this recipe fits our family to a tee! Thank you for sharing!

country:
None
text:
Wow this is perfect! Decrease sugar to your preference if it's too sweet; I decreased to 1/2 cup after the first batch and that's what works for me. Used unbleached white flour and turned out great, but better with bread flour... not as heavy in my stomach. This has replaced storebought bread for my family. I keep it fresh in a breadbox. If you don't it only lasts about a day, day and a half, but w/ breadbox, it lasts about 4 days, which is great for my family as the kids gobble it up. Once it starts to dry out a little it's still good for toast, french toast, homemade garlic bread, croutons... very versatile, best recipe I have ever made. Thanks for posting this!!!

country:
None
text:
I make this bread once or twice a week with great results every time!  It's never failed.  I add the water, sugar and yeast to the pan in my bread machine and let it sit for about 10 minutes (until foamy), then add the rest of the ingredients and choose the dough setting.  When complete, I divide the dough in half, and shape into loaf pans for the final rising, then bake as directed.  Perfect every time.  Love this recipe!

text:
Very good bread! I usually use my bread machine to mix and rise dough, but did it all by hand with this bread. Absolutely easy and rewarding. I just had major surgery and was able to make this with no issues that is how easy it is! Just a note, I only ended up adding 5 cups of bread flour instead of 6. I also reduced the sugar to 1/4 cup. It took a little longer to rise after putting into the loaf pans but so far it looks fabulous! Going to do a cream wash on top to make it shiny and pretty before I bake it. Also made enough to make a little pumpkin shaped loaf for my kiddos since Halloween is on Monday!

BEST and easiest bread to make. I was out of money and bread, and had all the ingredients on hand to make this. I do not have much experience with making bread... but it turned out perfect. country:
None
text:
Thank you so much for sharing this recipe. I'll never buy white bread again! I've tried it with the entire 2/3 cup sugar and then with 1/3 cup and it came out absolutely perfect both times. It took mine a bit longer to rise but I just let it sit until it got there (about 3 hrs). I also brushed butter over the tops when they came out of the oven - keeps them nice and soft.  Less sugar yielded a less dense bread, very close to the texture of store-bought white but so much better. Makes the best toast and grilled cheese sandwiches ever. Love it!

This was my first attempt at baking bread and this recipe worked out wonderfully!  I did adjust the amount of sugar as other reviewers suggested and made 1 loaf by adjusting the serving size to 12 and reducing the sugar to 2 tablespoons.  The bread was so easy to make (I'm a beginner in the kitchen) and it tasted better than I imagined.  My husband and I had it with maple butter (whipped butter with maple syrup whipped in) and it was to so delicious. 

Did have one quick question for the group...for wheat bread, would it be sufficient to just replace the bread flour (I ended up using regular flour based on other reviewer's note and it worked out well) for wheat flour without adjusting the levels of any of the other ingredients?

I'm not a very good direction-follower, but the deviations I took gave the recipe a little extra character. I activated the yeast about 30 minutes ahead of time using about 1/4 cup of water and some honey. I also cut back on the sugar and used an egg wash with some rolled oats 'cause... well... it's pretty. :) I really enjoy the simplicity and flavor of this recipe.  I've made this recipe about 3 times now and it only seems to get better.

country:
None
text:
This recipe is simply delicious!! I really wanted to make a fresh loaf of soft, fluffy white bread today.  I halved the recipe and made 1 loaf, although I really should have made 2 because it is going on 3pm here and there's about a quarter of it left.  I did not have any oil left after a doughnut frying adventure.  So, I simply melted some butter and used that in its place.  I also decreased the sugar, as suggested by other reviews to 2 tbs.  I coated the loaf with butter twice before I baked it, and also twice after it came out of the oven!  FANTASTIC...the flavor and texture are bang on perfect!! Thanks for sharing the recipe, it is now my go to white bread recipe!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the first yeast recipe I've ever tried and it gave me all the confidence I needed to tackle my yeast phobia. It's an easy straightforward recipe that's also very flexible. I also decrease the sugar somewhat, or I replace some of the sugar with honey for a slightly different taste. I've also switched 1.5 cups of bread flour for whole wheat flour. Like another reviewer mentioned, this recipe also makes delicious dough for cinnamon rolls. Just roll it out flat, generously slather melted butter, cinnamon, and sugar on it, roll it up and slice it.

This bread is so fantastic. Sweet and yummy. I halved the recipe. Other than that, the only thing I really did different is the proofing of the yeast. I proofed the yeast according to the package directions (adding in about 2 tsp of sugar to the yeast) and mixed the rest of the sugar in with the flour. It turned out perfectly. I will definitely be making this again.

It worked perfectly the very first time. I'm so impressed with how fluffy and moist it is.  i halved the recipe and used half the amount of sugar called for, and have one heavenly loaf on my hands. 

I have been making this bread weekly.  The only thing I've noticed is that it consistently takes longer than 30 minutes for the dough to rise the second time - it's more like an hour to hour and a half, making this recipe a 3 to 3.5 hour endeavor.

text:
I did not find this bread dense at all!  It is actually flimsy in texture and falls apart when slicing.  For improved  nutrition, the second time I made it, I reduced the sugar to 1/3 cup and added 3/4 cup of non-fat dry milk along with the flour.  The texture was better.  Overall, it is still the easiest bread recipe I've used - except for Italian peasant bread - (yeast, olive oil, water, flour & salt.)

OMG! I will NEVER buy store-bought bread again! This bread is SO good! I made it exactly as the recipe reads... not sure exactly how much flour I used- but it was around the 6 cups. I mixed in 5 cups at first and then kneaded more until the dough as the consistancy that I wanted. It was still a little sticky (because that is how I like it).  When I kneaded again after it rose the first time, I added a little more flour. It is seriously the best bread I have EVER tasted. :o) Good luck- and have fun making the most simple and best tasting bread that I have ever made!

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very nice loafs of white bread. Used only 1/4 cup sugar, and added 5 tbsp. gluten. Used only 5 cups of the flour to mix, and used some of the 6th cup in the kneading process. I think all 6 cups of flour would have been too much for the amount of water. The dough was wonderfully soft and a pleasure to work with, and the end product turned out just as soft and fluffy. Don't forget to put a shallow pan of water on the bottom rack of the oven while baking. 
My 3 guys pretty much devoured one of the loaves with dinner.

I made this because it would make two loaves at once and my bread machine would not accomodate the amount of flour.  I made one loaf and as other users suggested, made cinnamon rolls. Easy Peasy! do not understand why others were cautioning.  Following the directions given will give you the desired product.

Easy to follow recipe for the novice bread maker.  It's a little on the sweet side.  I cut the sugar down to 1/2 cup,otherwise this recipe has yeilded a fool proof loaf everytime I've made it. text:
This bread is the best white bread I've ever made. It is a little sweet so I will definately reduce the amount of sugar next time, probably to 2 Tbs. I also used 1 cup water and 1 cup milk for smoother texture. After shaping them I put them in the refridgerator for a 6 hour cold rise. Let it sit out for a little, or until room temp and puncture any bubbles that form before placing in the oven. It was not dense at all like others stated. It was so soft and fluffy, just a little too sweet.

None
text:
I love this recipe. I've made it quite a few times now exactly as it is written. It makes a very sweet dough. Everytime I have baked it, the dough in the center of my loaf is underdone, while the crust is perfect. This could be my oven or cheap pan..? However, this dough makes delicious, perfect Parker House rolls. After the first rising, form dough into 1" balls in greased muffin tins and allow to rise 30 minutes. Then bake until golden. I always keep a batch of them in the freezer.  Thanks!

text:
A nice bread.  Cut the sugar to no more that 1/2 cup.  Also, there is no need to proof the yeast, the French don't.  Just mix the yeast sugar, salt and oil in the flour.  Stir with a spatula until a shaggy mass then put in mixer with dough hook.  Cuts prep time to 10 minutes.  Four stars because six cups of flour won't fill or make two regular sized loaves in 9x5 pans.

text:
Spectacular!! I used this bread to try to replicate my MIL's recipe that made 7 loaves! So I used 1/4 cup brown sugar (no white) and 1/4 cup melted shortening (not oil). Also used 3 1/2 cups white and 2 1/2 cups whole wheat flour.  I baked in two 8 x 4" bread pans and they turned out absolutely delicious, moist, and EXACTLY what I was looking for!

text:
I have tried a number of bread recipes with terrible results. I am a novice at bread making and a lot of things such as how much should the bread rise, how much should I knead to get smooth dough and how smooth is smooth really are not very intuitive to me. In spite of these shortcomings this recipe yielded two tasty, soft, fluffy loaves of bread. If I can get this recipe right, anyone can! Adjustments I made:  1) Cut sugar to 1/4 cup like almost everybody suggested.  2) I live at 5000ft and its very dry. So I could only add in 5.25 cups of flour.  I am never buying bread again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This bread is very easy to make and has a sweet taste that leaves you begging for more. I have found that the baking time varies greatly from day to day, and the recipe baking time is much too long. The less you overcook your bread, the sweeter it tastes. Once it is brown on the top and you can tap it with a finger and hear a hollow sound, its done. Pull that baby out and let it cool down for at least 10 minutes before devouring.

This bread turned out absolutely perfect for me. I did let the bread rise a little more than 30 minutes the second time in the bread pans.   I want to make a note that the most important thing to do when making homeade bread is to let the yeast proof! It makes all the difference. It makes the bread so much lighter and fluffier.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As so many other reviewers have said, this is truly an easy, fool-proof bread recipe.    I reduce the sugar to 1/4 cup and make it totally in my KitchenAid.  I divide the dough into 4 small loaves and bake side by side on a bar pan or in small aluminum loaf pans - either way it turns out great.    Along with making the white bread, I use this as a base recipe and substitute other flours for some of the white;  such as whole wheat, rye, oatmeal, etc.  My favorite is 1/2 whole wheat with sesame seeds on top.  It has a wonderful nutty taste when toasted.  It also makes incredible cinnamon raisin bread (I bump up the sugar to 1/2 cup for this).  I bake this bread every week and can't seem to keep any on hand.  It gets eaten or given away as fast as I can make it.  Thanks so much for this wonderful recipe!

Simply divine!  With a KitchenAid, this bread is dead simple...but even without one, it's easy and makes a delicious loaf of bread.  I've adapted it to make wheat bread by switching out 2 cups of white flour for 2 cups of wheat, but it needs to rise for about twice as long.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this three times now; the first two times, I was pretty lazy and  used half all-purpose flour and half whole wheat flour, no baking stone, glaze or steam, resulting in dense though entirely edible loaves (I kneaded the second batch for about 20 minutes, and that seemed to help). The third time I decided to go all out and used bread flour, as well as a baking stone and a pan of hot water for steam, and what a difference it made! Half of the batch was used for *terrific* sandwich rolls (my incredibly picky and, at that point, fairly suspicious boyfriend said they tasted store-bought), about a quarter for some spur-of-the-moment cinnamon rolls, and the last quarter is baking now into a glorious, crusty loaf with an egg yolk wash. This one's a keeper.

text:
This bread was really, really good. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because it was a little bit heavier than what I was looking for, and the texture wasn't quite as fine as I wanted.  I've made it three times now, and each time it seems to be better than the last, so maybe practice makes perfect.  I did try something new this time, though. Instead of punching down the dough, I gently pressed it out and rolled it into a loaf for the loaf pan. That seemed to help with the heaviness factor, though it made the texture less fine.

I have made A LOT of bread and this is by far the best in texture!  I used only 1/3 C. sugar and 3 C. bread flour and 3 C. whole wheat and it turned out perfectly. Additionally, with all white bread flour, I tried adding cheddar cheese cubes and jalapenos and let them rise only 25-30 mins on the second rise to make more of a moist dinner roll.  They were fabulous!

text:
I cannot say enough about how good and simple this bread is.  The first time I made it at home for my family and they loved it!! I read the reviews and reduced the sugar to 1/3 cup and made half the bread into a loaf, half into rolls.  I personally did not eve notice the sugar.  The second time I made this bread with my preschool class. They had a great time mixing an kneading by hand!! This time I used the full 2/3 cup of sugar and we made the entire thing into rolls.  It turned out beautifully brown and soft.  But I think that was too much sugar as it was a little bit too much on the sweet side.  Next time I will play with it to see what is the perfect sugar amount for me.  Thank you for a wonderful recipe!!!

text:
Awesome Recipe!  I found this years go on this site and have been using it ever since.  It's a wonderful dense sweet white bread which tastes great on sandwiches or toast.  It is very easy to flavor this bread.  I've added fresh or dried herbs for herb bread, cinnamon and raisins for raisin bread, a banana for a yeast banana bread, and even half a can of pumpkin with apple pie spice for a yeast pumpkin bread.  Experiment with it have fun!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
absolutely perfect and was the exact taste i was hoping for! this is the first bread recipe i've ever made with yeats and couldn't be simpler. I did read some reviews, but decided to stick with all called for ingredients. I LIKE the sweetness of the bread, it's great for all types of sandwiches or even by itself or as toast! I didn't know what to expect for yeast 'proofing', but do make sure the temperature is 110!! It'll get a nice caramel-colored foamy top and that's when you know it's "proofed." Also, don;t forget about your pan loaves rising like I did for an hour cause they'll grow to 6+" above the pan, whoops. They do 'deflate' so to speak if you touch them.  Overall, tonight is the second time i've made this recipe in a week. That's 4 loaves of bread between my boyfriend and I, so it really is delicious. THANK YOU!

text:
The closest you will get to store bought white bread! I love this recipe, and was so happy to find it on this website as the majority of bread recipes require a bread machine, which I don't have. Plus there's a certain satisfaction that comes with doing all the hard work yourself instead of letting a machine do it. Anyway, this bread is wonderful! It makes two delicious loaves, one of which doesn't make it to the end of the day. It's a tad hard to cut, but if you let it sit overnight or pop it in the fridge to let it cool, it's easier to cut into slices. This is now my ONLY recipe for bread!

text:
This recipe is very similar to our 150 year old family bread recipe with the exception of oil vs. lard. (I like the oil better!) As a variation, I made  coffee cakes by dividing the dough into two round balls, placed on cookie sheet. Brush 2 tablespoons of melted butter on the dough. Sprinkle over dough: mixture: 1 cup of sugar, 1/4 cup of flour and some cinnamon.

text:
I have done very few reviews, as few things have impressed me as much as this bread.  I followed the instructions pretty exactly, except for kneading with my KitchenAid for about 6 minutes as opposed to hand kneading.  (Also, I did not find the bread too sweet with the full amount of sugar.) I was afraid the 6 cups of flour would be too much, as the dough itself seemd a little stiff,  but it was perfect.  The loaves were beautiful.  I ate three slices hot out of the oven with butter for dinner.  I didn't even WANT anything else.  This is the best loaf bread recipe I have ever tried, and I'm not a novice bread baker.  Easy and wonderful. I'll be making again and again.

text:
I like this recipe for a couple of reasons; it makes two loaves and it's very forgiving.  I set out to bake this while I did laundry and cleaned the house.  I got diverted during the second rise and finally got it into the oven to bake after rising for about 45-50 minutes.  Good thing, since it produced a beautiful tall loaf ideal for sandwiches.  I didn't find it overly sweet at all.  This has a great crust and is actually somewhat light in texture.  I'll definitely make this again. Thank you for posting this recipe!

text:
After not baking bread for 15 years, I decided to give this a try, because it seemed like a nice foolproof recipe for just plain 'ol whitebread.  And it is exactly that.  I've made it twice now, and will definitely keep making it.  A little sweet, so you might want to adjust the sugar.  The first loaf was gone before bedtime, and it is a hit with the entire family.  Good for French toast, good with butter & honey, good for sammiches, good for 'bout anything.  Boy, those Amish sure know how to bake!  Thanks, Peg- you rock!

text:
like others have said...would give it more stars if i could...and of course i did my own tweaking.  i lessed the amount of sugar to 1/2 cup...then i put in some honey, about a tablespoon or so.  i love to use honey when i  bake bread.  i also put half water/half canned milk in.  i usually always use canned milk in any of my recipes.   i used this recipe to make bread bowls .  so i didn't make loaves, i made the bread bowls instead.  i had four nice-sized bowls from this recipe.  also, i added some italian seasoning to the dough...gave it a little extra flavoring...i had used the bread bowls for meatballs.  so i wanted them to have an italian flavor.  honestly, my husband couldn't say enough about this recipe.  he makes bread sometimes too.  so he was really impressed with this.  it's such an easy recipe....i believe it is probably fail-proof.  have fun making and sit back and wait for the ooh's and ahh's!!  :-)

text:
This was my maiden voyage in bread making (sans a bread maker, no less!)  I was a little concerned at times that I had done something wrong (trying to interpret foamy yeast and giving it a little extra time during the initial rise) but in the end, it came out great.  I did have to help it rise the second time by sticking it a warm oven since it must've been a little too cool in my house for it to rise on it's own.  Because of the pans that I had, 1/2 was baked in a Pampered Chef bread pan, the other 1/2 in a Pyrex dish.  I do have to say that the 1/2 baked in the stone seemed to cook more evenly and was a bit better so it you have the choice...  Both were good though!

text:
I made this bread tonight and I love it!  I used about HALF the amount of sugar, and it turned out great.  It takes about 5-10 minutes for the yeast to proof with the sugar and water.  I made two cinnamon rolls and a french bread loaf out of it.  I like to brush the bread with a little bit of cream before I stick it in the oven so that the tops brown.  I will be making this recipe again!

text:
I can finally make bread thanks to this recipe!!  Made the dough using my Kitchen Aid mixer with the dough hooks. I made a couple of changes (but I'm sure it would have been just as delicious if I hadn't):  I used melted butter in the place of the oil, threw in about a cup of raisins when the dough began to pull together, and added about 1.5 tbsp of cinnamon.  This recipe gave me loaves; my husband finished one of them within two hours of coming out of the oven!  Thanks--

text:
This is my favorite bread to make, I will not use any other recipe anymore, because this one is too simple.  I make it for my Feingold Family, and have it memorized.  Anyhow, There are 3 things I do different which are I add real butter instead of oil, I use about 1/3 of a cup of sugar, and after I put the dough together and kneed it, I punch it down after 10-15 minutes then let it raise again like the recipe calls for.  A tip a polish restaurant gave me about their homemade bread making.  Thanks and good luck.

text:
I've been baking bread for over 40 yrs but never have baked a simple white bread. This is the best tasting white bread. Hands down, the easiest recipe to make. My husband nor I found this bread too sweet. The only thing that differed from the instructions was the 2nd rising. It took a little over an hour for the bread to rise 1" over the pan.  They baked beautifully but stuck to the pans which were well oiled. I believe it's because I baked them in Corning Ware loaf pans. I'll try (as others have suggested)several different ways to use this wonderful bread recipe: half honey wheat,dinner rolls,cinnamon raisin. Thanks Peg for a GREAT reicpe!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very forgiving recipe! Not only did it live up to what other reviewers have said, but I made some very silly mistakes. First, I forgot the sugar. So I just mixed it right into the dough I had made. Second, I didn't roll it out before letting it rise the first time. I followed all directions after that. It turned it out beautifully. I made this over the weekend. I did as some suggested and cut the sugar by 1/3. It was still very sweet! I also only made a half-batch because I had bought 3 loaves of bread not two days before I tried this recipe out...I just couldn't help it when I read all the raving reviews! So I divided the dough in half (1/4 the recipe at this point) and formed one piece into a loaf as is and the other I pinwheeled cinnamon. I baked both in the same 9x5 pan as directed. Both mini loaves were devine!

text:
Okay. So, this was my first time making
a homemade white bread that wasn't a beer bread. You can imagine my combined excitement and anxiety. 

I can't take credit for my efforts entirely. Thank you to breadguy who posted his method of making this bread with the Kitchen Aid mixer. Totally saved my life, let me tell you. Using his advice, I was able to make this bread
with a little less freaking out about messing it up. 

I wish I'd read up more about cutting back on the sugar. It is a bit sweeter 
than I would have liked. Next time, I'll be sure to cut back on the sugar. Other than that, there were no other hitches. This bread worked out perfectly for me 
as a first time bread baking experiance.

text:
Awesome!! I'm a novice baker. I followed this recipe down to a science.This bread is sweet and very filling. Maybe cut down on the sugar like everyone else next time. overall VERY NICE BREAD. I used 2 packages 8oz of normal not quickrise yeast, still turned out fine. Also for people who are new like me.. if your wondering when the yeast is "proofed" the foam it looks like poridge or rice pudding and step 3. I think is crucial because I didn't use quickrise yeast... I timed it 30 min. it wasn't even near risen.. I took a chance and decided to wait till 1 inch above the pan... finally approx 1h:45 min. later the results payed off!! ***** stars!

text:
My first loaf of bread! And it turned out awesome! For some reason I have always been fearful of making bread or baking in general. With regular cooking, if you mess up you can correct your mistake. With baking it's like once you put it in the oven, it's a done deal and if messes up there isn't much you can do. This recipe has taken away my fear of baking. This was a really easy recipe to follow and the results turned out so great. For those like me who are on the timid side when it comes to baking, have no fear with this recipe.

text:
This was a great recipe. The bread rose perfectly. The finished loaf was a bit too sweet. Next time i will reduce the sugar like many other people reccomended. To help your dough rise put the whole container in a oven (that is not on) and add boiling water to a container. This time i used three bowls. One underneath, and one on either side. You can also use one large dish underneath or pretty much any other varration.

text:
I like this recipe! I changed the flour to wheat flour, and I used 1/4 of a cup of sugar. This was the second time I made this recipe, and this time we didn't have sugar, so I used brown sugar. The first time I made this recipe, I took the bread out right away, and it didn't come out in one piece, but I discovered that if I left it in the pan to cool, it would come out in one piece. I also used dark pans, so I reduced the temperature and the time of the bread in the oven. Over all, this is one of my favorite bread recipes.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/2414.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This bread is perfection. Better than bakery bread, it's slightly chewy, a little sweet, and just dense enough to be used in a wide variety of recipes. I made half into a loaf of bread, and the other half into 8 medium sized rolls.
I used all-purpose flour with a mix of raw sugar (about 1/3 cup) and brown sugar (1/3 cup) with a tsp of honey, and suprisingly the sweetness is very subdued. It just tastes like an expertly made bread, which is amazing for a novice bread baker like myself.
The crust is perfectly browned, and my house still smells amazing many hours after the baking is done. A forgiving dough, which allows for minor alterations, while still producing excellent flavor and texture? I'm sold! This is now the standard white bread in my house. Thank you so much!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2007-03-21T09:10:16.963
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
19663
Display Name:
LROHNER
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
20
favoritesCount:
64
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A few weeks ago I posted a 5 star rating for another white bread recipe on this site that I said was the absolute best.  Well, when I'm wrong, I'll admit I I'm wrong.  Intrigued by the hundreds of 5 star ratings for this recipe, I decided to give it a try.  Since it's just my son and I, I halved the recipe and threw everything into my bread machine and set it for basic white bread with a light crust.  A few minutes into the first knead, I checked and did have to add almost 1/3 cup of water.  I checked after the first rise and had the sinking feeling that this was going to be yet another failed bread recipe.  OHMIGOSH WAS I WRONG!  When the beeper on my machine went off, much to my surprise I was looking at the most perfect loaf of white bread you can imagine.  I was even more surprised when I tasted it and deemed it better than Sunbeam!  Needless to say, my son awoke this morning to a huge plate of french toast and claimed it was the best he ever had!  Try this recipe....it's a keeper.

Only one little, minor, eensy weeny problem that I believe was caused by the bread machine.  While the density of the loaf is wonderful, it was a bit "holey".  I wouldn't say the nooks and crannies were quite like an English muffin, but the next time I make this recipe I will use the custom setting on my bread machine and follow the knead and rise times given in the recipe more exactly.

text:
This is a wonderful white bread.  Slightly sweet, very soft and just a little chewy.  I found the texture a bit coarse with just one rise, so I cut the yeast back to 1 Tbsp., and let it rise twice before putting it into pans.  I find this bread rises much faster than the published time, but I make bread several times a week, so I have a lot of wild yeast in the air in my kitchen.  I also like this bread made with half White Whole Wheat King Arthur flour

text:
This is one of the best white breads I have ever made. I have made it for 2 years now and it has become a staple in our home. I cut the sugar back to 1/2 cup but when I use honey I leave it at 2/3. This a dense sweet bread with a good crust. If you find it to be a little sweet you can cut the sugar back as far as 2 table spoons and the bread is still great just not so sweet. If you follow the directions you can't lose.

Thanks

text:
Absolute perfection! For those of us in high altitutes, I added a heaping 1/4 c. flour (I used self rising and got rid of the salt), and I upped the temp by about 15 degrees, using an egg yolk/water wash before baking. I let the yeast set for a really long time (say 38 minutes) and it was the first bread I've ever had turn out well way up here in the mountains. Thanks for posting it!

text:
I am a notorious bread making oaf.  This recipe was so easy!!!  I let the bread rise for almost two hours the first time then for a bit shy of an hour on the second rise.  They ended up perfect.  They never rose over the pan but I think that my loaf pan is a bit bigger than it should be.  The bread was a bit dense as well, next time I'll let it rise for longer.  I also felt that the vegetable oil addition added an odd taste, it can be considered good by some, but next time I'll melt butter and use that.  This is the first time my bread has come out edible and I am ecstatic.

By far the best bread recipe I've made! It smelled so delicious baking we ate it straight out of the oven and burned our tongues. :) Adding jam seemed to take away from the great bread taste. I baked it in stoneware loaf pans and had to decrease about 5 minutes of the baking time. Definately going to make this again soon!

text:
I enjoy trying new recipes, and this is certainly simple.  However, I substituted 3 cups of white flour, 1.5 cups whole wheat flour and 1.5 cups oatmeal for the 6 cups of white flour.  I let it raise a little longer than recommended because of the denser flour.  The bread came out really moist and tasty.  We ate it warm from the oven with soup. I will certainly make it again.

text:
Super!  The user who thought this would make good french toast was right on.  I had company and made up a batch of this by hand, using the instructions from a previous commentor, which worked great and was very easy.  One loaf I made normally, and the other loaf I turned into a cinnamon swirl bread.  I mixed cinnamon and brown sugar, and added oil until it was spreadable.  I rolled out a rectangle, spread a thin layer of the cinnamon mixture, rolled it up, and cooked it in loaf pan.  The next morning we used it for french toast.  HEAVEN!  It was the best french toast I've ever had!  And the regular loaf was great for dinner, and I didn't think it was too sweet.  I making it again as we speak, and I can't wait.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is fantastic! I had a lot of fun making this. The bread was nice and light with a very nice taste. It didn't taste yeasty like some other homemade breads. I baked my bread as the recipe directed (for exactly 30 minutes at 350 degrees) and was delighted to see that the bread had a light golden brown crust. It wasn't heavy and thick as the crust that you would get from an automatic breadmaker. The only thing that I did do differently was cut the sugar back to 1/2 cup and used all-purpose flour instead of bread flour. I also brushed the top of the crust with margarine to soften and bring out the golden color of the crust. My house smells so wonderful from this bread.

text:
This bread is sweet and tasty, though it tends towards overbrowning.  I'd suggest using an oven thermometer to be sure your temperature is correct and adjust the temp down if necessary if the first loaves are too dark.  Reducing the baking time just gives half-baked bread.

This bread was so good, I finally had to stop making it since I was eating a loaf a day.  ;-)

WOW!!!!! I've been making homemade bread for the last 13 years...always looking for a better recipe. THIS is the best bread recipe I have EVER made. In fact I am eating it right now as I review this. It was very easy to make. I made it before bed and let it rise once, punched it down and put it in 2 greased loaf pans. Then I stuck it in the fridge and in the morning it had risen just perfectly. I stuck it right in the oven and out came the most beautiful, tender loaf of bread I have ever made...THANK YOU!!!

text:
This recipe is so easy and it doesn't take all day to make. It is the only bread recipe I use anymore - for loaves, buns and pizza crust. I sometimes substitute 2 cups 12 grain flour for 2 cups bread flour. After experimentation, I have settled on 1/4 cup sugar which I dissolve in the water before adding the yeast. The bread never crumbles so even my kids can cut it. They love it for sandwiches and just as a snack.

text:
After the "thousands" of excellent ratings, I must mine! I recommend cutting down on the sugar. Another variation: form into french bread loaves on large tray that has been sprinkled with cornmeal. Spritz the oven with water before putting in the loaves, and again once or twice during baking. Gives a good chewy crust with the tender center.

text:
I'm so happy - I am a beginning bread baker and I just can't mess up this yummy bread recipe! I use my bread machine on the dough cycle, then take it out and divide it into two pans for the 30 minute rising time, continuing as the recipe instructs.  I've made it with varying amounts of the sugar called for with great results each time.  This bread is very sturdy and makes excellent garlic bread - spread with softened butter & minced garlic, topped with Parmesan and cooked under the broiler.

text:
Very easy to make, avoids milk or other milk products (people actually put this stuff in bread?!) but much too sweet.

If you want your kids to have a tooth left in their heads, seriously cut down on the sugar.

Do it in your bread machine (but watch the machine's capacity!) - but be sure to add just the warm water, yeast and (reduced) sugar for the first 10-15 minutes. Then add the oil,  flour and salt and select your machine's rapid bake (or near 2-hour cycle)

text:
I made this bread and everyone loved it. Enjoying experiments, as I do, I decided I would try to add a little to it. Before it rose for the last half hour and after I had needed it, I melted 1/4 cup of butter and mixed together 1 teaspoon cinnamon and 1/2 cup white sugar. Mixing all of these ingredients together, I added a large, chopped apple. Stretching the bread out as far as I could, I spread this mixture over it and then rolled it up and let it rise for the last half hour. When we tasted it, we were overwhelmed with the luscious flavor and texture.

userID:
15017398
Display Name:
Kevin Frazier
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
5
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1877555.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is now my favorite white bread. There are a couple thingsto look out for. The first and most obvious is my house is cold in winter and I didn't take enough time to proof the yeast. What this means is that once the yeast is mixed with the warm water (prior to adding the sugar) let it set up and foam a bit. I let it proof maybe ten minutes and then off we go. That may not have been long enough.
In any case, you make a roux, just like any bread and the first two cups of flour or so should be whisked in.
DO NOT mix all the flour indicated in the recipe...get to maybe four cups and then add a little at a time until the dough is just firm enough to knead without gooping up your fingers. Knead it on a floured surface (note I did not say "lightly floured"...) as it picks up flour, add a little at a time to avoid kneading on an un-floured surface. You'll get the hang of it. Knead it for a bit and then put it in the greased bowl (follow instructions). Mom and I always heat the oven to about 100 degrees (no hotter because you don't want to kill the yeast) so it will help it rise. DON'T FORGET to turn off the oven before putting the dough in! The oven rack should not feel hot to the touch, just warm.
If it happens like mine, it was in a warm oven for an hour and barely rose. This can happen. So what I did was knead it on a lightly floured surface for a bit, split it and made two loaves. If you haven't done that before, be sure to put the part where the dough is roll
Review:

Rating:

dateLastModified:
2020-02-16T16:29:41.547
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
2333176
Display Name:
chicgma
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use to make the potato flake Amish bread starter bread.  It was too much to keep up for only two people.  This recipe tastes just like that recipe without all of the "up keep".

I made the bread and we love it.  We cut the recipe in half so I make one loaf at a time, great for two people that do not eat bread at each meal or everyday.

1 cup          warm water
1/3 cup      white sugar
2 1/4  t.       active dry yeast
3/4 t.           salt
1/8 cup      oil
3  cups        flour

text:
I followed the recipe (metric conversions), although I used a stand mixer with a dough hook and, as is typical with bread, I added more flour as needed to get the dough to the right texture to come away from the sides of the bowl. The baked texture was fluffy and it came out looking just like the photos. 

I just have to take a star away for the amount of sugar in this recipe, though. In the future, I think I'll cut the sugar by at least 33%, maybe as much as 50%. It's just a bit too sweet for my preferences. I have plans to make some French toast with this initial batch, though!

text:
I make this once a week.  Sometimes I only make 1/2 for a single loaf.  Always using a scale.  If I make 2 loaves, I use the extra 1/2 for cinnamon rolls or dinner rolls.  This is a wonderful base for cinnamon rolls.  I  roll it out, fill, cut and pop in a greased cake pan - then in the fridge.  The next morning I let rise 1-2 hours and bake.  I am then officially everyone's best friend :)

text:
My friend made the best cinnamon rolls and I asked for the recipe. She gave me this bread recipe and I am scratching my head. She told me she made the dough from this recipe and then rolls it out to the shape of a rectangle spread a liberal amount of butter onto the dough,  sprinkle  a generous amount of brown sugar, roll it up and cut with a string. Let the rolls rise again for another hour in the butter pan. Bake at 350 for 18-20mins. Best cinnamon rolls ever! Dont forget to make the cream cheese frosting!

text:
I have made this several times cutting the proportions in exact half to make 1 loaf.  Comes out perfect every time. I start it in my bread machine through the rise cycle, punch down and transfer to buttered loaf for 2nd proof and bake in the oven. I do find that I need to loosely cover the top in foil about half way so that the top doesn't get too brown. This bread is delicious. Makes out of this world grilled cheese sandwiches.

text:
This was the first time I ever cooked bread from scratch.   I couldn't be more pleased with this bread.  It makes a soft and delicious bread that puts store bought bread to shame.  After reading some of the reviews that recommended reducing the amount of sugar,  I decided to only use 1/4 cup of white sugar.  I also only used about four and half cups of flour.  The bread had a perfect consistency with the smaller amount of flour.  I will be making this again... I hope you have the same results that I have had.

city:

country:

text:
Very easy bread and fast to make.  As others have noted it is extremely sweet -- my first thought when I tried a slice was that this would be good dough for cinnamon rolls.  But it also makes a good sandwich bread.  I used it for meatloaf sandwiches and between the savoriness of the meatloaf and the tanginess of the mustard the sweetness of the bread was perfectly balanced out.  Another bonus, this bread held together really well  for the sandwich, instead of crumbling apart as many white breads do.

text:
This is why I'm rating it five stars:
The description was "easy, doesn't take long to make." It fits that description.  It wasn't the most amazing tasting bread I've ever baked - but it isn't supposed to be.  This was a good sandwich bread that my picky family ate when they make sandwiches.  My wonderful sourdough goes stale; my delicious challah doesn't get finished, but this went, two slices at a time, from right to left as they ate lunch. (And yes, as I snacked)

The crumb came out moist and light as air.  The crust was very soft, which they like.  The dough was easy to bring together and pleasant to knead.  I gave a loaf to a friend, and he and his gf loved it. 

And it didn't take all day to make.  I'll be making this one again - not to show off with at a potluck - but to show love to my fam.

1 c. luke warm water
1/4 c. sugar
2 Tbs. veg. oil
3 c. flour
3/4 tsp. salt
1 tsp. bread maker yeast

makes 1.5 lb. loaf and has been raved over by family and friends!

text:
Awesome! I used bread machine yeast instead and skipped the proofing part. I used the same measurements for the quick rise yeast and it worked perfectly. Just mixed it right in with the flour and started kneeding. Very dense and rustic - would be awesome as French toast or just as it is with soup or stew. I'm actually going to use this recipe for making bagels. The dense chewy texture would be perfect! It seemed to be browning too quickly, so after 15 minutes, I turned the temperature down to 350. Next time I'll just bake it at 350 the whole time.

Next time I think I'll try 2 cups bread and 4 cups all purpose.

text:
I am one that believes to rate a recipe you need to make it exactly the way the poster wrote it first. Then review it then make your changes and then post it as your own. It gets me so mad when I see a 5 star rating and people go on and on about all they changed. You are giving you and the recipe you created with your changes a 5 star rating. Not the original recipe. Okay. I'll get off my soap box.

As you can guess, I made it exactly as written. And it needs no changes. It is wonderful. Very, very flavorful. It taste amazing. My first piece was still warm from the oven and I just put butter on it. Delicious. My second piece I put strawberry preserves on it. Majorly delicious. Third piece I toasted it and put butter on it. It was a explosion of flavor. This was my first attempt at making bread. I am now hooked. My mom always made bread when I was a kid. Smelling this brought back so many memories. Then when I punched it down after the first proof, brought some more. That is one thing my sisters and I were allowed to do and would fight over it. I will be making a lot more bread. The next one that my mom made a lot was raisin bread. I am on the hunt for a recipe. I so wish I had hers.

text:
It didn't look like the picture. It was dense, not fluffy. I made 1/2 the recipe & cut the sugar like reviewers suggested. Initially, that was the only change made. Adding a cup of flour at a time, it only took 2c & it was feeling kinda dry. While flouring the surface to knead, it may have taken another 1/4 cup. My yeast was really frothy before I added the salt, then flour, so I dont think that was the problem.  I can't say it was "the best" but it was still good bread. I'll try again. Might double the yeast & might try adding milk as another reviewer suggested. I wonder if buttermilk would make this more delicious.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a single loaf, and halved everything with the exception of the sugar. I didnt want a sweet loaf, so I knocked it back to 1/4 cup. The loaf came out beautiful, and the texture was superior to any bread Ive ever had. It was velvety soft, and stayed soft for several days. I have just one negative comment: I used 3/4 of a tsp of salt per the recipe, and the loaf really needed more salt. I wondered about it when I was putting the ingredients together. Three cups of flour is typically a 1.5 pound loaf, and the standard amount of salt for a loaf that size is one tsp. Once I buttered the bread with salted butter it was ok, but just cutting a slice and eating it you definitely noticed it lacked just a little something. Ill absolutely make this beautiful bread again, with just an extra 1/4 tsp of salt.

text:
So quick and easy to make and absolutely delicious. I've personally found the loaves rising time takes closer to 45 minutes.
 A Kitchen Aid Mixer with a dough hook really helps things along. However if you have a tilt head you may wanna half the recipe. if you have a lift bowl the recipe fits in fine. Either way, still add the flour cup by cup or else you get a dusty mess!
This recipe is delicious and works with any meal.

text:
I divided the dough and did a loaf of bread and cinnamon rolls with the other half. The cinnamon rolls turned out amazing!! Perfect base for cinnamon rolls - not too chewy but also not super doughy. However my bread ended up with a huge top and a HUGE air pockets in the middle. Not sure where I went wrong with these - I reduced the sugar to 1/4 cup, and I DID use all purpose flour, so that may have had an impact. I also may have let the bread rise too long for the second rising - more like an hour and a half than 30 min (and I didnt punch it down again, maybe I should have). Im going to try again for the bread since the cinnamon rolls turned out so well.

text:
Good recipe! Forgot how my mother taught me, so this helped immensely!
First round, I forgot the oil: bread came out a bit firm and hard, but that made it good for a soup.
Second time I applied some butter, added a nice soft crust.
Third I switched the white sugar to brown, again buttered. Gave it a tad more flavor.
All-in-all, good recipe that's nice and simple. Definitely will be using this again.

Display Name:
Erin

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this bread 3 times so far and everyone who had tried it has really liked it. Its very, very sweet (too sweet, imo) so I've cut down the sugar every time since the first. I highly recommend using bread flour instead of all purpose and only add 4 or 5 cups to start. The recipe calls for 6, but depending on your flour and humidity level and the position of the moon, sometimes you'll find you need a lot less. I usually end up using just over 5.  I also sprinkle a little salt on top of the shaped loaf before I bake it. 

If you're looking for a savoury bread, I'd skip this. Even with the reduced sugar, it's still a sweeter bread - kind if on par with those little Hawaiian rolls (in terms of sweetness, not flavour). Its absolutely delicious with butter as a snack but I probably wouldn't be using it for sandwiches or garlic toast.
Review:
Rating:
5

Display Name:
Tamara Brown

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6514063.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love it! My kids, my Mom, my neighbors, and co-workers loved it. Here are my notes. I have been making bread for about 25 years now. YOU MAY NOT NEED ALL THE FLOUR LISTED.  Measure the flour out into a separate bowl. You add the flour one cup at a time until the dough forms into a ball.  Use the flour that you measured out to flour the surface,  dump the dough onto your floured surface, sprinkle flour, from the bowl onto the dough and KNEAD! Add flour to the dough after it absorbs in and knead.  Keep doing that until the dough is elastic and not too sticky. I did not use all the flour that  I measured out. The bread is not dense at all, but it is a little sweet for my taste. I will drop the sugar to 1/2 cup the next time I make it, and I will report back.

I first mixed it in bread machine ( I have that thing going every single day ) I followed the recipe exact , even though I thought I had a bit too much sugar , I still like to try all recipes exact when first making . This bread rose beautifully,  it was a bit more chewy than I expected & I would prefer less sweetness ( my preference , not my husbands ) . We still both loved the bread , but I prefer the Portuguese sweet bread on this site a bit more ( if adding sugar ) I'm looking for a good dense enough sandwich bread for my son & husbands lunches & even though this bread is good , I feel it may get a bit soggy by lunch time if I use mayo etc ... but we will see tomorrow!

userID:
25032365
Display Name:
Brea's World
isPro:

1

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6322554.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have several problems with this recipe. First, it doesn't state how long to let your yeast bloom. Not everyone is a yeast whisperer. Secondly, the recipe asks for you to put the salt directly in the yeast mixture. This is a mistake. Anyone familiar with working with yeast knows that salt can slow the chemical reaction in the yeast and stifle rise. It also doesn't state how long to knead the dough or if you should flour the work surface. It also doesn't mention if the loaves should be covered for their second rise.  I make bread all of the time, at least once a week, and the lack of these kinds of details are the main reason why bakes fail. I've got these loaves in the oven right now, after allowing an hour for the second rise, not the 30 mins in the recipe. They wouldn't rise well, and I discovered that this is likely because a skin formed on the top of the loaves from being exposed to the air. The skin inhibits the bread's rise and will result in a denser, smaller loaf. Not what I'm looking for when making sandwiches bread. I will not be making this again.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-01-30T13:40:15.61
helpfulCount:
0

text:
Tastes great, cuts nicely (my serrated knife has seen better days, and it even cut well).  Had it as toast with butter and eggs this morning, very tasty!  I typically have challenges getting it right when working with yeast and kneading but this bread dough turned out perfectly.  I do think the trick is allowing the yeast to proof.  I mixed in a clear food processor so I was able to see the sugar and yeast working together, and resurfacing as foam.  I will use this recipe again and may try it as a dinner roll recipe when I need to.

elle

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loves this bread!  Two loaves lasts 2 days!  I throw everything into my bread maker on the dough setting.  Once its kneaded, I follow the directions from splitting and flattening, jelly-rolling, and letting it rise in loaf pans before baking in the oven.  When I do this, I use the instant yeast.  Ive also tried this with Gold Medal AP flour, King Arthurs AP flour, and good quality bread flour.  The bread flour was the lightest and fluffiest, but our preference was the King Arthur.  And I found that if I let it rise in the pans long enough, they were just as light and fluffy as the bread flour.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I have made this exactly as written. My house is a little on the cool side during the winter, so I heat up my oven to 350 F and let the bread dough rise on top of the stove (not in the stove, that would kill the yeast).  I cut the loaves in half and only keep out half at a time, as they get crumbly really quick, within a day or two. It does also make great bread crumbs when it gets a little stale. Nice recipe.

text:
My family loves this bread. It is very sweet, as I would expect from the amount of sugar in it. I found it to be very similar to bread that I have been served at Amish restaurants, which is exactly what I was looking for. I followed the recipe exactly before baking. However, once it was done baking, I spread a very small amount of butter and honey over the top to give it a glaze as soon as it came out of the oven. Then, I placed it on the table while still warm along with a little softened butter and Apple Butter.  My children (ages 7 & 9) loved it! Perfect addition to a home cooked meal. Thank you!

None
country:
None
text:
I love this bread. Both loaves were gone in less than 24 hours. My household won't let me go a day without making it now. It is perfect for daily baking. I have already passed this out to a bunch of friends to try. There is one thing I did differently. I used honey instead sugar. I used the same measurements with the honey as it called for with the sugar. It was perfect. Before I made it, I read the reviews on it. If you follow this recipe...every single step, as required, you won't have any problems with density. It does taste a lot like hawaiian bread, but it is not too sweet. It is perfect for sandwiches, with a meal, or just on it's own for breakfast. I have been making bread most of my life, and can say that by far...this is the best I have found in years.

text:
I add the salt in with the first cup of flour rather than with the oil.  I use EVOO and it gives the bread a great flavor.  Also, I increase the salt to 1 TBS. as I find it tastes better.  But the best tip I can give is that I mix it all in one bowl using a Kitchen Aid hand mixer with dough hooks.  I mix it for 5 minutes exactly and get an amazingly silky dough.  Also, use butter for the bread pans instead of oil and the loaves will pop right out.  For fun, I sometimes add ground flax seed, sunflower seeds, poppy seeds.  Very delicious plain or with a little 'fun' added.
Review:
Rating:
2
dateLastModified:
2018-07-23T03:52:45.513

Perfect bread for the beginner. Didnt knead enough? No problem. Second knead to our into loaf pans will fix it and the dough is more pliable then. I have never had a bad batch. Our family has been using this recipe for years now. No one has had a bad loaf. The bread browns up perfectly as well (a problem with other recipes). I have also replace our Hawaiian dinner rolls with this bread by dividing into rolls instead of loaves. Thank you thank you for this wonderful recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As far as breads go, this is a very simple recipe.  I cut the recipe in half because our freezer is full and we can't eat two loaves that quickly.  

Next time, I'll cut the amount of sugar a little bit, more for health reasons than anything else..  I thought the sugar gave the bread extra taste,  texture and added dimension.  I did have trouble with it rising.   Instead of the one hour the recipe calls for, I waited two hours.  I also lit my oven for a minute, shut it off, checked to make sure it wasn't too hot, and put the bread in for the first rise.  Also, on the second rise, I waited one hour,  not the 30 minutes that the recipe suggests.  For those that are having trouble with this recipe, give it more time to rise,  and definitely watch the amount of flour.  Mine did not take the full amount, more like  2.5 cups.

country:
None
text:
I've made this bread many, many times and have passed it down to my granddaughter.  Both our families love it and so do our friends.  I don't ever have "bread flour".  I use organic all purpose flour.  I knead by hand for about 5-6 minutes the first time and about 2 minutes after punching down. I also bake it for 40-45 minutes instead of 30.  I test with a thermometer. Internal temp needs to reach  200 degrees.  Be sure to use the right size pan as it can affect the outcome.  This is a fantastic recipe and sure beats paying over $5.00 a loaf for store bought organic bread.

Soo good! text:
I enjoyed this bread a lot. Based on other reviews I was afraid this would be too sweet, but it isn't at all; the sweetness is there but it's not going to offend anyone. It has a good flavor overall and tasted amazing with some peanut butter for a snack--my husband and I destroyed over half a loaf in five minutes. 

My bread did come out a bit too far on the crumbly/soft side, but I didn't knead for long enough and even noticed when I was putting the loaves in the pan that the dough didn't look quite ready. When I make this next time I will knead for much longer.  I will be looking at how this bread keeps over time.

12867176
Display Name:
Rachel Major

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5218705.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this bread a few times so far, and it will be added into the regular rotation! Instead of 2 loaves, I usually make 1 loaf for sandwich bread and use the other half to make cinnamon rolls. The sweet bread is perfect for both applications. As others have said, this bread dough is a sticky one, which is variable with the humidity o' the day, so don't be taken aback if your dough is as well. I've only had to add additional flour once. Using a scraper to help you get it together is recommended if you are doing everything by hand.  When kneading, I'd suggest you keep an eye on the timer and the other on the dough. When it's ready you should be able to pull a corner between your hands to "window pane" test it.  If you stop too soon, and the dough still breaks when you pull it in your hands, it hasn't gotten itself together enough for a good rise. You should be able to pull on it to get the dough thin enough to see through in a small spot like you are "looking through a window".  Best of luck, and happy baking!

text:
This is so good I want to cry. Made it AS IS. Light, fluffy, wow! NOT too sweet as others have mentioned. I thought it had a hint of sweetness, but certainly was not over-sweet by any means. I LOVE how high this bread raises! It's truly a fun bread to make. The kids will not only love eating it, they will love watching it rise, and punching it down. I love another reader's tip to turn the oven to 350 for ONE minute, turn off, then put your dough in the oven to rise. It definitely rises much faster in this environment. (Just be careful that you only warm it for a single minute!). This recipe was soo good that I am making it again today to give to moms in the neighborhood this Mother's Day weekend.  P.S.  You'll never buy store bought white bread again.

None
text:
I made it following the recipe. It only used 5.5 cups of flour. I had no bread flour, only regular flour. 

As I was reading the reviews, I realized that this is the bread I grew up with. It's actually made with a starter. Once you get it proofed, you can add things like nuts, honey, and dried fruit to it. It's a wonderful bread, meant to be sweet and dense. If you find it too sweet, you should look for a regular white bread recipe.

I made one large loaf, one small loaf, and 6 rolls with this. And used 2 1/4 tablespoons of yeast. Came out super yummy and light! I also mixed it with my hands only. Only machine used wasy oven. I proofed it for one hour, kneaded and divided, then proofed again for 30 minutes.

text:
The best bread recipe with the most consistent results! I free-form the loaves and bake on cookie sheets, they end up cooking in less time and seem to prevent larger bubbles compared to when I bake in a loaf pan. Dont over-handle the dough after the first proof- it will create a dense loaf if you do.

text:
I've done everything with this bread. Loaves, dinner rolls, cinnamon rolls, rolled around a meat and cheese filling, you name it. It's never let me down. Change up the flour to whole wheat? No problem. Brown sugar instead of white? Great.  Follow a proper knead, rise, punch, rise protocol? Perfect. Throw everything in a bowl at the same time and ignore it? Still perfect. It's the most forgiving bread recipe I've ever tried. I've even had it rise chilled. Only caveat...make sure your yeast is fresh!
