madeRecipesCount:
34
favoritesCount:
158
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1554949.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe more times than I can count. It has been loved in our home for years-requested for every special meal we have and by many friends. I have made loaves, mini loaves, and (most often) rolls. People often think you have to have a roll recipe to make rolls-no, no, no-a recipe for loaf bread usually makes about 1 dozen rolls/loaf. For mini loaves I use the Pampered Chef mini loaves stone. I get 4 mini loaves for 1 regular loaf. The tricks to this recipe: **follow directions**, use the exact ingredients, exact temperature for the water, use the yeast the recipe calls for. Dont add all of the flour it calls for in the beginning. You can add flour, you cant take any out ;-). Once you know how to make bread and how it should feel, THEN you can play with different ingredients (different flours, different oils. Ive used bread flour, the cheapest all purpose, unbleached, wheat. Oils Ive used: olive oil, coconut oil. Ive maybe used others, these Im sure Ive used), or using different yeasts (google whatll need to change. For ex: I use instant yeast when Im in a hurry. But, I use less yeast 25-30% less, and I mix it differently-all the dry ingredients except salt (flour, sugar, yeast) add salt later, it can mess up your yeast, then I add all of the wet, making sure they are the right temp. I mix my oil in the water to warm it. Add salt after kneading a few minutes. 1 rise is a 10 minute rest. 2nd rise is for 30-45 min depends on the warmth of the room.

text:
This is a great recipe. Yes, it is a bit dense and sometimes crumbly, but it's versatile. I made donuts once with this dough- let it rise the first time, punch, then roll it out. Cut out the donuts, let rise on a lightly floured surface until they're a little poofy, then drop them into hot oil and flip them over as they brown. It goes fast but they're delicious!

userID:

Display Name:
Laura Mitchell Hamann

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1135954.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe turned out delicious  and looked just perfect. Advice: make sure you dont skimp on rise time. Do allow both rises.  It works great to let the kitchen-aid bread hook do the kneading.   Then grease a bowl and scrape the dough into the bowl.  Then make sure your cloth that you lay on top is damp.  Next, put the bowl in the oven on a top rack(not on or hot) with a pan of boiling water (3 or 4 cups) on the bottom of the oven to give off steam and heat to help the dough raise quicker.  The oven is still warm enough for the second rise that I dont have to warm the water again.  Allow to cool before storing in an airtight container or condensation may make damp spots.  I substituted all purpose flour and it still was perfect.  Also, it slices up easier when cooled but you cant beat the taste of it fresh out of the oven.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The thing that made the most difference for me when making this bread was to add the flour one cup at a time mixing with a wooden spoon up to 5 cups. After that I begin to knead the dough, adding flour a little at a time. For my conditions, the 6 cups of flour is too much. I end up at around 5 3/4 cups. The dough should be slightly sticky when there is enough flour, and smooth after kneading.  I also reduce the sugar, but that is just personal taste.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was looking for a simple recipe to try out my new loaf pans. This fit the bill. Delicious. I used all-purpose flour and light olive oil instead. Perhaps because of the all purpose flour, my loaves were a little short, so maybe better to use the smaller loaf pan size. Peculiarities: Ever the airhead, I forgot to add the salt and oil until I had mixed in 3 cups of flour so I did it then. Also, I used a handheld beater to break down the clumps of yeast that I dumped in all at once into the sugar water mix. I'd say this is a nice bulletproof recipe :). Next time, I will try slitting the loaves on top before baking to see what kind of difference it might make in the texture.

country:
None
text:
I've made this several times and my whole family loves it. I use 1/4 cup sugar plus 2 Tbsps honey. I always feel it's missing something when I forget to add the honey. The crust is nice; the bread itself very soft . It's a forgiving recipe. The dough is slightly sticky, so be careful with adding too much flour. What I do to help with kneading is only add one tablespoon of oil to the mix and keep adding little by little drops of oil to the dough ball rather than adding more flour.

text:
I read other reviews about significantly cutting back the sugar and or oil.  I made several batches of this trying each.  The batch that tasted best was the one made almost exactly like the recipe - I just cut the sugar back to 1/2 cup instead of 2/3 cup and mine used about 1/2 cup less flour in order for he dough to be soft and pliable, not too hard which, in my trials, led to a flatter, heavier bread.  The sweetness was just right.  This bread is the best I have ever made and taste and texture is just like store-bought white bread.  The recipe is so easy.  On the second kneading just do it for about 30 seconds to get big bubbles out, no need to knead longer.  It made fantastic dinner rolls but it would, in my opinion, need more sweetness to make cinnamon rolls, but otherwise would be an excellent bread for sweet rolls.  Great EASY recipe

country:
None
text:
As-written, this bread is amazing, but a tiny bit too sweet for my husband's tastes. He likes it best when I reduce the sugar to about 1/2 cup. I love the flavor and texture either way. The crust is soft and thin as well, which we prefer.

This recipe is so forgiving and easy to play with. For example, we like to make a multigrain version that substitutes 2 cups of alternate flours like quinoa, oat, teff, rye, amaranth, etc. and 1-2 Tbsp gluten in place of some of the white flour.  The texture remains soft and fluffy. My toddler gobbles up this bread like nothing else.

I'm a novice when it comes to bread. I just made this and it came out so very delicious.  I did twerk it a little bit however.
I substituted 6 tablespoons of honey instead of sugar, used 1/4th cup less water and baked at 325 for 20 min. I seriously just ate one loaf by myself.
I didn't give it a chance to cool down when I started cutting into it. but as it cooled it was very light and fluffy.
Review:

text:
This recipe was very good. I made it exactly to recipe. I don't think it's fair or accurate to change a recipe and then rate it, as what you're rating was not the original recipe. I coated my glass loaf pans with Baking Pam instead of oil. It worked out great. The bread released as soon as I turned them over.  The amount of yeast given is exactly 2 packs of yeast. We ate one loaf and I am freezing the other. A quick and very simple recipe  that would make a good place to start for any new bread maker.

I've made this recipe many times, and it's always turned out delicious. It is pretty sweet, though. Cutting back on the sugar, shouldn't be a problem. To get lighter & fluffier bread, I add two Tablespoons of dry (powdered) milk per loaf in with the flour. It makes the bread rise much higher.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm sorry I'm one of the people that changed this recipe to suit my tastes. But I'm sure it is 100% fool proof and that's why i was able to do so. Substituted 1c water and 1c milk for the 2c water and used 1/4 cup sugar total instead of the 2/3c because I didn't want a sweet bread. The crumb was so delicate, soft and tender. Not dense at all. Bread rose beautifully. I made one loaf of bread and 9 dinner rolls (next time I'd make 12 because they were a little bigger than I'd like). Brushed everything with butter before baking. Rolls baked up in about 25 minutes and the bread was finished at 30 minutes. Crust was pretty golden brown color; nice and crunchy too (until I smeared more butter over the hot bread, then it turned soft). Everyone raved over this recipe and asked me to share! we're on day two and all the rolls and half the loaf of bread are gone. Makes delicious sandwiches. New favorite bread loaf recipe.

text:
This bread is SO DELICIOUS!! I highly recommend it! Super easy to make. I made one loaf in a metal pan and another in a glass pan. I used a utility knife and cut an inch sliver down the middle of the dough right before it went into the oven and it made it rise beautifully! I got a prettier loaf in the non stick metal pan than in the glass pan but the glass pan wasn't as brown and it also needed more time to bake.

userID:
17028115
Display Name:
JMac

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great bread. I have made it twice. Once with the full amount of sugar and once with 2 - 3 tbs. Both good depending on what results you want. I used my kitchen aid and used the following suggested method from another reviewer: Proof your yeast in the mixing bowl then add the oil/salt, the add the flour approx. 1 cup at a time with the dough hook on low speed. Once all the dry ingredients are in come up to medium speed for 5 minutes. Then take the dough out, fold it over on itself to redistribute the yeast, make a ball, and place it back in the same bowl after you drizzle a tablespoon of oil (veggie or olive) and turn the dough to coat evenly. Cover tightly with plastic wrap and then a kitchen towel.
Review:

I made this bread for the first time tonight and it is absolutely delicious. The only thing I changed was that I added 1/3 cup  +1/6 cup of sugar instead of 2/3 cup of sugar. It's so easy to make in the KitchenAid mixer!  I made one loaf in a glass pan and one in a metal pan and there is no comparison. The glass is way better and made the bottom and sides more crisp. I also did an egg wash on the top and the crust is so chewy and sweet. This is going to be a new family favorite !

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe made a dense, sweet loaf (half recipe). I did make a procedural change. I added one cup of flour before I added the salt. I've been told this buffers any effect the salt may have on the yeast.
My second bout with the half recipe found me cutting the sugar back to 1/4 cup. This got a better reaction from my family.
I haven't had any failure in this recipe. I have had failure of yeast, in envelopes that were outdated, although they had been bought recently at the store. Open jars of yeast go bad fast. Freeze between uses.
Always check dates when buying anything. Some stores don't remove, or are slow about removing expired foods.
Review:

5

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time making a bread dough in a while and it went on smoothly. tastes nice and sweet, delicious by itself. I did cut the portions by  half because it felt too big to be consumed in such a short time. 

Scrolling down the comments, I see a lot complaining about it being dense. The trick to not making your bread too dense is to use less flour as possible. If the recipe calls for 6 cups of flour, don't dump everything in at once. Save half of it and add more as needed as you work on your dough. In my case, i have a mixer with a hook attachment so i only had to use 2 cups and 2 tbsp of flour to achieve the perfect consistency, so my bread was very soft abd fluffy.
Review:

text:
We  have made this bread for years now and have not changed a thing.  Peg knows her stuff.  We did however learn to place a light bulb, 150 watt metal work light in the oven bottom and with the door open about 3", held open by a rolled up dish rag, keeps the oven at 90 degrees F while rising the dough.  It made rising easy.  As a result we have all but stopped buying store bagged bread.

I've made this quite a lot this past year (every week or two). It is true that it makes a denser bread that is quite sweet. But that's why I love it. text:
This recipe was so easy.  I only used a scant quarter cup of sugar because I didn't want a sweet bread.    I also had to substitute some of the bread flour with ap flour, since I didn't have enough bread flour for the recipe.  I mixed the flour and water with a spoon, then used my hands  to  knead the dough  just until combined.  Honestly this was the least fussy bread recipe ever.   I think as long as the bread is allowed to rise fully, then there really shouldn't be a problem achieving  lovely and fluffy loaves of bread.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe and the bread came out perfect. For something fun, you can cut dough into small pieces before the 2nd proofing and put them in muffin tins.
Also, it helps if you knead the dough using a dough hook on a kitchen aid on medium high for about 5-7 minutes. When proofing, put the dough into your oven that is warmed. I start the oven then cut it off when it reaches about 100 degrees. I also throw in a cup of water for extra moisture.
Don't forget to eggwash your dough before baking!

I grew up on homemade bread and I have been making bread in a bread machine for years but never seem to get a perfect loaf. This was the first bread I have made actually worth freezing. I got a new Kitchen Aid mixer for Christmas and this was my first attempt at bread and found out they are like a 2 year old, can't turn your back on them.........hehehe (not sure where my common sense went). I was headed for the fridge while mixing on medium speed and within a couple seconds the mixer, dough and my pride all crashed to the floor, vibrated right off the counter. Determined not to give up I picked it all up, put the dough back in the bowl and finished mixing. Not sure how but this was my best bread to date and will be my go to recipe.

text:
I really do like this recipe.  I have made it as directed but it is a little sweet(or would have been 5 star).  For our liking, we decrease the sugar to about 1/4 to 1/3 cup.  I do add flour cup by cup and sometimes don't use all the flour.  As expected. 
Great recipe that you can adjust to your liking and still works out! I have even used all purpose flour and it still worked out.
Sometimes I increase the recipe by 1/2 to fill 2 full sized loaf pans better--makes nice tall loaves that way.  Just depends on your loaf pan size.
BUT!!! the VIDEO for this recipe is a FAIL!!  You don't make bread that way--putting all the flour in at once!! And not how you make loaves!!  Wow!!  The 2nd loaf she put in the oven was falling!  Punk bread!!  This recipe deserves a much better video!!

text:
I made this bread twice in a week. I am an experienced baker and been making breads for a very longtime but this recipe is simply amazing. 

I made the following change:  used only 1/4 cup of sugar based on another reader's recommendation. 

The first time the bread was a little crumbly inside. So the second time I made I allowed for a longer but slow rise and also baked it 5 minutes longer for a total of 35 min. 

Perfect is all aspects. This one is a keeper.

text:
I got a new bosch mixer and was looking for a good bread recipe.  I came across this one and am so glad I did because it's delicious.  I doubled the recipe and made 4 large 1 1/2lb. loaves.  I decided to share it with friends and family so I wouldn't gain 50 lbs. from eating it all myself.  I'm actually making a second batch to share tomorrow.
UPDATE 3/12/17
I've made this bread so many times now I can make it in my sleep.  I usually double it and give 3 of the 4 loaves away.  Sometimes I make 2 loaves and use the remaining doubled recipe and make cinnamon rolls.  They come out fantastic.  I figured out the cost of ingredients and it is about 89 cents a loaf.  You can't buy bread this good for that price.  Everyone I've shared it with has raved and raved about it.

text:
Second time making it..both times excellent! But rather use than going exactly by rising time stated for 2nd rising, I just waited until it was an inch or so above pan, which took about an hour..it's  more important that it achieves this height, rather than how long it takes to get it there..So use that as a sign that they're ready to bake rather than time. Family LOVED it just as it is..but for myself I'd like it a little less sweet..so don't expect a buttermilk or potato bread flavor..more like a kids soft white bread, great for sandwiches!

I used only 1/3 cup of sugar as other reviewers have done.  No other changes.   This bread just came out of the oven and I have never seen such an awesome loaf of bread in my life!  Beautifully tall and rich brown top.  Marion Cunningham - a cookbook editor and teacher of cooking- suggests that kneading breads be done by hand.  I kneaded this bread by hand and when my hand got tired I used my rolling pin.  I believe kneading this bread by hand is the reason it came out so well.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this almost every day for a few years now, but never thought to rate it. This bread is great when you have three kids that eat bread faster than you can buy it. But what makes this bread so special is that the small list of ingredients makes it very easy to change to your liking. Say you want it more soft and moist, then you can add an egg and use milk instead of water. You can also use whatever fat you want in order to make it your own. It is also very easy to change this into wheat bread. Just substitute up to half the flour with wheat flour and use slightly more liquid. The only bad thing about this recipe is that, in my opinion, it calls for way too much sugar. I use about 1/3 of what it calls for most of the time.

Update: 12/24/16 (Happy Holidays) - My variation calls for:  1 cup almond flour (Bob's Mill), 2 cups whole wheat flour, 3 cups unbleached flour, 2 heaping tablespoons of gluten, 2-3 heaping tablespoons of flax seed.  You get a delicious, buttery-type dense bread without the butter :) and the goodness of flax.

Used 2/3 cup sugar  it wasn't too sweet.

text:
I love this bread recipe! Its great just as it is. My family and neighbors just loves it too. You can also make wonderful cinnamon raisin bread with this dough. Just roll it out and sprinkle with cinnamon,sugar and rasins. Brush the dough lightly with a little butter first. Then just roll it up and pinch the ends put it in a loaf pan and let it rise till doubled in bulk and bake the same way you bake this bread all the time. Its a treat!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4033776.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like others have written this isn't really a sandwich bread if that's what you're looking for. This is a sweet dense bread that's perfection with spreads or simply just butter. Family loves it.






UPDATE: Last time I made this bread (a few nights ago) it was not dense at all. It was super soft, squishy and fluffy. Having good yeast and the proper environment for it to rise is key. Not only to this, but to anything yeast leavened really. I'm not really sure how mine came out so dense at first, but I've just made lots yeast leavened things so I picked up some tricks that always gives a really nice rise to anything I make. Firstly, the temp of the water is crucial. I can feel by hand I don't use a thermometer and while the water shouldn't be too hot it should be more on the hot side than the cold side. My yeast foams at the mouth this way. DO NOT add in salt with the yeast. Recipes never tell you this, it's annoying. Salt prohibits yeast growth. Do it after adding in the first or second cup of flour, or just at a point where your yeast is incorporated into the flour. I also boil water and put it in the oven with my bread while it's rising to create the perfect humid environment for the yeast to thrive. I do this on both rises. Hopefully these help you.

text:
This is my go to bread recipe.  I don't know how many times I've made it. I made 2 batches of it just yesterday. I usually make it into rolls instead of loaves. A great addition to the recipe is to roast two garlic bulbs(more or less, depending on taste) then squeeze them into the mixing bowl when you add the flour. The roasted garlic incorporates into the dough and gives it a great garlic taste.

I made this along with homemade butter with my 5 year old granddaughter.  Such a fun and tasty learning experience!  The bread is absolutely delicious.  We took half of the dough after letting it rise, rolled it into a rectangle, spread butter on it and sprinkled cinnamon and sugar on top (just eyeballed it), then rolled it up and sliced into cinnamon rolls.  After they baked and cooled, we topped with a little icing.  YUM!

P.S. this is almost the exact recipe on the back of Bob's Red Mill Artisan Bread Flour. They call it "Amish Country Loaf". The only difference is Bob's Red Mill only calls for 1/4 cup of sugar, the rest in exact.
I've made it many times and it always comes out excellent! We slice it, toast it, and eat with butter and honey until it's gone (which is pretty quickly). We also cut down on the sugar.

text:
This is a good recipe, but I find it funny that "Peg" says that it doesn't take long! lol  It takes at least 2 and a half hours. Like most breads.....

Self Notes/Changes: 
- I use 1/2 c sugar instead.  
- Brush it with a wash: 
egg yoke and tbsp of water. It gives it a glossy, golden crust. 
- If baking the bread on parchment paper instead of using pans, slit the tops for aesthetics and for the cooking process.  
- Using the French method of hot water in a pan beneath the baking bread with make the crust crunchy and more European bread texture.

text:
Followed recipe and proofed the years in kitchenaid mixer instead of measuring cup. Added one cup flour at a time and used dough hook to mix on low. When all added used med speed for a few minutes. Turned onto floured surface and kneaded few more times. Added to 10c banneton proofing bowl (heavily floured with flour), drizzled 1T oil over it and made sure dough was covered with oil and then covered with towel to rise.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic! I let my 14 year old try this recipe first, and she is a novice baker, so when the bread came out delicious, I knew we would be keeping this recipe. With a family of 8, we have been baking two loaves about 3 times a week and each time it's delicious! As others mentioned, we have experimented with reducing the sugar and it was good but we all prefer it sweet. I find swapping a couple tablespoons of the sugar out with the same amount of honey keeps the same level of sweetness but gives it a unique flavor and a slightly moister texture. I've also used just a third of the dough each in the two loaf pans (to make more "normal" sized bread that actually fits in the toaster) and then rolled the other third out, spread it with butter and sprinkled it with sugar and cinnamon,  rolled it up and sliced it into 8 cinnamon rolls.  I baked those in greased muffin tins for twenty minutes, the kids loved them!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time working with yeast. All other times failed except this recipe. I used instant yeast by fleishmanns. I followed directions, proofing the yeast means adding it to the sugar water to make sure it foams. If it doesn't produce a thick foam, the temperature isn't right or the yeast is bad. Test out the water temp on your wrist. It should be warm but not hot and not cold. Adjust the water to warmer if you add it to a cold bowl before putting yeast in. I just used a 4 cup glass measuring cup.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This bread is really good and easy.  I've had trouble with bread in the past, the best advice I got (from an Allrecipe reviewer) is that you do not have to incorporate all of the flour in the recipe.  My dough used to be very dry and when I cut back on the flour the dough was much better.  The other thing I have found helpful is that because my stove/oven has an electronic igniter and no pilot light I have just put the bowl of dough into the oven with the light on and a heating pad placed on the bottom rack on high.  I have also used a hotel shower cap to cover my bowl.  Works great!

text:
Excellent recipe and very safe for substitutions.  Was out of granulated sugar, so I used confectioner's sugar and added my standard 4 tsp of wheat gluten to the proofing liquid .  Then--I was really trying to go for an Italian herb kind of thing, so I added basil, garlic powder, marjoram and rosemary before the first rise.  Rose beautifully both times, and made12 good sized rolls plus a braided loaf.  Will definitely be making this a staple base recipe!

text:
My mother in-law said it tastes better than the bread at our local highly esteemed bread bakery. She can't wait until I make more! The only changes I made were adding only 1/2 cup sugar instead of 2/3 cup, I lightly oiled my hands to knead the dough, let it rise in the pan 2 or 3 inches over the edge rather than just one, and I buttered the ENTIRE outside crust as soon as it came out of the oven. It was absolutely delicious! Thank you for sharing!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3358908.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This bread is fantastic. But I did alter it a mite and added more flour to make the dough more elastic and less gooey. The bread turned out perfectly.
I added 1-1/2 extra cups of flour at the end of the dough cycle  if the mix seems too gooey. Mix with your
Mixer and dough hook. If the dough doesn't all pull away from the sides easily it is too wet. Add more flour. I used King Arthur 100% organic bread flour. 
Then all the timing becomes perfect.
I've made this recipe about 6 times now. Everyone raves about it. I use avocado oil, and Celtic salt, with Italian yeast.

text:
I have made this bread several times and it always turns out well. one note- if you are finding your bread isn't rising like it should, add your flour, oil, and then salt. The salt can kill the yeast if added directly to the water/sugar/yeast mixture.

text:
This bread is so easy, and so delicious!  As other reviews suggest - I cut the sugar to 1/4c, but I also add another 1/2 tsp of salt.

I bake this bread at least once a week, and no matter how bad a cook I am, I just can't mess up the recipe. I've used less flour by a half cup, and it turned out perfect. Ive used less yeast and it turned out great. I've even over cooked it by 10 minutes and it was just fine.

I mix the ingredient using my kitchenaid too. It makes it so easy, and leaves little to nothing to clean up.

I have a friend from Kenya that says this bread reminds her of a bread they used to make in Kenya called "you've been away from home a long time bread". She said the only difference is their loaves are much larger.

userID:
9749182
Display Name:
luv2cook!
isPro:

10
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe. It has become my go to for bread. The recipe is extremely forgiving and versatile. My favorite is to make it with 50% white bread flour and 50% whole wheat flour. I have even made 100% whole wheat and it still comes out light and fluffy! Because I think wheat flour can have a bitter taste, I tend to use the whole amount of sugar when using it. If you are a first time bread maker, I would highly recommend this recipe and follow it exactly a couple of times before getting adventurous. Kneading can be intimidating for first timers and this recipe isn't very specific about that, so here are my thoughts ... For the first knead, don't be afraid of over-kneading as that is virtually impossible. What you want to get to is a dough that is kind of elastic in feel. A good test is to pinch a bit of dough between each thumb and forefinger and pull in opposite directions (as if you're opening a bag of chips). If the dough doesn't tear and sort of springs back to where it started, you're good to go. For the second knead, you don't need to get so aggressive with it (and this is where you may run into trouble if you knead too much - you may kill the yeast and the dough won't rise again very well). All you want to do the second time is punch down the dough to release some air and knead just enough to get it back into a dough that resembles what it looked like before you let it rise. This second knead only needs to be done for a minute or two. Hope someone can find this of s
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-01-11T08:26:50.16

text:
Easy to make and came out wonderful, and believe me, I've had a lot of bread failures in the past.  I used 1/4 c sugar and all purpose flour.  Tip for rising bread:  Heat up some water in the microwave to boiling.  Take out the water and put in your covered bread dough.  The warm damp interior of the microwave is great for rising dough.  (Just don't turn it on while the bread is in there).

text:
I made this today, substituting 5 1/2 cups AP flour and 1/2 cup self rising. it was absolutely wonderful! I took another reviewers tip and froze half the dough for later baking in the week. I think this recipe is definitely a keeper!

Update : The recipe wasn't quite creating two full loaves so I increased the recipe by 1/2 and then followed the same steps, separating into two loaves, freezing one loaf before the second rise and baking the other loaf. It definitely made a better sized loaf! My husband absolutely loves this bread and enjoys the soft texture and perfect sweetness.  He was eating toast and butter the other day and said it was the best toast he ever had!

12/15/15 I made this exactly as written. It makes a soft, fluffy bread, but lacks salt and is a little too sweet for a white loaf bread (I've never had Amish bread before, so maybe it's supposed to be that way).  Next time, I'll cut the sugar a bit and add an extra teaspoon of salt. Otherwise, the water to flour ratio, seemed about right. I used about 28 ounces of flour.

6/24/16 Made this again because I forgot I reviewed it already. My original review stands, too sweet, not enough salt.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The bread is light and fluffy.  The best bread I have ever made. I used 1 Tbsp instant yeast to replace the 1.5 Tbsp active dry yeast. Sugar and salt is dissolved in warm water first. Then oil is mixed in. Then,  flour and yeast are added in. I knead it in my stand mixer till sides of bowl are cleaned. I followed reviews to use half of the sugar and it turns out just like a regular white bread. Remember after baking, immediately remove from pan to prevent sogginess. Also, cool before slicing.

This is my only bread recipe. I let the mixer do all the work and as long as my yeast is fresh, it is foolproof. I love that it is made with oil, and no eggs for allergic people. userID:
16706804
Display Name:
Renee Adkins
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2761209.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is not my first attempt at bread but my first attempt with this recipe. I've learned butter/oil makes the bread produce less crumbs and firms it up enough for heavy sandwich materials. But I love to make more nutritious bread. I substituted in three cups of whole wheat flour, added a half cup of Bob's Red Mill Whole Ground Flaxseed Meal, and I left the sugar at 2/3 cup. This is the first recipe my four year old will actually eat since it is not overly yeasty in flavor. But that has to do with rising temps in addition to recipe ingredients. I will be using this recipe from now on. 

If you are using a stand mixer like I did, make sure you do all of the mixing in the mixer on low. Once everything is well combined move to a medium speed until it is no longer sticking to the sides of the bowl. If it's been more than ten minutes and it's still sticking, add flour by the handful. 

The first rise in the bowl did take over an hour until it was ready. The second rise took an hour until it was an inch above the pan. (My yeast was closing in on expiration date, which may have factored into this timetable). I cooked it on 350F for 25 minutes, not 30 minutes as the recipe suggested.

text:
I made this recipe twice now; both turned out really good!  I will definitely make it again. The second batch of the two was probably my favorite. I only changed one thing: I used just a tiny bit less yeast. The bread was just a little bit denser, which I prefer. Basically, I made half as much bread as the recipe called for this second time. Because I was using yeast in 1/2 tablespoon sized packets, I had to decide between using 1/2 tablespoon of yeast or 1 tablespoon of yeast for this half sized recipe (instead of true half which would equate to 3/4 tablespoon).

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this exactly as posted.  It turned out perfectly.  It was very light and fluffy, very soft, easy to cut, and sweet.  

Keep in mind, this is not your traditional white bread.  This tastes very much like the Hawaiin rolls you can buy at the store.  It is sweet; however, it tastes good as is.  For our family it is not a bread we would use for, let's say, ham sandwiches.  It was, rather, a sweet treat.  Certainly you can use it for savory sandwiches, depending on what you like.  It is the kind of bread you can just eat as is, nothing added.  It is a wonderful recipe.

TIP:  I'm sure many of you already know this, but for those who don't, a great place to let your dough rise is in the microwave.  (Obviously, the microwave is not in use at this time).  It keeps the dough safe from drafts, and speeds up the rising time.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this bread every weekend for nearly 2 months now. I started by making it exactly to recipe and have tweaked it each week . I use a kitchen aid mixer with dough hook instead of kneading by hand.  I still mostly follow this recipe but I use 1/4c organic sugar with a few tablespoons honey, 2 packets yeast, 1/2 c milled flax seed, 1.5c whole wheat flour, and then add bread flour until the dough balls and isn't sticky. It's amazing and never goes to waste! I freeze one loaf and the two loaves last our family of four a week, between sandwiches and toast.

text:
One of the easiest and best tasting breads I've tried. I've been looking for a no egg, no milk bread and this one's a keeper. The first time I've made this, I followed the instructions to a T. It was great, easy to slice, firm, and soft. It's nice and soft but a little crumbly when toasted. The second time I baked this, I ran out of bread flour so I used half/half cake and bread flour.  This time it's came out softer, but still great especially with butter. I couldn't stop myself from having a bite straight from the oven.

text:
Just wanted say that we made this bread twice and loved it. Per other's suggestions, we cut the sugar down from 2/3 cup to 1/2 cup and it suits our taste just great. I have not tried the original recipe so cannot comment on its sweetness.

For beginner breadmakers like me, I would like to stress how important it is to knead the dough well before the first rise. I kneaded it for at least 10min to develop the gluten. I'm sure the longer the better. Try the poke test and the windowpane test to know when it's ready. The first time we made the bread it was very crumbly and difficult to use as sandwich bread without toasting or grilling it first.

text:
Good consistency, but too much sugar for me. Next time I will reduce the sugar by at least 2/3 of the described amount. In addition you can also use ordinary yeast too and if you follow the recipe it will be 17grams of yeast instead of 1 1/2 tablespoon.

If you want a upper crust, put a bowl of water into the owen and also reduce the temperature with 20 C if you are using a convection oven.

On top of it, it was easy to make!

I did put the loafs in one loaf pan and the other in a round high cake pan. The later turned out really great!

userID:
15694242
Display Name:
awifeyforlifey
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
11
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I reduced the sugar to 1/4 cup and doubled the salt. I let the dough rise for about two hours, as it needs to rise until it achieves a marshmallow-like texture (when you poke it, you can make air bubbles). I didn't punch it down when I took it out of the bowl - instead I just shaped the loaves.

To shape the loaves, cut the dough in exactly half. For each half, pat it down to form an oval. Fold the top third of the oval down towards you (like the top of a business letter) and then gently but firmly press the whole folded bit down with the floured palm of your hand to seal. Turn your dough around so you can do the exact same to the opposite side. When you're done, just fold the dough in half along the "seam" you created (like shutting a book). Press the folded dough together. You should end up with a nicely shaped log loaf. 

Drop it in the oiled pan and press it down firmly with your palm. It should spread to fill the whole loaf pan and look even on top. Then cover it with oiled plastic wrap and let it rise for 30 mins, but NOT OVER 1" over the bread pan or it will deflate as soon as it hits the oven. If it over-rises, take it out and reshape again, then let it rise 30 mins again in the loaf pan.

Make sure you press firmly when shaping so you don't leave air bubbles in the folds, as this will make holes in your bread while baking! Your oven MUST be preheated to 350 before the bread goes in. You can test if the bread's done by thumping the bottom to see if it sounds hollow.

region:

country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe and some personal variations of it multiple times, and it's always turned out great. It's dense but soft, good for breakfast or snack because of the extra sweetness, but not quite as well suited for sandwiches or dinner breads. It does take quite a bit of kneading to get it super soft, but for me it's worth it. Now I make it with honey instead of white sugar -- I replace the sugar with 1/2 cup of honey and reduce the water by 1/8th of a cup, but it works great either way.

text:
Great recipe! Very yummy, got it right the first time. To get the flour right, I pour a bunch in a big bowl and whisk it for a bit. It is quicker and less messy than sifting it, and just as effective in my experience. I am making peanut butter and jelly sandwiches for a mother-daughter tea party, so I wanted pink bread. I added red food coloring and a half teaspoon of raspberry extract, just for fun. Turned out awesome! I added the photo if you wanted to see it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just tried the first slice, had to have a second one too!  It is still slightly warm ( I know I should wait until it has cooled but just couldn't stand the temptation) This is by far the prettiest, soft and fluffiest, tallest, bread I have ever made.  The aroma in our home is so wonderful too! Mine rose more than double in less than an hour and the second rise was a good 2 1/2 inches above the top of the loaf pan when I checked on it in 30 minutes.   I was afraid it would fall in baking due to 'oven spring' but happily the loaves held their beautiful risen shape and turned a lovely golden color while baking ..... Very pleased with the outcome of this recipe. Made it strictly as written and used the breadguy's Kitchenaid directions for mixing and kneading.  I will be using this wonderful recipe often. Thanks for sharing. I shared a photo of the bread before baking and how high it rose in the 30 min. time.

This is a great easy bread recipe that makes two delicious homemade loaves.  I haven't made bread in a long time but this turned out way better than even a bread maker I had used in the past. city:

country:
None
text:
Good basic white bread  recipe. . For those who have  problems with yeast.....YOUR temperature  is approximately 97 so you want the water or liquid in the yeast to be only a Bit  warmer . If you think it is just barely warm- it is good. If you think it is the same as your temp ( ie no difference ),  it is ok, just takes a little longer for the yeast to get moving .  My oven will keep at 100 degrees which is still air and warm . The yeast need food ( sugar and flour) moisture,  and moderate temps to perform- just like us.

text:
I loved this recipe I made rolls out of it to. I let the yeast rise on my counter before I punched it down. Once it was in the bread loaf pan and the rolls were in the pan i put it in the oven to rise withought any hear . It rose so much faster. Than when it was almost done rising i preheated my oven and let them bake for 40 minutes in the oven. my oven took about 10 minutes to preheat. When I was kneading it I added honey as I went until the honey was just oozing  out of it when you squeezed it in any direction. Then I added flower and kneaded until it felt like kneaded bread dough. Before I baked i finely diced a 1 centimeter thick slice of butter and put it on my rolls and bread.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is an excellent, foolproof recipe for traditional white bread.  I followed some reviewers suggestions, and I only use 2 tbs of sugar.  I've been making my family's bread for the past 3 months and this is the recipe I use.  I no longer buy bread from the grocery store, my family loves this recipe too much!  I love that there are only a few ingredients, and no HFCS.  I can feed this to my family and feel good about doing so.  I use my Kitchen Aid mixer to make the dough and knead it, couldn't be easier!  I even do the first rise in the KA.  I just spray the inside of the bowl, turn the dough once so it's coated with cooking spray, then cover the bowl with plastic wrap and a kitchen towel and allow to rise.  Perfect, perfect bread recipe!

text:
This recipe is perfect every single time. My boyfriend loves this stuff so much, he mentions it to almost everyone he comes in contact with. I'm serious.
The only change I ever make is to sometimes use olive oil in place of vegetable (or canola ) oil and sometimes half olive and half vegetable. 
As someone said, a very forgiving recipe. Delicious with good butter and excellent to sop up dinner sauces.
It's best eaten within a few days and definitely by a week. We usually give away the second loaf unless boyfriend is unusually greedy that week.

text:
It's a little too sweet, I made two loaves and used the rest for cinnamon rolls. The rolls were great, but the loaves had a dense texture, I think maybe because it calls for oil rather than shortening? However, it is quick, easy and pretty foolproof so if you are in a hurry to make some, use this recipe. Because of the denseness, it slices well. Would be great for Thanksgiving as the texture and sweetness lends itself to being dipped in candied yam juice :)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1113518.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use this recipe to make all my bread.  If you want it less dense and less sweet, just let it rise more.  The yeast will eat more of the sugar and produce more gas for a lighter loaf.  I think the people complaining about it being too sweet or too dense have not proofed their yeast properly or have old yeast.  The first time I made this bread I went to the store while it raised the first time and forgot it for over three hours.  It was ginormous!  It still came out OK, but slightly dense because the yeast had trouble rising the second time.

5

text:
My first attempt at a plain white bread and it was fantastic.   This recipe is sweet, but not too much.   I could possible see reducing the sugar by about 1/2, but it is definitely just an option left up to personal tastes.   I made this using my KA stand mixer and that went well.   I added flour slowly as directed and ended up using the full amount as stated in the recipe, plus a little for dusting the counter for final hand kneading.

I'm a first timer too and this recipe turned out great! I did test the yeast and it was fine and then it took almost ten hours for the bread to rise. Seriously. And it still could have gone longer, but I couldn't wait. I had to go to sleep. I don't know if our house is too cold or what, but I'm glad other reviewers mentioned that it won't hurt the bread to just let it rise as long as needed. I'm looking forward to summer when, perhaps, the process won't take a whole day! Oh and also, I made rolls too, froze them, and they baked up pretty well.

text:
My family loves this bread so much that I have been making it almost every week for the past 8 months. It's simply delicious and so easy! I use 2 tablespoons of sugar (sometimes honey) and substitute about 1/4 of the bread flour with wheat flour, just to give it a little more flavor. I follow all other directions. One problem I've been trying to overcome is that the bread comes out a little dense at the bottom of the loaf. Not sure if this is normal for home-made breads, but I've tried increasing the rise times to see if it helps, but it made no difference. The dough rises as the recipe indicates, but it always comes out with that 1/2 inch dense bottom. Any suggestions?

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe deserves all of the 5 star ratings it has received! I've been searching for the perfect soft sandwich bread recipe for my anti-crusty, anti-chewy, anti-all things that I love in a loaf of bread husband. This recipe fit all of his needs and even I loved it! I used my bread machine to make the dough so cut the recipe in half to make one loaf. Next time I will reduce the sugar to 1/4 cup instead of 1/3 only because this will primarily be used for sandwiches so less sweet is better (for eating straight the recipe as is is wonderful!). Also my bread took significantly longer to rise because the dough is SO dense, so I just waited until it was an inch above the pan as the recipe stated. Overall if you love really soft breads this recipe is a keeper!

country:

text:
THIS IS SO GOOD!  I reduced the sugar to 1/4 cup, but left everything else the same.  It's amazing and dangerous- you'll want to eat the whole loaf in one sitting!  I made one loaf according to the recipe and made one with cheese.  To do the cheese loaf, I flattened out half the dough to a rough square about as wide as my loaf pan.  I sprinkled it with cheddar cheese, rolled it up, and put in the loaf pan with the seam down.  After it rose in the pan, I brushed it with an egg wash (an egg and water) and sprinkled the top with garlic powder and seasoned salt.  Delicious!

I have made this for the last three Sundays, and find this to be very tasty and easy!  The first time I did not have bread flour, and it was good.  The second and third times I added some wheat gluten to AP flour and it was great. A tip for rising, heat a cup or two of water for two minutes on the microwave and leave the cup and water there with the bread dough to rise - it works perfectly. I also use my stand mixer with the dough hook, and this mixes up in minutes. Very quick and easy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A very simple but satisfying recipe, I bake a lot of bread and this recipe is now my staple for white bread. If your dough is taking a long time to rise, here is a tip that will cut the time approximately by half: before you begin mixing your dough, turn your oven on the lowest setting possible, let it preheat for five minutes and turn it off. Put some water on to boil, I use a teapot. Before you put the dough in to rise for the first time, pour about an inch of boiling water in a pie plate and place on the oven rack below your bowl of dough. You will not need to cover your bowl with a damp towel if you use this method. Make sure that you turn your oven off after a few minutes of preheating and use an oven safe bowl. This method not only cut the rising time for this recipe, but I got a lighter, less-dense loaf than some people on here have described.

text:
Easy bread. Quick to make. I tried it in my Kitchen Aid Classic. While the KA can handle it, it doesn't do great. I'll stick to my professional KA in the future. That said if the smaller KA is what you have it can be done. 
I usually make one of the loaves with cinnamon and dates or raisins, or a hard cheese: asiago, parmesan, etc. But I've tried it with mozzarella and it was delicious. Roll out one of the loaves, sprinkle with garlic salt, oregano and cheese. Roll it up and let it rise with the plain loaf. They bake the same. I cut the loaves, then freeze half of each and use the frozen bread for toast or grilled sandwiches.

Display Name:
BrennanX2

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/47658.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe, slightly tweaked, worked like a charm for me. I got the most gorgeous loaf of bread imaginable (seriously, with some homemade jam, this is other-worldly!) but I took half of the dough and make cinnamon rolls instead of a 2nd loaf of bread. They rise BEAUTIFULLY! I used all purpose flour (King Arthur organic un bleached) and used my dough hook on speed 2 for the entire recipe, adding flour and letting it knead slowly and patiently until all the flour was incorporated into a beautiful dough ball. I used less sugar- 1/2 a cup, and I used turbinado (sugar in the raw) instead of white sugar. I also used less flour- 5.5 cups, and used melted butter in place of the oil. I let mine rise 1 hour the first time, then the bread reached 1inch over the top of my loaf pan in a 30 minute second rise. I heated my oven with a Pyrex bowl of water to 200 degrees, then turned it off and let the oven cool 10 minutes, and let the bread dough and cinnamon rolls (smeared with a mixture of softened butter, brown sugar, cinnamon, etc and rolled up, cut into rolls) rise in the warmed oven together both times.They came out remarkable. I will never have a Cinnabon craving that rolls made with this bread recipe would not absolutely 100% satisfy! Amazing sandwich bread, dense but soft. My go-to recipe now!! Cant screw it up!!

Display Name:
Kat

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a pretty nice tasting bread, but far too sweet for my tastes. I also just find the texture to be more dense and crumbly - reminds me of Ukrainian easter bread, "paska" - and less stretchy yeast bread. I still make this occasionally without adding the full amount of sugar, but that's just when my brain isn't working well enough to try to remember my own recipe. It's definitely a fine bread. Still would recommend this recipe to anyone looking for an easy recipe starting out making bread. A good tip for this recipe is to be careful when adding the last of the flour and make sure you don't accidentally dry out the dough. A bit at a time worked in at the end is the safest way for to avoid this, but you can always add in a few drops of water if you find you've got something a bit stiff. This recipe also makes pretty good dinner rolls.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy, basic recipe.  Based on other reviews, I halved the amount of sugar as I didn't want a sweet loaf. Also, I think less sugar makes for better tasting bread generally speaking.

I used the conversion to metric function and halved the amounts to make only a single loaf.  Finally, I did the rise in a basket and turned out the bread onto a hot pizza stone in the oven, and had the temperature at 200C instead of the recommended 170C.

It turned out very well, was super easy to make and the pizza stone gave it a very nice crust.

I've made this bread twice now and both times it turned out great.  I think in future I'll keep the sugar and add some dried fruit to make a raisin bread.  I think it would work a treat.

text:
This is a nice white bread. I use the recipe to make rolls for southern pulled-pork sandwhiches. With the flour that I use, I find that 6 cups is too much. I use 5 cups and then knead a half cup more into the dough. I actually make all bread like that to keep an eye on the density/dryness of the dough. Normally, I make white bread with much less sugar but this is an interesting change.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1065809.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Quite possibly the best and most forgiving recipe. I would definitely recommend this for beginners to boost their confidence.

I thought for sure that my bread would be flat and hard as my yeast didn't proof the best. My dough did NOT rise in the first hour, so I kneaded it and put it in the bread pans as instructed. I set them in my cold oven and filled a large bowl with hot water and set it under the pans and closed the door. I let them rise AGAIN for another hour - it worked! So, it took an additional 30 minutes than expected but sooo worth it. The bread is moist, fluffy and so delicious! The only adjustment I made was the sugar. I only used 1/4 cup. I will be making this again for sure (with better yeast!) - thanks for sharing! :)

text:
Love it with a few adjustments as others suggested only 2 tbsp sugar, less flour I add 1 cup at a time until it comes off the side of the bowl then mix on high 5 min and then by hand kneeling in another half cup flour for a total of 5.5 cups.  I let rise in a large Tupperware bowl with lid that sits in a sink filled with hot water the key being its Not metal you can use any bowl in our cold house the dough still doubles in 30 min.

text:
This is a great recipe...I followed the suggestion below for using a mixer...I only used 2tbsp of sugar and only added enough flour approx 5 1/2 cups to make the dough come off the bowl...I kneaded the dough down three times and let the dough rise for an hour...the last kneading I kneaded by hand with a little flour on the board and let rise the the pan for approx 45 min...everyone loved it...nice crispy crust with nice light bread inside

text:
I made two small changes.  I substituted the 2/3 cup sugar for 2/3 cup raw honey.  I also substituted the vegetable oil for olive oil. My only complaint is that the bread turned out a bit on the sweet side, so it wasn't quite a "white" bread. It was more like a sweet bread.  I will make it once more, with half the honey, and hope its more of a white bread.  Although my whole family thinks this turned out great, I don't think it would be that great for a deli sandwich.  I also made this, by hand, no bread machine.  I think I needed to knead the dough a tad bit more, as it was a little on the spongy side, and the overall texture wasn't what I thought it would be.  This is also my first time making bread.

text:
This is a wonderfully delicious and easy recipe, for any baking experience level. I am definitely no expert baker. I made this recipe with my 9 year old son. He did most of the measuring, mixing, kneading and punching! (I did the dividing and baking.) Not knowing whether or not he got all the measurements precise, I took a chance. It turned out fantastic! It is a bit dense, so if light and fluffy is what you are after, this many not be the bread for you. I couldn't find my big loaf pans, so we used mini's and ended up with 4 HUGE loaves. I recommend letting the loaves sit and cool a bit before cutting. Awesome! Thank you all for the tips and hints!

country:

text:
This a delicious bread and I found it easy to make.  I used this fast rise yeast and it worked fine.  I also lessened the sugar and kept my rising bowl warm.  Think I could have let it rise a little longer than the recipe and it took 40 minutes on the second rise.

Most commercial breads and flours have a chemical called Bromide in them (usually packaged as dough enhancers, labeling not required except for in CA) - which has been outlawed in the EU and Canada for it's health risks (cancers, thyroid issues, goiters), but not here.  You can buy flour without Bromide - King Arthur brands is Bromide Free and most organic flours are as well.

text:
I LOVE this recipe! I have made it both exactly as the recipe states for a sweet "Hawaiian style" bread and have reduced the sugar to 2 Tbsps and used it as traditional sandwich bread. I honestly don't have a preference; they are both great!
I have recently moved from a fairly dry area of the state where I never had any problems with this recipe forming up on my KitchenAide dough hook. Now that I am in a very humid area of the Gulf Coast, I have to add an extra 1/4 C or so of flour. Still my favorite go-to bread recipe with no milk or eggs required!

text:
I've made this recipe twice now. The first time I made it, it was *DIVINE*. Some people said it was too dense, so I let it rise for 2 hours, and it was nice and fluffy. Plus it made 3 nice loaves. The second time, I cut the sugar in half, like many people suggested. I wouldn't recommend doing this. This bread needs to be a sweet bread - when you cut out the sugar, it just doesn't taste quite right. Next time, I'll probably make it with just a little under the 2/3 cup.

text:
I was looking for a simple, delicious bread and I have found it in this recipe. The only criticism that I have with the recipe as posted is that I found that I have to allow the loaves more than a half hour to rise, else the loaves look sloppy when baked--still very tasty, though. Take your time and allow the loaves as much time as they need to rise fully and you'll have an irresistible, versatile bread in no time.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I've always loved this recipe - making it by hand, mixing raisins and nuts into it to make it a snack bread. 

Today I made it with the bread machine (Sunbeam BM2500) for the first time. I halved the recipe and cut down the yeast to 2tsp from 2 1/4. Method is pretty simple. Water, sugar, yeast - let it foam. Add salt, oil, flour - level it and chuck the bread bin into the machine. Use Basic or White bread setting. Add raisins and nuts when the machine prompts for it.

It turns out perfect, just like if it were done by hand. Fluffy and soft!

text:
I have made this recipe at least once a week for nearly a year. It turns out every time, and is always a winner. We don't buy store bought bread. This is a thick, dense bread, so it creates a thick, hearty bread for sandwiches, SOS, and it makes a fantastic bread pudding. If you are expecting home made bread to be like commercial bread, then you will be disappointed. I will sometimes use less sugar than listed, or substitute the sugar for pure honey from my husbands Uncle's bees.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-03-13T10:29:59.75
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
3606214
Display Name:
Rachel Swiger-Imhoff
isPro:
False

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5892824.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I forgot to add that if you add an egg wash to this bread, it takes it from really good to amazing. I mix up an egg really well and then brush it over both loaves before putting them in the oven, making sure to get every bit of exposed dough. It makes the crust nice and crispy and gives it a wonderful rich flavor.

text:
Excellent recipe, easy to make.  Not an expert, but I've made a lot of bread over the years, so not a newbie, either. I used bread flour and followed the recipe exactly except for the sugar.  I reduced it to 1/3 c. as recommended by several reviewers.  Bread rose beautifully, has a lighter texture than most breads I have made.  The only reason I did not give it 5 stars is because it does not have as strong a flavor as most breads I've made.  Possibly the trade off is due to how light a texture it is? because of the reduced sugar? not sure.  Anyway, a very worthwhile recipe.

text:
Absolutely wonderful. I cut the sugar to 1/4 cup as suggested. Let it rise for about 40 min for the second rise and it turned out fluffy and light. It hasn't even been out of the oven for a half hour and already half a loaf is gone! Even my little ones love it.

I want to add that this recipe is perfect for cinnamon buns as well. Do everything the same just in the end instead of forming into loaves, roll it out and spread a mixture of butter, cinnamon and brown sugar. Roll and cut into slices.

country:
None
text:
Read many reviews before I made this.  I cut the recipe in half to make only 1 loaf.  Following others advice, I cut the sugar to 1/4 cup and I feel that it was still too sweet.  I also had to add an additional 1/4 cup of flour as the dough was way too sticky to work with.  I used my kitchenaid dough hook to "knead" the dough for five minutes prior to letting it rise.  The texture was fluffy and not at all dense as described by many reviewers.  I will definitely make this again, without any sugar.

Its been my first time with this Amish white bread and I must say I am disappointed in both myself and this recipe. Amazing bread, according to my husband and kid. I took the second loaf, rolled it out and put a paste of cinnamon, butter and sugar on it and rolled it up to make cinnamon swirl bread.
Mine took several hours to rise properly (maybe my yeast??) and its not good for much more than toast or french toast by the second day.
Totally worth the effort of breadmaking. 
By the way, I just all-purpose flour and worked just fine!

Easy and delicious.  Make this OFTEN.  Using an electric knife really helps to get evenly spaced slices that are straight. I also roll it out, add fillings (cinnamon raisin, cheddar jalepeno, apples, etc.), roll it back up and bake.  My favorite was cranberry orange pecan.  Zest some orange, a good helping of craisins, pecans, roll it up like a jelly roll and it's a delicious loaf!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So easy and it turned out perfectly.  I did cut the sugar in almost half because I wanted a fluffier bread and it was just right.  I actually made colored bread by mixing all the liquids according to the directions, dividing it into thirds, adding food coloring to each, then adding the 1/3 of the flour to each bowl and following the directions for each batch.  At the dividing in half step after the first rise kneaded each batch a little, rolled into a rope, braided the 3 ropes, and then cut it in half and divided into 2 pans.  Next time I would cover the bread lightly with foil about halfway through to prevent some browning so the colors would show through better.

This special bread will be used for communion and it's hard to find a recipe that's not too crumbly, but this one works just right.

Very good white bread recipe!  I just made one loaf and used my bread machine to make the dough (just put the ingredients in the order suggested for my machine and set it on the dough cycle), then shaped it, let it rise in the pan, and baked it.  I will say that it is too sweet to use as regular sandwich bread, when I made a second loaf I reduced the sugar to 2 tablespoons.  Overall, a great recipe!

Just made this up for my family and they instintly fell in love with it. Thankfully I read some of the reviews and saw how folks felt it was to sweet. To avoid that I just used enough sugar to get the yeast going. Seeing as how I only have 1 bread pan I did the second loaf on my cast-iron griddle just rolled and shaped out like a loaf and it did very well like that. This was a very easy and tasty recipe. I will recommend this recipe to others as well as continue using it myself.

Display Name:
Amateur_cook_2009

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used unbleached all purpose flour, about 2 tbsp of olive oil + 1tbsp for rising bowl, about 2 cups of distilled water, 1 1/2 tsp sea salt, 1/2 cup of organic sugar. Used less than 6 cups of unbleached all purpose flour.
made the dough just like I would make a pizza dough with a 3 hour rise time (1 hour each). rolled the dough out with 
rolling pin and rolled it back up like a cinnamon roll. Cut three slits in loaf and let it rise in bread pan covered with towel for a hour and baked at 350 for 30 minutes. side note, it may come out better if bread flour is used.

userID:
7089015
Display Name:
damselfly
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

2
favoritesCount:
9

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe. It is very easy and delicious. I am a novice bread maker and it worked out very well. I did cut the sugar  in half. I have made it 3 times in the last 2 weeks.  I have also used 4 cups of bread flour and 2 cups of all purpose whole wheat flour and it worked out fine. Using 6 cups of  bread flour the loaves have a lot of loft and raise really quite high. When you use part whole wheat flour they don't raise quite as high, which I thought was a bit better. I find that the recipe quantity is also good for making one loaf and one pan of cinnamon buns. My husband loved this bread and so did my kids. From now on I will try to bake bread instead of buying store-bought. Thanks so much for this recipe.

text:
This bread is super easy to make. The more you knead this dough, the denser it will be. If your dough is tough, you've kneaded too much! I make two loaves every other month for homemade french toast- I wrap up the slices individually and freeze them for easy breakfasts. I do go lighter on the sugar than what this recipe calls for, as it is a pretty sweet bread.

text:
Meh.  Not sure if I should be blaming how the recipe was posted or how allrecipes corrected the ingredients per serving size requested, but I attempted to do 12 servings instead of 24.  When following the recipe the way it was suggested it was way too wet to the point that the consistency was comparable to pancake batter.  I added probably 1-2 more cups of flour to get the dough going and I think that may not have even been enough.

I let the bread rise for 2 hours the first round and 1 hour once in the bread pan.  Once in the oven it didn't rise very well, I'd say the height was probably 1/2 as high as a normal loaf of bread.  It was pretty yeasty and very sweet.  30 minutes was also not enough baking time - there were pockets throughout the loaf that were not fully cooked.  

I've baked quite a few loaves of bread so I'm not sure it was my fault how it turned out.  My husband said he liked it, and I'm certainly going to eat it, but I'm not sure I'd make it again.

Just like the bread I remember making with my grandmother as a child. Absolutely delicious and super easy to make! I didn't follow the recipe exactly; I dumped in a whole package of instant rise yeast instead of measuring (was only making one loaf and didn't want a little left over) and I added the flour a half cup at a time until the consistency was right as I kneaded it, I think I only used 2.5 cups. Amazing recipe and will definitely be making again!

10059414
Display Name:
IreneQ91690
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
What an awesome recipe! I wasn't sure if I was doing it right because there was a lot of loose flour when I was mixing it, and it was quite dry. so I added a cup of buttermilk. It took much longer than 20 minutes to prepare. I waited much more than 10 minutes (about 30) for the yeast to "proof" --- which I didn't know what that meant. Read the back of the yeast package. It didn't foam as much as I thought it was supposed to. Maybe someone can help me understand what "proof" means and what it looks like. 

Anyway, I decided to start kneading it and did so for 10 minutes. The consistency was fine. Then it didn't rise as much as other recipes have. It was supposed rise one inch above the pan, it barely cleared after I let it sit for 45 minutes. After 45 minutes, I put it in the oven for 30 minutes. When it was ready, I pulled out of the oven, the most beautiful loaves of bread!!!  After it cooled, I sliced it to sandwich sized pieces and made a PB & J with milk. I have to say it was heavenly. I think adding buttermilk reduced the sweetness and added to the awesomeness. 

I'll be making this recipe every week. Thank you for sharing it!!!
Review:

text:
My family absolutely LOVES this bread... We don't have a whole lot of money, so I decided to start making bread to save us from having to go buy it. I cut the recipe in half and made a loaf, but my loaf pan was too small and it came out pretty weird looking. >.> On my second try I cut the recipe in half, then cut the dough in half. I got two beautiful small loaves, one of which I kept for me and my boyfriend. The other I gave to his sister, and now I've been recruited to make all the bread for Thanksgiving. O.O Our 4-year old niece doesn't like bread, but with this recipe she'll sneak over and steal more when she thinks no one is looking. It's delightfully sweet without being overwhelming and goes great with so many other foods - we've had it with soup, chili, even used a few slices in place of hamburger buns! I recommend it for anybody who likes tasty, thick, delicious bread.

As a reluctant baker (and a very bad one), this recipe was the first yeast bread I've ever sucessfully made. I had no clue there was a special flour for bread...I followed the recipe almost religiously (I did lessen the amount of sugar a touch) and it came out beautiful and perfect. thanks for a great recipe...The only suggestion I have would would be to give novice bakers like myself a little more information on how long to knead the dough. I used my recently acquired KitchenAid mixer and it told me to use the dough hook on it for 5-6 minutes.

text:
I make this often :)  I mix up the dough in the bread machine then rise/bake in the oven.  Most recently, I rolled in some sugar and cinnamon to make cinnamon bread...today I will add some Chopped apples, as we just got back from the orchard.  This is my 'go-to' bread for my girls' lunch!  Do be aware that the dough is SUPER sticky! If you knead by hand, use enough flour.  I've even used 1C of cake flour for a more delicate dessert bread....Use this one again and again!

text:
Well, this is just wonderful bread!  I followed the recipe exactly, and it came out perfectly.  I did have to lower the temperature of my oven and allow the bread to bake for an additional 5 minutes, as it was still a bit doughy in the middle after the 30 minute bake time.  Tonight I just served it sliced and buttered, still hot from the oven and it was sooo yummy.  I am sure it is going to make great sandwich bread too.  I got a tip from a friend here on AR (thank you Keri!) to let it rise a third time before baking, and I will try that the next time I make it...which will be soon!  Thanks for a great recipe Peg :)

text:
for those of you who are having trouble watch this: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KbU7hEw7wNU&list=FLw2yp_CgP9yJpiPnt42PUTw&index=2&feature=plpp_video   

she is making the same bread but with less sugar. this help me out a lot (and i just made it for the first time today)..also a good tip i was told was to heat a cup of water in the microwave for two minutes, push to back or side..just to make room for dough in bowl or loaf pan. leave the door close for 30 minutes and your dough would rise perfectly.. ( by the way this tip is good for people who has cold kitchens like me)

country:
None
text:
Years ago, I bought a bread machine and swore off of hand-making bread.  This recipe has converted me back!  It is so easy to put together and is perfect for everything from simple buttered bread, to sandwiches to french toast.  I no longer purchase bread at the grocery store.  Great recipe, Peg!

*Update - I was having trouble with sandwich slices falling apart.  After some research indicating that more kneading leads to a denser bread, I now knead this bread for an extra 8 minutes after the first rise.  I had only been kneading for a couple minutes and the extra kneading time yielded a loaf that was still deliciously tender, but with slices that held together for sandwiches.  No more store-bought bread for this family!

Display Name:
Rev. Micheala Lauer

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent Bread, loved it! Thank you for this awesome recipe. I made it as is and then another batch, I reduced sugar to 1/4 cup, for the diabetics in family.  It did lend to be fluffier and not near as sweet or dense as the original recipe. We so enjoyed both ways. I did find that keeping the Temp of room @65* did make a difference. Make sure NO Cool breezes, or windows open near your cooking area, andbe sure not to have the area raising bread above 115* the yeast will die for certain! On second batch I turned oven on for about 3 minutes, turned it off opened door for 2 minutes, placed a pan of very warm water on bottom shelf then placed bread on middle rack to rise. Rose very quickly but evenly and such a smooth even top of loaf was my result. Like this method of rising also. I did find that it makes a big difference when making sure the dough is well oiled when readying to rise first time. Be sure to roll adequately in dish so well oiled all around.
Review:

userID:
9867110
Display Name:
MandiLandi

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use this recipe for all of my bread.  Bread making takes a little practice, and the amount of flour may vary!  My husband followed the ingredients precisely, and ended up with bricks.  If you're ending up with a dense bread, you're probably overworking it, or working in too much flour, by adding the full 6 cups.  It's important to follow step 2, and add in one cup at a time, until the dough isn't sticky, but is still stretchy.  Usually, I end up with 4 1/2 to 5 1/2 cups of flour actually IN the dough, and the rest just to flour the surface.  Makes for a much fluffier loaf, when you don't add quite so much flour.
Review:

5

text:
This recipe is so easy and cheap!  Very few ingredients!  I love that it uses oil instead of butter because I always have oil.  It's a great soft bread.  I always use all purpose flour and it's great!  The bread is ever so slightly chewy, but nice and soft.  Good sandwich bread... or anything bread, really.  I always let mine cool enough to handle, then put it in a sealed plastic container to keep the crust moist as it cools, then I store it in same container or a ziplock bag or an washed bread bag with a twist tie.  So, I don't know how the crust is naturally.  I also have to bake mine on the bottom rack.  The middle makes the top too brown.  Today I used this recipe to make cinnamon swirl bread.  I just rolled out the dough after the first rise to put on butter, cinnamon and sugar, then rolled it back up into a loaf and did the second rise. Really easy modification. Made two loaves and gave one to the three college students living above us. They were so excited! Its delicious!

I have made this bread about 5 times now, and it turns out consistently great each time. Measurements are dead on.  I also add a cup of white whole wheat for a bit of fiber. If you use more than a cup of ww flour, then be sure to use more yeast or vital yeast so it still rises nicely.  Good white bread, a touch of sweetness, but not overpowering or cloying.  Slices well and is great moist sandwich bread, that is, if you have any left after your family eats it fresh & warm from the oven, of course!

userID:
7490264
Display Name:
Tunaoue
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe is very basic and somewhat forgiving. My first attempt yielded loaves that were a tad too dense. When I tried again, instead of scooping flour with the one-cup measure, I weighed the amount instead. Scooping tends to pack the flour and usually you get 10-15% more than intended. Some baking web sights list all purpose flour as 4.5 ounces per cup. The recipe calls for 6 cups, so I weighted out 1 pound, 11 oz. The bread came out PERFECT. I've tried using shortening instead of oil, not much difference, I also like to use an egg wash of 1 egg and 2 tablespoons of milk - it gives a nice dark crust.  When baking I try to confirm if its done by using a temp probe or long meat thermometer. I usually try for 195-200 deg F about mid-loaf. It seems just a tad moist but if I let it rest for an hour and cool completely it turns out fine.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-02-13T02:40:46.623

text:
Fabulous recipe and most delicious white bread yet. Just getting back into baking breads after a 20 year haitus. Thank you Mr. Breadguy for your Kitchenaid directions except that I started with 4 cups of flour and then gradually added the rest 1/2 cup at a time.  Followed suggestions from others to cut back the sugar and used just 2 Tbsp. Light, moist, and wonderfully palate satisfying. Came out just perfect! This recipe will permanently replace my other white bread recipes. I intend to try some of the other very helpful variations posted! Thank you all!

Needless to say it doesnt last and if I don't make 2 loaves back to back then it is gone by the next day. I also cut the recipe down to 12 servings and put my machine on a 1.5 loaf setting. Throwing it in my bread machine cuts down on all of the time and work and with 3 kids I definitely need an short cut I can find. LOVE this recipe and will continue to make it over all others.

text:
This bread is absolutely delicious!  The only problem I have - which is not a big one - is that it tastes like a type of sweet bread.  So, if you are wanting regular white bread, cut the sugar down to 1/3 c. It's and excellent sweet bread, though!  I've also added about a teaspoon of cinnamon and about a cup of cranraisins to this recipe & my family loved it!

userID:
5892210
Display Name:
Ariana
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/54.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this bread multiple times since discovering it on allrecipes, and everybody loves it.  I haven't found it too sweet at all, personally.  For those who state it is dense/not fluffy, I suspect the issue is not letting the bread rise enough.  I check it after the given time, but find I need to let it rise longer to double in size (initial rising) and to later rise to 1" above the pan.  I find the loaves need to rise 45 minutes prior to being put in the oven.  But, I go by how it looks not a set time.  I put a damp cloth over the bowl and loaf pans and set it/them in a small room that has a heating fan, so the room will be warm enough for adequate rising.  I liked the suggestion of brushing the top with butter before putting it in the oven, and have been doing that.  It's a great recipe, in my opinion.  Reminds me of bread I had as a child in Europe (grew up in the Air Force).
Review:
Rating:
5
