text:
Made using kitchenaid.  Proofed yeast in warm bowl with water and sugar before adding the rest of ingrediants.  Kneaded on speed 2 for about 5 minutes and let rise half an hour first.  The second rise I did one hour.  Turned out perfect.  I also decreased the recipe to bake in 8x5 pans because my 9x5 were being borrowed.

text:
I cut the recipe in half to make 1 loaf instead of two.  I didn't care for it too much - i felt it was too dense and too sweet.  Even if I cut down on the amount of sugar I'm not sure that would improve its taste - but then again there are so many variables in this recipe that I could have gotten wrong so I can't really blame the recipe for it.  Maybe I didn't proof the yeast long enough, maybe i didn't let the dough rise long enough etc etc - but either way, i don't think i will try this recipe again.  The bread was not bad, but i expected a softer, fluffier bread than the one I was left with.

text:
I have literally made this bread hundreds of time and am never disappointed. It makes a great gift. With my family, the loaves never stay around long. I'd say it is best to eat it within 24 hours of making it!  I've varied the amount of sugar on several occasions with success. We live at a high altitude, but I'm never disappointed with how it rises and turns out. Yes, it's dense. Yes, it's sweet - but it's unbeatable for a tasty homemade treat.

text:
If you have struggled to make a good looking and good tasting loaf of bread.  Then this bread is for you!  I made it just like the recipe except - I didn't have bread flour so I used regular flour and 1 Tablespoon of wheat gluten.  Also, I make it in the Kitchenaid, but I take it out at the very end and knead it by hand for 30 seconds.  I like to feel it to make sure it is the right consistency.  Enjoy

text:
I like my bread to be a lot denser than this. While the taste was good, the texture came out a lot like hamburger buns (which I'll admit could be because I used partly bread flour and partly all-purpose). But if you're looking for a fluffy white bread, this is the recipe for you. Also, I would cut down a bit on the sugar.

Display Name:
Domino

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I decided to try it verbatim the first time, and I really enjoyed the way it turned out.  The sugar certainly was detectable in the finished product - to the point where next time I will cut it back as other reviewers have.  I did do one thing different though, I used a baking stone without bread pans.  I just shaped the dough after the rise into 2 loaves and baked them on stone that had preheated in the oven with a pan of water for moisture.  It was excellent!  The stone gave the bread a nice flat bottom while the lack of pan restriction gave the bread room to further rise while baking.  Sliced it made for delicious cinnamon toast.  I would certainly recommend this recipe to anyone.

text:
NEVER in all my days trying to bake bread have I done any better than bake bricks.  Today I tried this recipe and was delighted at just how easy the whole process was.  My yeast proofed perfectly.  The flour was easy to mix, although I was able only to add 5 1/2 cups, and the kneading was a breeze!  The dough doubled in size in about 30 minutes and, for the first time EVER, the dough in the loaf pans actually looked like loaves.  I took everyones advice and used 1/4 cup of sugar and the end result was deeeelicious!!!  I've been wanting to stop buying bread at the bakery for years, and now I can.  This recipie is easy and delicious.  I can't believe I did this!  You've got to try it.

text:
Absolutely delicious! But, I had to cut and eat it in squares, sort of like rolls, when I tried to slice it fell apart. But as long as I cut it in big chunks it stayed together and was great. I also had to bake for about 45 minutes on 350, not nearly done after 30 minutes. This bread is a little sweet which I prefer, but if you don't like sweet bread then you may want to cut back on sugar. Thanks for sharing Peg!

text:
This bread is fantastic!  I love it plain but I also like to experiment.  My favorite is to divide the dough in half, and knead in a bag of dried cranberries, blueberries, and cherries.  Then add as many pecans as your family can afford (I love nuts).  Once everything is distributed well form into one loaf and use the other half of the dough for plain white bread.

Extremely easy and delicious. I tried using just 1/4 c of sugar the first time and it wasn't sweet enough so I stick to the 2/3c and it's very yummy and not too sweet at all in my opinion. Be patient with the yeast as some types take longer to proof than others. I put an egg wash on the loaves and they come out looking beautiful. This recipe is a keeper and the loaves make great gifts.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the EASIEST recipe for homemade bread ever!!!  I followed the recipe exactly as stated (even used my digital meat thermometer to make sure the water was 110 degrees). I have screwed bread up so many times by either underheating or overheating the water.  Yeast cells are very sensitive little boogers.  They do their fermentation job perfectly at 110 degrees.  I measured out 2 Tbsp of yeast which turned out to be almost 1 strip of the 3 linked yeast packets.

I love this recipe.  I am a bread 'virgin'.  I had heard that bread was hard to make, but this recipe is awesome.  My yeast proofed well, my dough rose and ran over the edge of my ganny's wood bread bowl, and I was able to make a loaf and rolls.  It was light fluffy and sweet.  I substituted sugar for 1/4 cup of honey   it may be that the gods that be where nice to me, or the weather was right and wind was plowing from the right direction today, but first try was a hit. text:
This bread surprised me. I cut the recipe in half, making one loaf, and cut back the sugar just a tad (used just under 1/4 cup rather than 1/3 cup). I use my bread machine to bake bread in, but make the dough by hand. The dough didn't rise very much on the second rise, but as soon as it started baking it completely filled my 2 lb loaf pan. I overcooked it a little, the crust is a little too thick, but that's my fault - I'm still getting used to the bake only function and timing it right. The bread tastes wonderful. It's great and it's milk free!

None
text:
My first attempt at making bread...and success!  This recipe was easy to make (my 4 year old even helped), and it turned out beautifully!  My hubby has never seen me so excited "Look! the bread actually rose!). I wasn't sure about putting the yeast into the full amount of water and sugar as the packaging instructed to proof it in only 1/4 cup of water with 1 tsp sugar, but it worked.  I kept the dough in the oven with a hot bowl of water on the bottom rack to help make it rise faster.  I'll be making this bread again, maybe getting adding some rosemary, cinnamon or other herbs and spices to change things up a bit.

text:
The only reason I didn't give this recipe the full 5 stars is because it isn't at its best the day after baking. This bread is phenomenal right out of the oven and for the rest of the day, but if you're making it for guests or something, plan to bake it the same day you'll be serving it. And if you have any leftovers the next day, they make marvelous french toast!  This bread is also exquisite made into cinnamon rolls!

country:
None
text:
This was GREAT!  It's my first time making bread and it turned out wonderful.  I will never buy store-bought white bread again!  Like many others, I didn't want a sweet bread so I added 1 tablespoon of sugar and 2 tablespoons of honey.  I wasn't sure if I could do all honey...  Next time I'm going to try adding some whole wheat, maybe half, and all honey.  And I plan to make a loaf with cinnamon & raisins and that one I will make sweet!  : )  The only thing I would add to the recipe is a note that yeast can take 10-15 minutes to foam.  I read that from other reviewers beforehand, but if someone doesn't know...  Other than that it really is fool-proof!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was inspired to try to bake my own bread by some advertisements I saw recently for a bread machine.  I was very surprised that I did so well with my first try on a yeast bread.  I kneaded the dough in my stand mixer according to the KitchenAid instructions in the manual.  I followed the recipe to the letter, except I brushed the tops of the loaf with butter and baked in the oven with a cookie sheet filled with water.  The bread is a little sweet, but was delicious right out of the oven with a little butter.  Next time, I will decrease the sugar to three tablespoons.  I'll update my review with any changes.  I say cut the recipe in half and try it as is and then make any necessary adjustments thereafter.  UPDATE 4/6/11:  Made as is, except subed a stick of margarine for the oil.  Left first loaf as is.  For second loaf, rolled out then with rolling pin, added cheese and italian seasoning blend and rolled back up.  Added more cheese and seasoning on top.  Drizzled both with an extra tablespoon of olive oil and baked as directed.  OH MY GOODNESS..made the best bread I have ever tasted.  The plain loaf was not too sweet at all, had a beautiful golden brown crust and amazing texture.  The cheesy bread was the absolute best, golden brown crust as well with a swirl of cheese in the middle...will make great turkey, ham or roast beef sandwiches.  Highly recommended, definitely deserves more than 5 stars!!

I used the second part to make cinnamon buns.  I rolled it out.   Put pats of butter, nuts, brown sugar and cinnamon in it.  Rolled it up like a jelly roll then cut them. region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great recipe. Based on others' comments, I used only 1/3 cup of sugar when proofing the yeast, and it came out pleasantly sweet, but not overpoweringly so. I also used AP flour & came out with a slightly denser bread, but had no problems - it just didn't rise as much pre- baked, but the loaves really puffed up when in the oven. I wouldn't recommend this as a dinner bread; it's much better as a breakfast bread with some butter or jam.

text:
I love making everything I can from scratch and went on a baking craze today. I took a previous reviewers suggestion and made one loaf and used the rest of the dough to make cinnamon rolls for breakfast tomorrow! I also used 1/2 cup of sugar because I was scared off by everyone saying the bread was too sweet and I'd say I'll try to full 2/3 cup next time, since I really didn't find it too sweet. AND on a side note, I've made many a white bread recipe and this one is by far the LEAST dense (we'll see how it holds up to sandwiches) but you definitely don't feel weighed down by eating a few slices! 
EDIT: I just through together a loaf of this, and although my house is cold and it didn't rise perfectly it still turned out delicious, on my third slice now.

userID:
910715
Display Name:
Leslie Schnare Harnish
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1988523.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The quantities in this recipe worksperfectly with my dough hooks in my Phillips mixer, which is a bit less powerful than the basic Kitchenaid mixer.  I keep forgetting to reduce the amount of sugar because that much isn't needed but it always comes out great.  We let the dough go to the first rising and then use it for "dough slingers" or "toutons" as they are called in Newfoundland.  Tear strips of bread off the size of a golf ball and flatten them a bit.  Fry them in oil like a pancake. Slice the touton down the middle, butter and coat with molasses, jam or just plain sugar.  Not healthy, but makes a hearty breakfast, and a good accompaniment to bacon and eggs!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i make this bread several times a week and it is great!  in saying that, it also is unpredictable.  one time i will make it and the dough seems too dry, next time it is sticky and tacky!  the time it takes to rise (the first time) is usually for me between and hour and an hour and a half and the second time (after punching down and transferring to pans) no less than an hour.  i keep my home fairly cool in the summer.  regardless of the dryness or how sticky or tacky the dough is, when baked, it comes out perfectly.  do NOT be discouraged if your dough doesn't seem exactly right.  this dough is nearly fool proof.  : )

text:
This a very good bread. It has a nice soft texture and a rather plain flavor which makes it good to use for sandwiches. However, I found that 350 made my bread very well done on the outside after about 18 minutes and the inside wasn't all the way done. I think a lower temp for a longer time would be better. Good recipe though and I'll certainly try it again because the parts that were cooked were delightful.

country:

text:
I join the ranks of all those who've rated this with 5+ stars! My very first attempt making bread dough. It's been raining pretty much non-stop where I live for last 5+ weeks, so good way to spend another rainy Sunday. Couldn't believe how perfectly they came out - was so proud of myself! I made sure to read many posts first, so I cut the sugar amount in half. Altho I like sweet breads, any more would've been too much. I also made mine in 8.5" x 4.5" pans so they did rise a bit too high. Next time I'll use 1 cup less flour, even if using 9x5 pan - nightmare trying to stir that last cup in & doesn't seem necessary. This is an amazing bread; my husband crazy about it & both loaves were gone in 3 days, w/just the 2 of us!  It's easy AND delicious, & like so many others wrote, I will never buy store bread again!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the first time I have ever attempted to make bread form scratch and I am very pleased with the results. I decreased the sugar to 1/4 cup and would still decrease it more as it is plenty sweet. I used the advice of others and used my mix-master with the dough hook and slowly added the flour and didn't increase the speed to more than 2. I also made a small 4cm diameter round pan of mini cinnamon buns. The whole recipe turned out great. Will make again. Thanx for sharing. Update: I tryed this again but decreased the sugar to 1/8 cup and also used 4 cups white flour and two cups whole wheat..turned out great. I don't recommend using the dough that way for cinnamon buns as it was tougher to roll out and when I cooked them the middle of each bun popped up. Looked pretty but not what I wanted

userID:
2723363
Display Name:
CookingMaMa08
isPro:
False
followersCount:
17
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
61
favoritesCount:
333
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/69156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I enjoyed the process of making this bread. It came out amazingly good. I don't have a bread machine and glad that it is still do-able by hand. I couldn't find bread flour from my local grocery store, so I used all-purpose flour. All-purpose flour makes my bread less chewy and more alike a "biscuit bread". But it is still very good. I think proofing the yeast is the key to this recipe. I don't have anything to measure the temperature of my water so here's what I did - 1. Put cold water into microweave on high for 1 min. - 1 min. and 20 sec. 2. Put sugar (I used 1/4 cup) into the warm water, if it dissolve easily with a few stir, the water is good. Make sure the water is warm, not hot. 3. Put the yeast into the sugar water, stir a few times to make sure the yeast is sub-merge into the water. And WAIT for about 10-13 minutes. You should then see a layer of bubbles. In my case, the layer of bubble was thin, and the yeast reacted to the water slowly. Check the expiration date of your yeast BEFORE use. If your yeast is too old, it will not work. This recipe is simple, but it requires patience. So wait a bit longer for your dough to rise. All in all, this is a keeper. I just had a nice thick slice of the bread for breakfast this morning. I toast the slice and spread my favorite raspberry preserve all over.....oh heaven!
Review:

5

city:

None
text:
I LOVE this recipe!! Couoldn't be easier! I've been making this recipe for several months now after not having made bread since helping grandma when I was 8. I was looking for something to do w/ all the flour I had sitting in my cupboard from cleaning out my father-in-law's place, wanted to make bread but didn't have any eggs. And I'm lazy :) One thing I did though is actually double the yeast and increase the sugar to about a full cup. I don't find it too sweet at all and everyone who's tried it so far loves it. And by increasing the yeast, I get a good rise both times and can get 3 loaves out of the same amount of flour. I would really like to try hand kneading it but my counter space doesn't allow for it. The electric mixer my Dad got me for Christmas after trying my first attempt works wonders!!

Excellent recipe!!  Thanks for sharing!  I actually used a bread machine to make the dough and it worked beautifully. I just followed basic bread machine order (liquid, flavoring agents, and fat on bottom, flour on top w/ yeast in the center of the flour "volcano") and it came out great, before baking i brushed with a little melted honey butter (I know everyone says its a bit sweet, but I am making it for breakfast). This is definitely a keeper because you don't need to run to the store for a bunch of ingredients!

text:
First-time baking bread and it turned out great! Like others, I used only 1/4 cup sugar. Just a note of caution to new bread bakers like me: I was scared when it first came out of the oven because it smelled and tasted too yeasty. I though I ruined it. Baking it at night, I let it cool, wrapped it, and then went to it the next morning, hoping for better results. Everything was fine. The yeasty smell and taste were gone. Thanks so much for this great recipe. I'll be sure to bake a lot more of it in the future, God willing.

Wow! This is a winner in my house, I made exactly how stated (my husband has a sweet tooth)and it turned out great. I doubled the recipe and with another caramel sauce from this site it made the sweetest carmel rolls. One bread loaf was gone before it even had a chance to cool off. text:
This was an amazingly forgiving and successful surprise.  I NEVER rate a recipe, but this is TOO GOOD to not comment.  It was a crazy day and I decided to try a new bread recipe (this one).  It was very easy to pull together, kneaded like a dream, and did the first rise like clockwork.  That's when the day went crazy.  I had a dishwasher installer show up an hour early and stay for 3 1/2 hours just at the moment I was going to punch down the dough, knead a second time and form my loaves.  So, by the time I actually got to this, I was a full 2 1/2 hours late.  I did it anyway.  I let it rise in the pans for about 45 minutes - didn't rise that high, but I thought Ok, lets bake them off and I can use them for Thanks Giving stuffing.  THEY CAME OUT PERFECTLY RISEN, LIGHT AND FLUFFY, PICTURE PERFECT CRUST, AND DELICIOUS.  I can't wait to make them again..

Wow!! This recipe is fantastic!!! I may never buy white bread again! I hosted a tea party and wanted to make pink bread for some of my cucumber tea sandwiches. reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/88456.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a wonderful bread.  I made it with my Kitchen Aid mixer and it turned out much better then anything that you make in the bread machine.  I find that a bread machine mixes for far to long and makes the dough tough resulting in a heavy bread.  I also reduced the amount of sugar to 1/2 cup and it was plenty sweet.  If you let this bread rise the second time for the full amount of time stated, you may find the bread overflowing from the pan BUT the result is a very fluffy white bread.  Perfect :)

text:
GREAT! After it cools it slices so beautiful. I use this as a daily bread in our home for sandwiches or warn with butter for dinners! I let it rise 2 times and punched down, then seperated into loaves and let it rise for baking. add a touch of honey for a little extra flavor although this recipe needs no help! Use an unbleached flour to keep it natural, unbleached is far better than bleached anyway!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So good, I made this bread twice in the last 24 hours!  The first time, I used King Arthur White Whole Wheat Flour.  My first time baking bread from scratch.  I worried about everything - did I let the yeast proof long enough, did I knead it long enough, did I let it rise enough....but it came out very good.  Today, I made it with regular white bread flour.  One of my loaf pans is slightly bigger than the other, and I wanted some big slices for sandwiches, so I split the dough about 2/3 and 1/3.  But, there was no need to - both loaves rose much better with the white flour.  Much tastier, too! Reduced sugar to 1/3 cup for both batches.

text:
I'm a total bread novice, but I made this bread today with minimal effort.  I followed the recipe as is with the exception of the flour, I used a half white/half wheat flour.  I made the adaptations for mixing in my Kitchen Aid with the dough hook and over all it was fairly simple once I researched exactly what letting the yeast perk was.  The bread came out very good and tasty and my entire family thinks it tastes like the bread they bring to the table at Longhorns Steak House.  We love it.  For sandwiches I do think that next time I will cut the sugar in half.  It's not bad as is, just sweeter than I typically like my sandwich bread.

We'll definitely make it again.

text:
This was easy-I made them into cinnamon rolls, but next time I think I will half the dough before rolling it out. But the end result was wonderful! I used syrup, heated in the microwave, added some vanilla, brown sugar & southern comfort and put that in the bottom of a glass baking dish & set aside. As for filling, I used brown & white sugar, nutmeg, grd cloves and melted butter. I had to let it rise for about 40min. and baked it at 350 for about 1hr. (it stayed raw in the middle-due to the excessive dough in an inadiquite dish) then i turned it out on a foil lined cookie sheet and spooned the "goo" on the upside. It reheated very well the next morn!!! next time when i make this, I am going to make two seperate dished for the rolls. Love it,Love it!!

text:
This bread was ok and probably would have been great if I knew how to work with yeast more.  I thought the yeast was ready because of it's foamy appearance and I didn't think my water was too hot, but I let the dough rise for 1.45 hours and it didn't double.  I put it all into one bread tin and let it rise for another 1/2 hour and this made a huge loaf.  I only used 1/4 cup sugar like other reviewers suggested but I think I will add more next time.  I'll make it again and hopefully give it a better rating next time.

I made this bread in my KitchenAid mixer- it doesn't get easier than that. After baking 30 minutes, I removed the bread from the pan right away onto a cooling rack, then buttered the tops and covered with a towel. {It helps to soften the top} I also reduced the sugar to 2T. for more of a traditional white bread. Great!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the first time I have successfully baked bread and the first time my family has smelled the delicious aroma of homemade bread wafting through the house! The end product after I halved the recipe, for fear of failing and therefore wasting more ingredients, and further reduced the amount of sugar to 1/4 cup was light, fluffy and not too sweet. I also used unbleached, enriched, all purpose flour instead of bread flour. Since an ineptness for cooking/baking is inherent in our entire family and thus we never bake anything besides premade/presliced cookies, we don't own a loaf pan, so instead I sliced the dough in half after the first rise and punch down, molded each piece into a baguette-like shape and placed them onto a greased cookie tray before the 2nd rise. This recipe is fantastic and easy enough for a beginner like me to make!

Display Name:
klwng

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is excellent. My husband & kids love the bread. I use only 1/4C sugar as other comment & with the help of a KitchenAid, it saves me lot of time & work. UPDATE: 1. I use fast(instant) rising yeast instead of traditional yeast. Use same amount as recipe stated. Just add directly to the bread flour, no proof needed (save you the step for proofing yeast). 2. Then follow the recipe: make sure sugar solved in the warm water (about 110F) & blend oil in (as wet ingredient). Add wet ingredient to dry ingredient. 3. I use Kitchen Aid to knead the dough. Knead about 15 mins or more, until SMOOTH (very important). 4. I add extra 2 - 4 Tbsp water to the dough when kneading since the air here is dry (diff flour/temp/humid will affect how much water needed). 5. Microwave is a good place to proof the dough. I heat up a cup of water in the microwave then put the dough in the microwave (the heated water will provide warmth & humid to proof the dough, don't forget to close the door). 6. Since I only have 8 x 4 loaf pans, so I only use 2/3 recipe to make 2 perfect loafs.
Review:
Rating:
5

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Great bread. It was definitely sweet, but in a way that I would still eat with a sandwhich or meal.  I used a little bit less sugar, but not a measured amount less, I just didn't fill the measuring cup quite all the way up. 

I used all purpose flour because I didn't have any bread flour.

It was definitely pretty easy to make. I made bread one other time before this, but this bread came out really well. Kneading took less time than I expected and all in all it was easy to do this whole process after work, eating dinner while the dough rose and then baking after I had finished eating. 

I made the bread a second time, and this time I substituted olive oil for vegetable oil, then added in chopped kalamata olives and rosemary when I was kneading. I made 2 rolls and a loaf (from a halved recipe), and it was very very good.

text:
I had a very dear Grandmother who made bread for a living. It was always a treat to get a loaf for ourselves because they were always sold to others. She has since passed away. This bread reminds my so much of her bread. It is moist and sweet and a great dense texture. I used half milk and half water. I also made the dough in my bread machine and transfered to my bread pan after the final knead. It was so easy and tasty that I hope to make this a family favorite just like my Grandma's bread.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
2-18-2007 This is the first time I've made bread and I had a lot of issues with the rising of the dough. I am thinking my house was too cold. Once I put it in the oven on low it worked I'm thinking perhaps it was denser because of this. I will try again. Also halved the recipe and it may have affected the outcome.

Update 4-12-2007 Ok so I made sure the house was much warmer and I ended up with a slightly different result. However I also added a bit of water to aid with the flour mixing. What a difference! There should be a little more in the recipe. If not the flour sits on the dough and you get a dusty mess. When I finished adding the flour this time (adding water using my cupped hand while kneading) I had a beautiful round smooth ball of dough. I thought the flavor was nicer this time as well. Perhaps use butter or butter flavor or something other than canola spray to coat the pan...the flavor is still there and reminds me of the taste of something fried. Excellent when first warm (we ate half the loaf). Trying toast tonight :)

They both were awesome, but this bread can be used for everything, incl. sandwiches!  The other better accompanies a meal.  A KEEPER FOR SURE!!!  Thanks for this recipe!!  ALSO:  I made this recipe AS IS w/o halving the sugar, as some suggested.  IT was great!!  I also put a pan of boiling water in oven under the bread during the rising stage, for 30 
minutes.

text:
Brilliant recipe! A nice dense bread, just like I've been looking for (airy just isn't my thing). I reduced the sugar some, as suggested by other people, but it still left a nice hint of sweetness and a lovely texture. Due to circumstances, I didn't have the bowl and oil to coat the bread in for rising, so I just floured it thoroughly and it worked just peachily. I think I'll try making cinnamon buns with this recipe, and maybe a braided Christmas bread. Huzzah!

Lovely bread!  Nice texture and crust!  I used raw sugar (less sweet than refined) and it was perfect.  I brushed the top of the loaves with egg white prior to putting in the oven and it came out with a beautiful glossy golden color.  This is a great everyday bread!
Thanks!

Beyond Perfection!  I made this exactly as the recipe stated and have no complaints whatsoever.  My past attempts at home made bread have always resulted in a dense, sometimes bland loaf.  Not this loaf, it's fluffy and so flavorful.  I can't be happier.  This is THE bread recipe from now on!  This was also extremely easy to prepare. text:
This is a great bread recipe.  I did a couple of things differently.  I used 2 cups of wheat flour instead of bread flour, I also used platic warp to cover instead of a damp cloth.  I didn't have 9 by 5 inch bread pans, so I decided to make one very large loaf in a 11 by 5 inch pan, and the bread turned out wonderful, and the baking time remained the same.  This bread is not too sweet at all.  Maybe I have a sweet tooth and can't taste all the sugar.  It makes for wonderful sandwiches.  The bread cuts easily.  I'm very pleased with the way my bread turned out, and how wonderful it tastes.

text:
Allrecipes is the best cooking site on the internet.  I am always looking for good recipes and this is where I usually find them.  This recipe is one of the BEST I have found.  Just took my first two loaves out of the oven and couldn't wait to try to see if the 400+ reviews were right.  My husband was my guinea pig, and he fell in love with this bread with the first bite.  When I find a recipe that works, it absolutely stays in my recipe file for the duration.  Wouldn't change a thing.  I add my 5-star review to all the others.  Also, I made the dough in my breadmaker.  It worked just great.  I put the oil, water, salt and sugar in first, then added the flour and yeast.  Set the machine on "dough" setting and hit the start button.  After dough is made, divide in 2 equal parts, place in 9x5 greased pans, let rise and bake in normal manner.  TOTALLY WONDERFUL!!

text:
This bread is easy to make and very tasty.    I did follow the advice of other and cut the sugar to 1/4 cup -- and even then I though it was a little too sweet, but my family loved it. When I cut the sugar down even more, to 2T, the bread was inedible.  The dough is also excellent for making mini-pizzas, which I top with a chopped tomato-onion-ham mixture or a mushroom-onion-sour cream mixture and then sprinkle with mozzarella cheese. Yummy!

Turtley

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
EUREKA! After years of searching I have finally found an easy, light, and tasty bread! I have made over 12 loaves with this recipe and each one has been great!  I took the advice of reducing the sugar to 1/2 c., but it was good with 2/3 c. too.  If you are going to use sweet toppings less sugar is better.  Also, I "proofed" the yeast until it formed a 1-2" head(15-30mins), sifted the flour, did both risings in the oven set on "warm", covered the loaves with foil the last 10 mins to prevent overbrowning, and brushed the with melted butter after baking.  I have used both all-purpose and bread flour didn't make any difference. Awesome! Thank You!

text:
This was my first attempt EVER at homemade bread.  I wasn't sure why the yeast wouldn't "melt" and ended up throwing away two packages of it.  I figured out that it wouldn't "melt" in the sugar, so I melted it first in the water, then added the sugar.  I wasn't sure what a "creamy foam" was supposed to look like, so I just waited for about 5 minutes before continuing and I made the most beautiful loaves!!

text:
This is the second time I've baked this bread and, frankly, I don't know what all the fuss is about.  Yes, it's a tasty bread (I agree that the original recipe is too sweet), but it isn't the best I've ever made.  Considering the amount of yeast required I was surprised thatI had to double the "rise times" and I have a toasty kitchen.  I thought that perhaps I had made a mistake the first time but the second attempt yielded the same results. This time I made the second loaf into cinnamon bread and it is very good.

I love this recipe! It's become somewhat of a staple at my house since I first tried it a year ago! I always substitute honey for the white sugar now. Just personal preference. Reminder: ALWAYS proof your yeast.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This might be called "Dan 'n' Linda's 10-pound thumpy biscuits."

We are evidently in need of remedial bread dough training.  Perhaps the instructions would benefit from specifying the amount of time to knead the dough.

We couldn't get the dough smooth even after about half an hour of kneading (hmm... did we learn something?).
Perhaps we don't know the right definition of smooth.  It never rose the inch above the pan that it was supposed to.  The bread came out dense with a craters of the moon surface and layers of air and undercooked dough.  An interesting culinary experience indeed.

Any advice would be appreciated.

PS.  The yeast was quite fresh, and all ingredients (except, perhaps, kneading time) were measured carefully.
